At 10 a.m. precisely, air-raid sirens sounded throughout Israel today and the country froze in its tracks for two minutes to remember the victims of the Holocaust. Drivers stood at attention beside their cars, shopkeepers stepped onto the sidewalk and pedestrians halted in mid-stride, their heads bowed or defiantly upright.But this did not happen in Mea Shearim or other strictly Orthodox neighborhoods. In Mea Shearim, as if the call of the siren was a car alarm, religious Jews in black frock coats and black felt hats did not pause, or interrupt conversations, or stop their shopping.At 10 a.m. precisely, air-raid sirens sounded throughout Israel today and the country froze in its tracks for two minutes to remember the victims of the Holocaust. Drivers stood at attention beside their cars, shopkeepers stepped onto the sidewalk and pedestrians halted in mid-stride, their heads bowed or defiantly upright.But this did not happen in Mea Shearim or other strictly Orthodox neighborhoods. In Mea Shearim, as if the call of the siren was a car alarm, religious Jews in black frock coats and black felt hats did not pause, or interrupt conversations, or stop their shopping.''Where does this thing of the siren come from?'' said Shai, a young Hasidic Jew with long strawberry-blond side curls, who would not give his last name. ''It's someone else's custom -- the English, the goyim,'' or non-Jews. ''What we as Jews do is recite religious texts. And not just today, but every day. To stand silent, like goyim, is to insult the name of those burned to death for their beliefs.''A woman shopper, dressed in a long skirt, her head covered with a tight scarf, agreed. ''God thinks it's a goyish holiday,'' she said of Holocaust Remembrance Day, which is a somber national holiday in Israel. Restaurants, theaters and nightclubs shut down, and schools and radio and television stations devote themselves to Holocaust education.''They have their customs,'' she said, nodding toward secular Israel in general. ''We have God.''For many Israelis the shunning of Holocaust Day by ultra-Orthodox Jews rubs extra salt in the wounds of a divided society. The haredim -- literally those who tremble before God -- also do not observe Israel's Independence Day or its Memorial Day. But many Israelis consider the Day of the Shoah, as it is known here, to be the one time when the Jews of Israel should stand -- literally -- together.''The haredim have set up parallel institutions for everything,'' said Efraim Zuroff, a Holocaust historian, a modern Orthodox Jew and the local director of the Simon Wiesenthal Center. ''But one would have hoped that the Holocaust would be the one exception. What did the Holocaust teach us, if not that Jewish unity was essential?''The matter is actually a complex internal Jewish dispute, not only about the way that the Holocaust should be remembered but about Holocaust history itself.In the haredi world, a string of new books, films and museum projects is sketching out an alternative to the official account of the Holocaust that is taught in Israeli schools and featured at Yad Vashem, the national Holocaust memorial.The mainstream account, by this reckoning, overemphasizes the physical heroism and martyrdom of nonreligious Jews who resisted the Nazis. It glorifies the fighters, they say, just as Zionists in Israel exalt the soldiers of the national army in which most haredim, who believe that they serve the country by keeping strictly observed Jewish traditions alive, do not serve.The date for Holocaust Remembrance Day, in fact, was fixed by Israel to commemorate the Warsaw ghetto uprising of 1943, in which the underground Jewish Combat Organization led Polish Jews in a four-week revolt against their deportation to Nazi concentration camps.''Why do we give more importance to the physical fighters?'' said Rabbi Menachem Mendel Taub, a Holocaust survivor who is known as the rebbe of Kaliv, the Hungarian city whose Hasidic Jewish community he and five generations of ancestors led. ''What about the rabbis and yeshiva students who clung to the religious commandments until the end? Did they not defend the soul of the Jewish people? Are they not as important to Israel today as F-16's and A-bombs?''More pointedly, Moshe Gorelick, in an article in a haredi weekly titled ''Even in Israel They Deny the Holocaust,'' said the official Holocaust Day explicitly disdained those who ''kept their godly souls until the last minute'' as ''going like lambs to the slaughter.''It is well known here that many haredim avoid Yad Vashem, which almost every other Israeli visits regularly as a schoolchild and a soldier. Most often they cite religious objections to the nude photographs of skeletal Holocaust victims. A deputy mayor of Jerusalem, an ultra-Orthodox Jew, created a stir several years ago when he threatened to cut off funds to Yad Vashem if the ''immodest'' pictures were not taken down.But ultra-Orthodox rabbis say the key complaint is ideological. The museum, they say, does not sufficiently pay tribute to religious martyrs, among them rabbis who had visas that would have allowed them to emigrate but stayed in Europe to lead -- and die with -- their followers.Rabbi Taub is one who is working to append the official history. He has published two volumes of a Holocaust encyclopedia filled with the stories of pious Jews who observed Jewish law against all odds in the ghettos and concentration camps.And he is raising money to build an alternative Holocaust museum in Jerusalem, for which the cornerstone has been laid. Another museum project, by a separate organization, is under way in Bnei Brak.After the Holocaust Remembrance ceremonies began on Monday night, the rabbi was interviewed in Bnei Brak, a religious community near Tel Aviv, through his personal secretary. The rabbi does not take questions from a woman; his secretary posed the questions. His assistants placed a large picture frame between the rabbi and this reporter so that his view would be blocked.He talked to the ceiling, alternating English from his 17 years in the United States with Hebrew and Yiddish. At the end he offered a blessing, both verbally and in the form of a small plastic pouch containing a 10-agorot coin, worth a few pennies.''When somebody is in jail for dozens of years, he promises to himself that when he is released he will do good things,'' the rabbi said. ''Usually his good intentions fade. I promised myself the day that I survived the Shoah that I would think about this day and night. What does a single day, Holocaust Day, mean?''To Holocaust survivors and to many of those taking part in the official ceremonies, it means a great deal. About 230,000 Israelis once lived under Nazi rule, according to Israeli statistics released today, and the population of survivors is dwindling. Some 20,000 have died since 1997.Prime Minister Ehud Barak and other government officials took part in an annual tradition today, reading, with breaking voices, the names of Jews killed in the Holocaust.In an editorial, a haredi newspaper, Hamodia, said ''God-fearing'' Jews still use ''these same names, in the same books, in the same customs, and in the same tradition that the opinion-makers in Israel would wish to put in a museum.'' Some religious Jews believe that they themselves are recreating the European Jewish village life that was wiped out during the Holocaust.Mr. Zuroff, author of a new book, ''The Response of Orthodox Jewry in the United States to the Holocaust'' (Yeshiva University Press), said he thought that the haredim had a hard time dealing with Holocaust history.The very fact of it is difficult for a person of deep faith, as were costly mistakes made by their leaders. Some Hasidic rabbis, for instance, ordered their followers to stay in Europe and not flee, which ultimately was devastating, he said. Then, while some top rabbis perished with their communities, others fled themselves.But ultra-Orthodox leaders disagree, and in the streets of Mea Shearim this morning, it came down to something more basic: Holocaust Day is a secular event, dictated by the secular authorities. And the haredim obey what they consider to be the higher authority of the Torah.Holocaust Day falls during the Hebrew month of Nissan, a month of celebration, when strictly Orthodox Jews are barred from public expressions of mourning. Modern Orthodox Jews believe that it is literal-minded to think that the ban should apply to Holocaust Day.But the strictly observant say that Judaism marks tragic events in the life of Jewish people on Tisha B'Av, a day of fasting and mourning that commemorates the destruction of the First Temple in 586 B.C. and the Second Temple in the year 70. Other Jews, they say, have allowed the Holocaust to dominate their worldview.''All Jewish history does not begin and end with the Holocaust,'' said Jonathan Rosenblum, a haredi spokesman.
The American political scene has always been enlivened by protests. But there are not many parallels to the recent rebellion among wealthy businesses tired of being hit up by Democrats and Republicans for campaign donations. As Don Van Natta Jr. reported in The Times this week, at least 31 corporations that have given big soft-money contributions in recent election cycles appear to be boycotting the process this year. Most are backing off quietly, but a few have stepped forward to say that swearing off soft money has not brought retaliation from the political establishment. Their disgust with the excesses of fund-raising could be another impetus to enactment of campaign finance reform this year.Late last year Trent Lott, the Senate majority leader, and other foes of the McCain-Feingold bill that would ban the unlimited donations to political parties known as soft money never tired of saying that this was an issue of little interest to American voters. Then the reform cause was energized by Senator John McCain's primary campaign, and by a Democratic race in which Vice President Al Gore declared that enactment of the soft-money ban would be one of his highest priorities as president.The American political scene has always been enlivened by protests. But there are not many parallels to the recent rebellion among wealthy businesses tired of being hit up by Democrats and Republicans for campaign donations. As Don Van Natta Jr. reported in The Times this week, at least 31 corporations that have given big soft-money contributions in recent election cycles appear to be boycotting the process this year. Most are backing off quietly, but a few have stepped forward to say that swearing off soft money has not brought retaliation from the political establishment. Their disgust with the excesses of fund-raising could be another impetus to enactment of campaign finance reform this year.Late last year Trent Lott, the Senate majority leader, and other foes of the McCain-Feingold bill that would ban the unlimited donations to political parties known as soft money never tired of saying that this was an issue of little interest to American voters. Then the reform cause was energized by Senator John McCain's primary campaign, and by a Democratic race in which Vice President Al Gore declared that enactment of the soft-money ban would be one of his highest priorities as president.Now business support for reform is growing. Senator Mitch McConnell has contended that businesses give money in order to ''participate'' in the political process, with no expectation of anything in return. But business leaders from the Committee for Economic Development and the Campaign for America, led by the investor Jerome Kohlberg, have characterized the campaign finance system as a shakedown operation. Many big businesses like General Motors, Time Warner and Allied Signal have concluded that the money they were spending on political contributions is better spent elsewhere.But of course many businesses and special interests still give to get something in return for their donations. Philip Morris and the National Rifle Association, two of the biggest givers to the Republicans, have gotten politicians to oppose efforts to regulate guns and tobacco. The question is whether the public wants big questions like a patients' bill of rights, the creation of Social Security investment accounts and policies on software, telecommunications and Internet companies to be decided by who can give the biggest donations to whom.Unfortunately, Gov. George W. Bush has so far joined Mr. Lott as an obstacle to reform. He says he favors a ban on corporation and union contributions to parties, but he would leave open a wide loophole by allowing unlimited donations to parties from individuals. Like other opponents of reform, he calls it a free speech issue. But Congress set limits on individual donations to candidates in 1974 after the Watergate scandals, and the legislation before Congress would simply extend those limits to donations to parties, which have been used to undermine the old reforms.Mr. McCain is to meet with the presumptive party nominee in a few days to talk about issues. He needs to press Mr. Bush to support his campaign finance legislation in the Senate, where it commands majority support, and Mr. Bush ought to sign on to real reform. Americans want it. Most in Congress want it. Now even the donors want it. Mr. Bush and Mr. Lott should not stand in their way.
Aides to Gov. George W. Bush fought back today against accusations that his fiscal proposals are risky, saying that the growth in the economy over the past six months meant that there would be enough money to accommodate comfortably the governor's spending and tax cut proposals.Mr. Bush's advisers released a new analysis of his budget plans after days in which Vice President Al Gore has sharply criticized Mr. Bush on fiscal issues. Mr. Gore has asserted that Mr. Bush's large tax cut proposal and plan to push for a portion of Social Security payroll taxes to be put into private investment accounts would return the nation to the era of deficits.Aides to Gov. George W. Bush fought back today against accusations that his fiscal proposals are risky, saying that the growth in the economy over the past six months meant that there would be enough money to accommodate comfortably the governor's spending and tax cut proposals.Mr. Bush's advisers released a new analysis of his budget plans after days in which Vice President Al Gore has sharply criticized Mr. Bush on fiscal issues. Mr. Gore has asserted that Mr. Bush's large tax cut proposal and plan to push for a portion of Social Security payroll taxes to be put into private investment accounts would return the nation to the era of deficits.Mr. Gore went on an advertising offensive on Monday against Mr. Bush, the presumptive Republican presidential nominee, through a series of interviews and television appearances, charging that Mr. Bush would continue ''multitrillion-dollar debts.'' Campaigning today, Mr. Gore called Mr. Bush's Social Security proposal ''bad for America's future and bad for America's economy.''The battle over numbers underscores how much the presidential campaign -- the first one waged in the new era of federal surpluses -- will be fought over economic policy and the related question of how to shore up Social Security. The Gore campaign considers the economic prosperity of the Clinton years one of its greatest assets.The figures released by Bush aides today addressed a weakness in earlier calculations. With the annual spending battle stepping up on Capitol Hill, the Bush campaign stopped assuming Congress would make large reductions in domestic spending, instead assuming discretionary domestic spending would grow.At the same time, Mr. Bush's advisers argued that the growth in the economy over the past six months means the federal surplus will be larger than previously forecast. They said that under their new calculations the estimated federal surplus across 10 years -- after $2.2 trillion is set aside for Social Security -- will amount to $1.8 trillion.That is roughly $1 trillion more than the Gore campaign estimates and about $500 billion more than the Bush campaign's earlier projections. Mr. Gore assumes a higher rate of spending and a less robust economy.Mr. Bush's aides said his cut would use 1.3 trillion surplus dollars, allowing $512 billion for other programs.''The bottom line is clear,'' said Lawrence B. Lindsey, the Bush campaign's chief economic adviser. ''Governor Bush's plan takes care of Social Security first, provides America's working families with a tax break and does it all within the context of a balanced budget.''The Bush campaign's new calculations were released less than 24 hours after Mr. Gore's aides held their own session with reporters and released an array of numbers they said showed that to accommodate his tax cut, Mr. Bush either had to make ''cuts in core areas of government that are unimaginable'' or risk a return to deficits.Mr. Gore's aides were still critical of Mr. Bush today.''Last month he claimed that his tax cut and spending increases were paid for,'' said Elaine Kamarck, policy adviser to Mr. Gore. ''Today, after finding more money, Bush still can't pay for his promises for a huge tax cut, increased spending and privatization of Social Security.''The Gore campaign said Mr. Bush was underestimating spending, and Mr. Bush's advisers refused to disclose how much Mr. Bush's embrace of a national missile defense system and prescription drug program would cost, while saying the proposals fit in their spending plan.The most serious dispute between the two campaigns is the true cost of Mr. Bush's tax-cut proposal. Mr. Bush's aides said the tax cut would cost $1.3 trillion over 10 years from 2001-2010. Over just five years they said it would cost $460 billion, slightly less than their original estimate of $483 billion. And they pointed to an analysis from the Congressional Joint Committee on Taxation backing them. The committee is controlled by Republicans.The Gore campaign argued that it was more appropriate to examine the tax cut through 2011, since the tax cut does not go into effect until fiscal 2002. Mr. Gore's aides said that once that extra year is added in, as well as lost interest costs, the tax cut costs $2 trillion.Another looming battle is over debt reduction and Social Security. Mr. Gore has made eliminating the public debt the centerpiece of his economic agenda. He says that Mr. Bush's proposal for putting some Social Security money into individual retirement accounts will carry a huge cost because it will require using part of the federal surplus that would otherwise go toward eliminating the national debt.Mr. Bush's aides counter that by giving individual workers their own retirement accounts, which can be invested in financial markets, they decrease the government's long-term obligation to pay benefits out of tax revenues. This itself, they say, is a form of debt reduction.The retirement system is projected to start paying out more in benefits than it is taking in through payroll taxes starting in 2015.THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE MONEY ISSUES
Jonah Jones, a jazz trumpeter who played with some of the great swing bands and sold a million copies of his versions of ''On the Street Where You Live'' and ''Baubles, Bangles and Beads,'' died on Sunday. He was 91 and lived in Manhattan.Mr. Jones, who was born in Louisville, Ky., learned to play the trumpet at a community center where he played church music. The day he heard a Louis Armstrong record, he said, his life changed. While still in Louisville, he performed with local bands like Tinsley's Royal Aces and Perdue's Pirates; in 1928 he was hired by the band leader Horace Henderson and worked in the Midwest for a few years.Jonah Jones, a jazz trumpeter who played with some of the great swing bands and sold a million copies of his versions of ''On the Street Where You Live'' and ''Baubles, Bangles and Beads,'' died on Sunday. He was 91 and lived in Manhattan.Mr. Jones, who was born in Louisville, Ky., learned to play the trumpet at a community center where he played church music. The day he heard a Louis Armstrong record, he said, his life changed. While still in Louisville, he performed with local bands like Tinsley's Royal Aces and Perdue's Pirates; in 1928 he was hired by the band leader Horace Henderson and worked in the Midwest for a few years.In 1932 he moved north and joined the violinist Stuff Smith's sextet. He continued changing jobs, appearing with McKinney's Cotton Pickers and Lil Armstrong, Louis Armstrong's wife, among other band leaders. But his first big break came in 1936, with a four-year residency at the Onyx Club secured by Stuff Smith. The band, featuring Smith on electrified violin, was popular, salting its vivid playing with slapstick humor.After working briefly with Benny Carter and Fletcher Henderson, Mr. Jones became a longtime member of Cab Calloway's group, from 1941 to 1952, seeing the band through its reduction from a big band to a septet to a quartet. (Calloway was an appreciative boss: he recorded a song celebrating Mr. Jones's arrival called ''Jonah Joins the Cab.'')He staged a midcareer resurgence in the 50's by putting a mute in his horn and familiar pop melodies in his hands. In 1952 Mr. Jones received an offer from the pianist Joe Bushkin to fill in at the Embers, one of New York's 52nd Street jazz clubs. Mr. Jones agreed to put a mute in his horn; this quieter sound was what his predecessor in the band, Buck Clayton, had adopted, and it was what the restaurant preferred. Mr. Jones, whose resume included stints with the society band leaders Lester Lanin and Meyer Davis, wasn't particularly fazed. Despite the fact that his regular style was open, forceful and swinging in the Louis Armstrong vein, he knew how to play softly too.He was invited back to play at the Embers with his own quartet in 1955, and the same restrictions of volume applied. Occasionally Mr. Jones was tempted to take the mute out of his horn. ''People would say, 'Jonah, just play one chorus open,' '' Mr. Jones told John S. Wilson of The New York Times in 1983. ''One night, Joe Howard, the maitre d', who had warned me to keep the mute in, was busy, and I thought he wasn't listening, so I played one chorus open. Afterward, when I came off the stand, Joe told me that if I took the mute out again I should just forget the address of the club.''The trumpeter Jimmy Owens recalled: ''The essence of his style was to swing. His whole thing was to communicate, and that's why he stuck with the melodies. He always said of himself that he was not a chord player, like Dizzy Gillespie and Roy Eldridge and Charlie Shavers; he was more of a melody player.''What started as a once-weekly job led to a week's engagement, which finally led to a five-year contract, in which Mr. Jones played at the club 20 weeks a year. He also began to sing during his performances of this period. The Embers became Mr. Jones's home base for the next decade, and he began to make records that further refined this sound, which verged on easy listening. His recordings of show tunes were extremely successful, and he won a Grammy in 1959 for the album ''I Dig Chicks.''.Touring and recording through the 80's, Mr. Jones finally retired from performing in 1993. His final public performance was at the Blue Note in Greenwich Village in November, when he sang during a benefit for the Jazz Foundation of America.He is survived by three children, Shirley Redmond of Manhattan, Lawrence Jones of the Bronx and William Jones of Cleveland; and two grandchildren.
The Rev. Floyd H. Flake, the Queens minister and former congressman who has been widely talked about as a potential candidate for mayor of New York City, plans to announce today that he is joining Edison Schools Inc., the largest for-profit school-management company  in the country, education industry officials said yesterday.Mr. Flake is to head the company's charter school division.The Rev. Floyd H. Flake, the Queens minister and former congressman who has been widely talked about as a potential candidate for mayor of New York City, plans to announce today that he is joining Edison Schools Inc., the largest for-profit school-management company  in the country, education industry officials said yesterday.Mr. Flake is to head the company's charter school division.Edison has been one of the most aggressive entrepreneurs in the mushrooming field of charter schools, publicly financed schools that operate free of much of the authority of local school districts.  Mr. Flake has been a supporter of the schools, as well as an advocate of giving parents vouchers to send their children to private schools.Mr. Flake, a Democrat who has been a leading black supporter of conservative causes, particularly in education, will continue to serve as senior pastor of the Allen A.M.E. Church in Jamaica, Queens, the officials said.H. Christopher Whittle, the founder and president of Edison, and Benno C. Schmidt Jr., the chairman, are expected to announce the appointment of Mr. Flake this morning at a news conference at Edison's headquarters in Manhattan. Neither Mr. Flake nor Edison officials would  comment yesterday.The appointment is expected to remove Mr. Flake from the list of potential candidates for the mayoral election in November 2001. Though he is a Democrat, Mr. Flake had been courted as a mayoral candidate by state Republican leaders, who saw him as someone who could attract African-American voters to the party through his support of education reform. And he has long been familiar to Republican leaders, having endorsed Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, Gov. George E. Pataki and former Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato in their campaigns for public office. Mr. Flake had told friends, however, that if he ran it would be as a Democrat.Although Mr. Flake endorsed Al Gore for the Democratic presidential nomination in February, he has criticized the vice president's education policy, which opposes vouchers. Last October, Mr. Flake gave a warm introduction to George W. Bush, whom he referred to as ''my homeboy,'' at a meeting of the Manhattan Institute for Policy Research, a conservative advocacy group, at which Governor Bush outlined his education proposals.One education industry executive who spoke on condition of anonymity said Mr. Flake's job with Edison would not be merely a ceremonial one. Although both Mr. Whittle and Mr. Schmidt are familiar figures in both business and political circles, Mr. Flake is expected to become the company's most prominent public figure, promoting Edison's management program and curriculum to school board officials and talking about the benefits of charter schools to state and federal lawmakers.Edison operates 79 public schools with a total enrollment of 38,000 students in 16 states and 36 cities. Most are schools for which Edison has been given a management contract by a school district concerned about  a history of poor student performance. But about one-third of those are charter schools, in which Edison is accountable to a community sponsor chosen to start a school free of standard district rules.In November, Edison announced its largest contract to date, with the Dallas Independent School District, to serve 6,500 students next school year. Edison is scheduled to open its first charter school in New York State this fall, in Rochester.Edison is one of the largest publicly traded education companies, and its revenues have been growing quickly. They totaled $132 million in the fiscal year that ended June 30, 1999, up from $69 million the previous year. In the six months that ended Dec. 31, revenues grew to $102 million from $60 million in the same period a year earlier. But profits have been harder to come by; the company recorded net losses of $51 million last year and $21 million in the first six months of the current fiscal year.Mr. Flake's extensive contacts on both ends of the political spectrum testify to his philosophy of using his political power with both parties to gain economic clout for his church. The Allen African Methodist Episcopal Church, which says it has 12,000 members, is one of the largest churches in New York State, occupying a cavernous $23 million cathedral, which opened in 1997, on Merrick Boulevard in southeastern Queens.Although he runs only a small religious school, with 500 students from prekindergarten through 8th grade, Mr. Flake has vast business experience through Allen A.M.E.'s wide-ranging interests. The church has more than a dozen affiliated corporations, some of them operated for profit, with interests in housing, transportation and financial services.In 1997, Mr. Flake retired from Congress after 11 years, saying he wanted to spend more time tending his congregation. He has since been active in political circles as well as in education, and already has an association with Edison as well as some of its rival charter school companies.In March, he was appointed to an Edison advisory board. He also serves on a similar board for Victory Schools Inc., a small for-profit operator of charter schools in New York City. Mr. Flake is a director of the Children's Scholarship Fund, the philanthropic venture started by Ted Forstmann, the financier.Mr. Flake had recently considered starting his own charter school company to apply for the right to open new publicly financed schools in New York. As part of those deliberations, industry executives said, Mr. Flake was approached by Mr. Whittle about working for Edison.George Arzt, a Democratic political consultant and friend of Mr. Flake's, said that although many people in both major parties had asked Mr. Flake to explore a mayoral candidacy, he always said that if he ran it would be as a Democrat.''But he found at the end of an exploration period, after some time thinking about it, that he just didn't want to do it,'' Mr. Arzt said.
It was not the spectacular golf course on a cove overlooking the Pacific Ocean that led Gov. Tom Ridge of Pennsylvania to fly here the other day to address a group of Republicans (though he did squeeze in a round before his speech). It was the chance to do something a politician rarely does: praise another politician more than himself. The object of his affection was Gov. George W. Bush.Bill Richardson, the secretary of energy, cut short a visit to India for meetings on nuclear proliferation last October so he could be in New Hampshire to toss questions at Vice President Al Gore in preparation for his first debate with Bill Bradley. After only 28 hours in India, Mr. Richardson rushed to London and then flew to Boston, where a waiting Gore aide frantically drove him to Hanover, N.H., just in time to catch the vice president in the parking lot.It was not the spectacular golf course on a cove overlooking the Pacific Ocean that led Gov. Tom Ridge of Pennsylvania to fly here the other day to address a group of Republicans (though he did squeeze in a round before his speech). It was the chance to do something a politician rarely does: praise another politician more than himself. The object of his affection was Gov. George W. Bush.Bill Richardson, the secretary of energy, cut short a visit to India for meetings on nuclear proliferation last October so he could be in New Hampshire to toss questions at Vice President Al Gore in preparation for his first debate with Bill Bradley. After only 28 hours in India, Mr. Richardson rushed to London and then flew to Boston, where a waiting Gore aide frantically drove him to Hanover, N.H., just in time to catch the vice president in the parking lot.In the shadow of the presidential jockeying, a second competition is well under way: for the spot as No. 2. Dozens of governors, senators, House members, Cabinet secretaries, business executives, retired politicians and maybe even a general are maneuvering behind the scenes to land on the candidates' purported (and perhaps mythical) short lists.They are also seeking to score points with Mr. Bush and Mr. Gore by stumping for them around the country, dispensing unsolicited political and policy tips and seizing every opportunity to say flattering things about their party's standard bearer. Mindful that they not appear unseemly, the one thing they dare not do is utter two words directly to the candidate: running mate.In fact, for many, the watchwords are deftness and subtlety. If you are caught looking as if you are actually campaigning, you may lose.Jack Kemp, the Republican vice presidential candidate in 1996 who did not lobby for the job, and, if anything, discouraged Bob Dole from picking him, cautioned those who want to be considered: ''Keep your mouth shut, your head down,  and don't act like you want it.''Heeding such advice, several politicians are keeping their mouths shut, at least publicly. But many certainly act as if they want the job. One big-name politician in Washington who is frequently mentioned as a possible vice presidential contender was eager in an interview to make the case for why he would be a fabulous choice. But he insisted that his name not be used.''I don't want to be quoted,'' he said conspiratorially. ''That would be a good way to get off the list.'' Boasting about his selling points, he said of the candidate, ''I won't say that I'm one of his good buddies, but I know him as well as anybody outside his close friends.''Another politician, a senator from a battleground state, was happy to offer reasons why the politician quoted in the previous paragraph would not be such a fabulous choice.''I don't think he brings anything to the campaign,'' the senator said. Then he offered himself as a possibility, saying, ''I'm a tough campaigner.'' Excusing himself for speaking anonymously, he said, ''It's important not to look too anxious.''The Gore and Bush camps have only begun their painstaking hunts to find just the right running mate, and to resolve perhaps the one lingering mystery in the presidential sweepstakes before the national conventions in late summer.In recent days, Tony Coelho, Mr. Gore's campaign chairman, has been making the rounds, informing some politicians -- even some that others on the campaign said they did not consider hot prospects -- that they were in contention.''I talked to Coelho,'' said one politician. ''He told me I would be considered. I said, 'Thanks.' ''Mr. Coelho declined to discuss such conversations, and, in an interview, would not even confirm that they were taking place. But he chuckled at the attention he was getting from politicians who were quietly trying to win him over.Asked if people were undermining their chances by being too overt, he said: ''I don't think it hurts one way or another. It identifies personalities,  and that's fine.''Warren Christopher, the former secretary of state, is running the vice presidential screening process for Mr. Gore. The vice president turned to him because Mr. Christopher had the same job in 1992, when he helped Bill Clinton settle on Senator Gore.Mr. Bush has picked Dick Cheney, a former defense secretary and White House chief of staff who served under his father, to conduct his search.Officials in both campaigns said they will be looking for contenders who could plausibly -- and admirably -- serve as president, but who also would complement the strengths or weaknesses of the nominee and add some zip to the ticket. Despite the coming months of speculation about who is on which list, the campaign officials said the decisions will not likely be made until just before the national conventions.Since the Republican convention is first, Mr. Gore's choice may be in direct reaction to Mr. Bush's. For example, Gore advisers said that if Mr. Bush picks a woman, they might feel pressure to do the same.But Mr. Coelho said that because he and Mr. Gore know most of the contenders pretty well, one of Mr. Christopher's most important duties is to oversee background checks.''The vetting process becomes important -- that will eliminate some people,'' Mr. Coelho said. ''That's what Warren does.''Even if they do not get picked, politicians say it burnishes their image just to be mentioned.Representative Robert Menendez, Democrat of New Jersey, said a few of his friends in Congress and in labor unions asked if they could float his name. ''I didn't dissuade them,'' he said. ''It's an honor.'' Asked if an appearance on Geraldo Rivera's show was useful in getting his name mentioned, he said, ''Absolutely.'' At the very least, Mr. Menendez said, he would get the opportunity to press a favorite cause: ''Why Hispanic-Americans should be voting Democratic in this election.''Some possible contenders are being pushed into the limelight by people far removed from the selection process. Representative David E. Bonior of Michigan, the House Democratic whip, said he publicly suggested Mr. Menendez and Mr. Richardson because ''they are both really qualified and fine people and deserve to be very seriously considered.''But Mr. Bonior also acknowledged that he thought it was important, at the very least, for House members to get some attention. ''We want our leaders considered for different positions,'' he said.Several contenders said their model of what not to do was Gov. John Engler of Michigan, who was viewed by many Republicans as an unabashed self-promoter for the job four years ago, with constant visits to Washington. Even so, while Mr. Engler did not get picked, one strategist for Mr. Dole at the time said the nominee was flattered by the attention.Many Democrats say that Senator John Kerry of Massachusetts has been one of the most obvious practitioners of the subtle-but-aggressive approach. He traveled to early primary states to campaign for Mr. Gore and, the Gore campaign has noticed, has delivered speeches on national policy that helped raise his profile.On the Republican side, advisers to Elizabeth Dole made no secret of her desire to help Mr. Bush -- and get her name out. After ending her own bid for the Republican nomination, she frequently stumped for Mr. Bush in early primary states. And she has the added benefit that her husband, Bob Dole, trumpets her availability while she plays coy.But Mr. Ridge is cited by many Republicans for most adroitly positioning himself. ''He has the keenest political eye to what you may have to do to be considered,'' said Chris Hennick, a former executive director of the Republican Governors Association.Mr. Ridge is an obvious contender because he comes from a battleground state, has a compelling biography as a Vietnam veteran and is versed in national issues from his days in Congress. Most of all, he gets along well with Mr. Bush. To many Republicans, his biggest drawback is that he favors abortion rights, but that position could help Mr. Bush appeal to independents and other swing voters.The Pennsylvania governor helped himself by successfully pushing for the Republican National Convention to be held in Philadelphia. So he has a legitimate explanation for traveling the country meeting with Republicans.In his appearance here before the Lincoln Club of Northern California, a group of moderate Republicans, Mr. Ridge, brimming with praise for Mr. Bush, spoke of the governor's ''candor, his mischievous humor, his directness, his decision-making ability.''Mr. Ridge said the governor's ''compassionate conservative message makes a lot of sense.'' He defended Mr. Bush's controversial proposal to cut taxes by nearly half a trillion dollars, saying, ''I don't think Governor Bush should abandon his plan to cut taxes.''After the event, Mr. Ridge insisted in an interview that he had been careful not to campaign to be picked as Mr. Bush's running mate. ''I don't think it's his style,'' Mr. Ridge said of Mr. Bush. ''I don't think it's appropriate. It's certainly not my style.''Even so, Mr. Ridge's behavior has seemed strikingly similar to that of another Republican who was sleeping down the hall from Mr. Ridge at the lodge in Pebble Beach: Dan Quayle. But he was here to play golf, not politics.Consider this passage from Mr. Quayle's book: ''The vice presidency isn't an office you can campaign for,'' he said. ''But I had tried, as subtlety as I could, to make clear I was both qualified and available.''Did Mr. Ridge knock on the former vice president's door for advice? He laughed and said he did not even know Mr. Quayle was staying here.THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE SECOND SPOT
After a barrage of fiery talk critical of the Justice Department's raid to retrieve Elian Gonzalez, Senate and House Republicans are distancing themselves from the case, no longer sure that hearings are warranted.Descriptions of ''jack-booted thugs'' and ''storm troopers'' have been all but muted in the last few days, replaced by a cautious call for answers, maybe even just written ones, from the Justice Department about its decision to send heavily armed agents into a private home.After a barrage of fiery talk critical of the Justice Department's raid to retrieve Elian Gonzalez, Senate and House Republicans are distancing themselves from the case, no longer sure that hearings are warranted.Descriptions of ''jack-booted thugs'' and ''storm troopers'' have been all but muted in the last few days, replaced by a cautious call for answers, maybe even just written ones, from the Justice Department about its decision to send heavily armed agents into a private home.While several prominent Republicans, including Senator Trent Lott, the majority leader, still want to delve publicly into the Elian case, many others have come to believe that doing so could be a grand political miscalculation.Those Republicans, ranging from conservative to moderate, have helped tone down the rhetoric surrounding the Justice Department's raid on the Miami house of Elian's great-uncle Lazaro Gonzalez.In part, members of Congress are heeding public opinion surveys showing that most Americans agree with Attorney General Janet Reno's decision to raid the house; disagree with the boy's Miami relatives who seek to prevent his return to Cuba; and scorn Congress's desire to dredge up the details of the raid once again. The members also recognize the political danger of hearings, which tend to become overly partisan and often paint Republicans as overzealous.''It could be turned into political theater, and I don't think anyone wants that,'' said Senator Don Nickles of Oklahoma, the second-ranking Republican in the Senate. ''I'd like to get some answers to some questions, but I don't think we need a big show.''Senator Olympia Snowe, Republican of Maine, echoed several colleagues' comments when she said she worried that hearings would be viewed as just more posturing on a case that many feel has already been overpoliticized.''It would look like a lot of political grandstanding, and I would be concerned about that,'' Ms. Snowe said. ''This could be done without hearings.''In his weekly news conference, Representative Dick Armey of Texas, the majority leader, seemed to search for the mildest characterizations he could find to discuss the case. After calling the photograph of a federal agent with a submachine gun removing Elian from a closet in the Miami house ''frightening,'' Mr. Armey said members needed ''to sit down and talk about'' hearings.''I don't know the answer to whether or not a hearing will be necessary,'' he said.Even Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani of New York, who had referred to the agents who seized Elian as storm troopers, has lowered the volume as he considers a Senate run. At a speech in Saratoga Springs, N.Y., on Friday, he did not call the raid ''unconscionable,'' as he previously had; nor did he lay blame for the raid, as he did earlier last week, on ''Fidel Castro, Bill Clinton and Janet Reno.''John Kingdon, professor emeritus of political science at the University of Michigan, said Republicans might have initially misread the Elian case, especially the level of outrage about the raid and the photograph of the agent with the gun. In addition, he said, they appeared to underestimate the power of another set of photographs, those of a beaming father and son.Their calculations also shifted after Ms. Reno and her deputies appeared on television numerous times to defend their actions. While Republicans say legitimate questions remain, the Justice Department has tried to address concerns about cost and the search warrant. And Ms. Reno has spoken of the events leading up to the raid.''They have really miscalculated the political benefits,'' Mr. Kingdon said of the Republicans.At this point, Senate hearings would most likely last one or two days and focus on whether the raid was legal and proper, Senator Lott said. The House has said it will begin a ''preliminary inquiry.''The Republican retreat began last week when Senator Orrin G. Hatch of Utah, chairman of the Judiciary Committee, who had called a hearing for this Wednesday, postponed it because the Justice Department failed to produce the information he sought. On Sunday, Mr. Hatch suggested that his committee might not hold hearings if the documents adequately explain the department's decision.Today, Mr. Hatch said he still awaited the documents. He also criticized Ms. Reno for making television appearances while pleading for more time to collect the documents.From the start of the case in November -- when Elian was rescued in the Atlantic Ocean after a boat carrying fleeing Cubans sank, claiming the life of his mother -- many Republicans were quick to side with Cuban-Americans in Miami who fought to keep the boy in the United States, even if it meant separating him from his father in Cuba.Top Republicans leaders, including presidential candidates, unleashed sharp attacks on Fidel Castro and argued that the boy's case should be heard in a state family court, even though it has no jurisdiction over an immigration case.Vice President Al Gore, treading carefully, broke with the Clinton administration and also suggested that the case was best left to the courts.In January, with Congress just back from its recess, Republicans pushed for a bill to make Elian a citizen. But in another retreat, Republican leaders dropped the effort, without saying so outright, after it became clear they lacked the votes in their own party to push the bill.A number of Republicans viewed the case as a family issue -- a son kept from his father -- and found it difficult to support any measure that suggested that the two should not be reunited. They were not the most vocal, but their influence was considerable.At stake is a crucial group of Cuban-American voters, which leans Republican but helped deliver Florida to President Clinton in 1996. Some analysts say Republicans were just trying to help George W. Bush, the presumptive Republican presidential nominee, win Florida.''Some would suggest that if Gore can deny Bush Florida, Gore would be hard to beat,'' said Brian Kennedy, a Republican political consultant. ''Republicans want to remind people that it was the Clinton administration that came in and pointed guns to take this boy back.''--------------------New Police Chief in MiamiMIAMI, May 2 (AP) -- A Cuban immigrant, Raul Martinez, was sworn in today as Miami's first Hispanic police chief, filling a position left vacant by political turmoil after the raid.Mr. Martinez, 50, replaces William O'Brien, who resigned after Mayor Joe Carollo fired the city manager, Donald Warshaw.

A high-level Republican committee proposed a new presidential nominating system today intended to build suspense and interest from March through June, with smaller states voting first and larger states casting the decisive final votes.The proposal was a sharp reaction to the current system in which both party nominations were effectively decided by March 7, the first day with several major primaries, before millions of Americans knew much about the candidates.A high-level Republican committee proposed a new presidential nominating system today intended to build suspense and interest from March through June, with smaller states voting first and larger states casting the decisive final votes.The proposal was a sharp reaction to the current system in which both party nominations were effectively decided by March 7, the first day with several major primaries, before millions of Americans knew much about the candidates.Bill Brock, former Republican Party chairman, who led the committee that offered the plan, said, ''Too many people in too many states have no voice in the electoral process that names our candidates.''Jim Nicholson, the Republican national chairman, said he expected the party to adopt the plan.The Republican willingness to scrap the system seems likely to open up a national debate, even though the Democratic Party's reaction was to point out that the present system had elected Bill Clinton twice and therefore ''at this point, there is little incentive to change.''But if Republicans adopt the plan at the convention in August, Democrats might be willing to discuss changing the primary process. A crucial provision would give the Republican National Committee the authority, which it now lacks and the Democratic National Committee has, to alter delegate selection rules between conventions.James Roosevelt, co-chairman of the Democratic Rules and By-Laws Committee, said, ''If the Republicans can get that kind of flexibility, then between cycles we could have some real substantive discussions about this.''Potential opposition from large states is a major obstacle to the Brock plan. So is traditional Republican reluctance to impose national rules on state parties. Democratic opposition, if it persists, would be another hurdle, and even if both parties agreed on a plan, getting almost every state to change its primary or caucus date would be difficult.Under the plan, the 12 least-populous states, the District of Columbia and the territories would be allowed to hold primaries or caucuses no earlier than the first Tuesday in March. Another group of 13 slightly more-populous states, from Connecticut to New Mexico, could go on the first Tuesday in April. Thirteen middle-size states, including Kentucky and Massachusetts, could go on the first Tuesday in May.The rest, including New York, New Jersey, California, Florida and Texas, could have primaries on the first Tuesday in June. Any state could go later, and in the early stages, some might do so to get a Tuesday that was less crowded. The plan makes no allowance for early votes in Iowa and New Hampshire, but that might be adjusted by the Republican National Committee.State legislatures would have to vote to adopt new primary dates. To pressure them, the Republican National Committee would have the power to deny state parties 50 percent to 90 percent of their delegates.That degree of central control may be an issue, at the convention if not earlier, at next week's meeting of the Republican rules committee.John Deardourff, a Republican consultant whose first primary was in 1964, said today, ''The unwillingness to impose Washington-based decisions and the unwillingness to accept them is pretty strongly ingrained in Republican theology, and whether it's the government doing it, or the party, it just doesn't sit well.''The first hurdle is clearly within the party.Bill Jones, the California secretary of state, said the plan was ''absolutely not'' in his state's best interest because it would mean that California always came in the last group. He said the majority of members on the Brock commission on which he served were mistaken in their belief that because nearly half the delegates would not be chosen before June, a contest would keep going.Mr. Jones, who had pushed to move the California primary up to March 7, said he did not think the suggested changes would be enough to overcome the current way of nominating a candidate, which he called ''raise a lot of money, get it over quick.'' He said he thought a system of regional primaries, in which different regions each got their chance to go first, would be better.Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, the presumptive Republican presidential nominee, could play a decisive role on the plan at the convention. But his campaign had no comment tonight, saying Mr. Bush looked forward to studying the report.The report was issued on the day when North Carolina and Indiana, the 11th and 14th most populous states, held presidential primaries that drew virtually no interest. Early in the campaign, primary turnout was high, at least among Republicans, but by March 7, known as Super Tuesday, two-fifths of Republican delegates and one-third of Democratic delegates had been picked.Curtis Gans, head of the Committee for the Study of the American Electorate, who cheered the Brock report as ''the best thing since sliced bread,'' said turnout since March 7 ''has been abysmally low, and the citizens in the states which were after Super Tuesday have felt left out of the process.''A study by the Joan Shorenstein Barone Center at Harvard, known as the Vanishing Voter project, found both interest in and knowledge of the candidates had declined in recent weeks.The Brock report said the plan that it recommended could ease ''many of the problems that have come to plague the current nominating process: front-loading, compression, low voter turnout, early media frenzy, excessive 'tarmac and media ad' campaigning.''If Republicans do adopt the plan, the process of getting legislatures to alter primary dates (and abolish winner-take-all contests), would be simplified if some agreement was reached with the Democrats. Republicans might not press ahead without such cooperation.Today Mr. Roosevelt complained that the Republican plan gave too prominent a place to ''states with no diversity.'' Mr. Brock acknowledged that blacks made up only 6.2 percent of the population in the first group of states. But he said the existing system, with pre-eminence to Iowa and New Hampshire, rewarded two even-less-diverse states, since Iowa is 2 percent black and New Hampshire is 0.7 percent black.In the 1970's, when Democrats were establishing new rules for choosing delegates, most legislatures went along. The bipartisan good feelings more typical in state capitals than Washington frequently persuaded Republicans to let the Democrats have the new procedures they needed to stay out of trouble with their national party. Democrats could well do the same for Republicans over the next couple of years.Prof. Thomas Patterson, a leading researcher in the  Vanishing Voter project at Harvard, said he doubted the plan would accomplish its goals. Mr. Patterson said he believed if one candidate won most of the primaries in the first two months, he would be acclaimed as the likely nominee, even if most delegates had not been selected.Mr. Brock did not argue that the plan, if in force this year, might have produced a different candidate. But he noted that a shortage of money had forced several Republicans out of the contest even before the first votes had been cast. He argued that a calendar that began with primaries in lightly populated, relatively inexpensive states would have let them continue longer and ''bring their ideas'' to the process.John Weaver, political director for Senator John McCain, said he had no idea how a different calendar would have affected Mr. McCain.''We've not been reflective about that,'' Mr. Weaver said. ''We were pleased with the calendar. Why look back?''On the Democratic side, the national committee's satisfaction with the existing system reflected the position of the campaign of Vice President Al Gore.Doug Berman, campaign manager for former Senator Bill Bradley, said that having both parties hold primaries at the same time would have helped Mr. Bradley, since interest in the Democratic race evaporated when only Republicans were voting in February.THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE PRIMARY SCHEDULE
In a speech pungent with tough talk about criminals, drug abusers and his Republican rival for president, Vice President Al Gore called today for a broad array of anticrime measures, among them mandatory drug testing of all prisoners and parolees.Choosing a Southern state as the backdrop for one of his most conservative speeches of the presidential campaign, Mr. Gore proposed federal spending of $500 million a year  to help states test, treat and counsel  prisoners and parolees for drug use.In a speech pungent with tough talk about criminals, drug abusers and his Republican rival for president, Vice President Al Gore called today for a broad array of anticrime measures, among them mandatory drug testing of all prisoners and parolees.Choosing a Southern state as the backdrop for one of his most conservative speeches of the presidential campaign, Mr. Gore proposed federal spending of $500 million a year  to help states test, treat and counsel  prisoners and parolees for drug use.Under the plan, inmates in state prisons -- mandatory drug testing already applies in federal prisons --  would not be released until they could pass drug tests. Further, parolees could be returned to prison if they failed the tests, which would be administered to them twice a week.  Parolees would also be subjected to stricter supervision, to ensure that they paid child support, stayed off drugs and found jobs.''When inmates are sent back to the streets unrehabilitated, unrepentant and unskilled, then they are just going to commit more crime and go right back into prison,'' Mr. Gore said to a crowd filled with uniformed police officers.As in all his recent policy speeches, the vice president used a harsh tone to attack Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, the apparent Republican presidential nominee, this time maintaining that he had cut state financing of drug treatment by half.As a result of such policies, Mr. Gore said, Texas under Mr. Bush has experienced a 25 percent increase in the number of former inmates returned to prison for new crimes within three years of release.Mr. Gore did not suggest that Mr. Bush had been soft on crime, a position that would be hard to defend: in Mr. Bush's five and a half years as governor, Texas has undertaken the nation's largest prison-building program, executed a record number of criminals, lengthened sentences for many crimes and incarcerated a rising number of juveniles.But the vice president did say: ''I believe that we should demand that criminals get clean before they get out of jail. Governor Bush seems content to keep pushing them out of the same revolving door.''Aides to Mr. Bush disputed Mr. Gore's statistic on Texas recidivism and his accusation that the governor had cut financing of drug treatment. They also said violent crime in the state had fallen 20 percent, to a 20-year low, during the Bush administration. And they asserted that the availability of drug treatment in federal prisons had declined during the Clinton-Gore administration, even as  drug use among adolescents had risen (an assertion disputed in turn by the Gore campaign).''If Al Gore is willing to attack Texas, where violent crime is at a 20-year low and the largest prison drug-treatment program in the country is located, we're also expecting attacks on Texans for defending the Alamo,'' said Dan Bartlett, a Bush aide.Just as Mr. Bush has tried to move further to the center of the political spectrum with education and health care proposals, Mr. Gore's crime speech today provided him an opportunity to reach out to centrist Republicans and conservative Democrats. And he seized it with gusto.He cited the Bible several times, illustrating the problem of violence among young men by retelling the story of Cain and Abel. He argued that no amount of anticrime legislation would work unless people took greater responsibility for their actions. And he castigated both conservative Republicans and liberal Democrats for failing to compromise on crime-fighting plans, casting himself as the purveyor of a third way who could rise above ''old orthodoxies.''''We can't go back to the finger-pointing and failed strategies that led to that steep increase in crime in the Bush-Quayle administration,'' he said. ''And we can't go back to the old Democratic approach, which was tough on the causes of crime but not tough enough on crime itself, again when people in both political parties wanted us to do more.''Mr. Gore's effort to outflank Governor Bush on crime recalls Bill Clinton's drive in the 1992 campaign to neutralize what had been a potent Republican issue by advocating tough anticrime measures, including the death penalty.The vice president's speech today, typifying the administration's approach to policy making, offered a mixture of ideas -- some new, some old, many small-bore. Several of the ideas were first discussed by Mr. Gore in a crime speech last July in Boston, where he called for longer sentences for all crimes committed with guns and for requiring photo-bearing licenses for people who buy new handguns.Today Mr. Gore restated his support for a proposal that federal money help local governments hire 50,000 new police officers in the coming decade. The Clinton administration has already helped finance the hiring of 60,000 new police officers, with 40,000 more in the pipeline.Mr. Gore also proposed aid to help state and local governments buy computers for crime-fighting purposes, hire new prosecutors and expand after-school programs.And in addition to mandatory drug testing of prisoners and parolees, he called for expanding drug treatment programs for noncriminals, though he offered no details. ''I believe we should build a country in which every single addict who finds the power to reach out and say, 'Now is the time I want help and I want treatment' gets an immediate response,'' he said.Mr. Gore also jumped into what has become a contentious debate in Congress by endorsing a constitutional amendment to expand the rights of crime victims. The amendment would grant victims and their families the right to reasonable notice of court proceedings involving their cases, the right to have a voice in those proceedings, and the right to notice of an offender's release or escape from prison.Opponents of the amendment, including many Democrats, assert that those rights can be ensured  without amending the Constitution. In addition, some liberals argue that the measure would violate the civil rights of the accused.In His Own Words  AL GORESpeaking yesterday about crime in Atlanta, as recorded by The New York Times:''I pledge to you that if I am entrusted with the presidency, I will launch a sweeping anticrime strategy to make our families safe and secure. I will intensify the battle against crime, drugs and disorder in our communities. . . .As crime and fear grew, too many families became afraid to live up to their own responsibilities and help take back their communities from the thugs and the dealers. And too many criminals saw the disorder on our streets as an invitation to further lawlessness and violence. . . .Seven years ago, we began to change all that. President Clinton and I thought we needed a tougher and more comprehensive strategy to fight crime on every single front. Smarter prevention to stop crime before it even started. More police on our streets to thicken the thin blue line between order and disorder. And tougher punishments, including the death penalty for those who dared to penalize the innocent.''THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE CRIME ISSUE

Now the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee, which believes Mr. Schweitzer has a good shot at winning one of six seats the party needs to retake control of the Senate, has produced a television spot urging voters to ''call the big drug companies and tell them to get out of the way of Brian Schweitzer's fair prices drug plan.'' Mr. Schweitzer, a farmer who has never held elective office, is trying to unseat the Republican incumbent, Conrad Burns.Robin Toner (NYT)THE STATESDRUG COSTS ARE ISSUE IN MONTANA  Brian Schweitzer, a Democratic candidate for the Senate in Montana, has campaigned hard on the high price of prescription drugs and the burden it puts on the uninsured elderly. There was heavy editing to the first lineup card posted by the Yankees' hitting coach, Chris Chambliss, tonight. It was covered with black blotches, the names and accompanying positions obliterated and then revised.Chuck Knoblauch was out with a sprained wrist, and the new leadoff hitter had a batting average of .170 -- but Ricky Ledee hit a home run, his first of the season. The new second baseman, Wilson Delgado, ripped a two-run double. The catcher, Chris Turner, played in his first game for the Yankees, hit an important double and guided Andy Pettitte through most of the 4-2 victory against Cleveland.There was heavy editing to the first lineup card posted by the Yankees' hitting coach, Chris Chambliss, tonight. It was covered with black blotches, the names and accompanying positions obliterated and then revised.Chuck Knoblauch was out with a sprained wrist, and the new leadoff hitter had a batting average of .170 -- but Ricky Ledee hit a home run, his first of the season. The new second baseman, Wilson Delgado, ripped a two-run double. The catcher, Chris Turner, played in his first game for the Yankees, hit an important double and guided Andy Pettitte through most of the 4-2 victory against Cleveland.It doesn't seem to matter who plays for the Yankees these days; Choo Choo Coleman and Marv Throneberry could wear Yankee pinstripes and be transformed. They are getting strong starting pitching and strong relief and scraping together enough offense, and their 17-8 record is the American League's best. The Yankees have won 23 of 32 regular-season games in Jacobs Field, this victory coming with a makeshift lineup.Knoblauch was scratched from the starting lineup because of his sprained left wrist, and unless he feels markedly better Friday, he will probably be placed on the 15-day disabled list. Delgado started at second base, in the 67th game of his major league career. He is not hard to miss when the Yankees take batting practice. Delgado is generously listed at 5 feet 11 inches and 165 pounds -- he is probably shorter and lighter -- and he tends to dump a lot of balls over the infield, rather than launching rockets over the fences. When asked about Delgado's offensive potential, Manager Joe Torre replied, ''Well, he's a good defensive player.''Delgado does not have the experience of the man he is essentially replacing, Luis Sojo. The Yankees don't have someone like Darryl Strawberry on their bench, the big left-handed slugger who frightens opposing managers; Lance Johnson hits singles and steals bases.Two years ago, Homer Bush came off the Yankee bench with his awesome speed and he stole a few bases and won a few games. Now there is Clay Bellinger, whose strength is versatility. Joe Girardi was once the Yankees' backup catcher, and now the backups are Jim Leyritz and Turner.But while the Yankee bench doesn't seem as deep or as strong, it is contributing in meaningful ways. Leyritz is hitting .125, but on April 16, his home run in the seventh inning snapped a 4-4 tie with the Kansas City Royals. Three days later, Johnson started and spurred the offense with four hits and two steals against the Texas Rangers. When the Rangers tied the game in the ninth inning that day, Bellinger slammed a game-winning home run in the 10th inning. Even Alfonso Soriano slugged an important home run in his otherwise turbulent and temporary tenure as third baseman.Delgado and Turner stepped in tonight, with Ledee moving to the leadoff spot. The Yankees led by 1-0 after Bernie Williams hit a solo home run in the fourth inning. Scott Brosius singled to open the fifth, and Turner -- who found himself nervous all day, ''feeling butterflies'' before his first start with the Yankees -- hammered a double against the center-field fence. Brosius stopped at third.Delgado was next. He learned just before batting practice that he would play, and he didn't know anything about Knoblauch's injury until reporters told him after the game. But what Delgado did know, as he batted in the fifth inning, was that Cleveland's Bobby Witt would challenge him with fastballs. ''They wanted me to show what I can do,'' Delgado said after the game, before pausing, then adding. ''But I can play.''Delgado lined a ball between the outfielders in right and center, the ball rolling and rolling, Brosius and Turner scoring. Delgado stood at second with two R.B.I. -- matching Knoblauch's total for the first month of the season.Turner had never worked with Pettitte in spring training, only watching him from afar. They sat together in the dugout during Monday's game, discussing how they might try to pitch against the Cleveland hitters, something the American League has done with great success this year. Coming into tonight's game, the Indians had scored only 121 runs, third fewest in the league, ahead of the Detroit Tigers (84 runs) and, amazingly, the first-place Yankees (114).Pettitte retired the first 12 batters he faced, nine of those on groundball  outs, and no Cleveland batter hit the ball out of the infield in the first four innings. Manny Ramirez opened the fifth with a single and Pettitte wavered, walking home a run.But Pettitte recovered, and in the seventh, Ledee lifted a home run deep into the right-field stands; he muted his smile until he returned to the dugout, and then, Torre said, ''He was cheesing from ear to ear.''Jeff Nelson took over in the seventh and pitched two innings, Mariano Rivera overcame an error and an unearned run in the ninth, whiffing Enrique Wilson to end the game.The bullpen has an earned run average of 1.31 over its last 11 games. The starters have an E.R.A.  of 1.67 in the last turn through the rotation. SOLDIER OF FORTUNE does not simply push the envelope for computer-game violence. It seals the envelope, stamps it and posts it, then empties a clip into the mailbox for good measure.In fundamentals, this new first-person shooter developed by Raven Software doesn't appear significantly different from similar games on the market. Cast as a mercenary on the trail of stolen nuclear warheads, the player explores a hostile three-dimensional environment through 26 game levels spread over 10 missions, lays waste to a host of enemies and uses an array of weapons and supplies.SOLDIER OF FORTUNE does not simply push the envelope for computer-game violence. It seals the envelope, stamps it and posts it, then empties a clip into the mailbox for good measure.In fundamentals, this new first-person shooter developed by Raven Software doesn't appear significantly different from similar games on the market. Cast as a mercenary on the trail of stolen nuclear warheads, the player explores a hostile three-dimensional environment through 26 game levels spread over 10 missions, lays waste to a host of enemies and uses an array of weapons and supplies.The twist: You can inflict wounds with unprecedented specificity. In most shooters, every hit to an enemy does the same amount of damage, regardless of location. (For instance, in Nova Logic's recent Special Forces shooter, Delta Force 2, you can kill enemies as effectively by shooting them in the foot as in the head.)However, 1998 releases like Sin, Vigilance and Tom Clancy's Rainbow Six introduced the concept of ''one shot, one kill'' -- with wounds to the head instantly fatal -- and Soldier of Fortune extends that conceit. An enhanced version of Id Software's Quake II game engine allows the player to hit 26 zones on the polygonal enemy bodies, with results that range from the disturbing to the practical.Playing with all the violence options enabled, I shot off enemies' legs in the opening level in the New York subways. I shot off arms aboard a speeding freight train in southern Africa. I left chests and groins spattered with blood in the Kosovo sewers. (When enemies fell forward, I could see the exit wounds.) In an Iraqi marketplace, guts poked out of the hole I had drilled in an enemy's midsection. In Siberia, I liberated some heads from their bodies and reduced others to something resembling partially eaten apples.And when I finished a level, I was provided with a checklist of carnage performed, including ''throat shots,'' ''head shots'' and, ahem, ''nether region shots.'' These are unusual things for a computer game to be adding up.Does the game go too far? Initially, I would have said yes. How many ways should you really see an enemy's head explode? (Soldier of Fortune is not suited for children. Parents and the squeamish will be grateful for a password-protected filter that allows users to disable five violent elements in the full-violence version. A ''tactical low-violence'' version is also available in which the filter is permanently enabled.)But it turns out that once you've seen one screaming soldier with his leg shot off, you've seen them all. The effects are shocking the first few times around, and then they begin to recede into the body of the game.And there is something to be said for a game that offers enduring evidence of the player's passage through the game world. Details like bullet holes and bloodstains on walls helped make Duke Nukem 3D a huge hit in the mid-90's, and it might be argued that Soldier of Fortune represents the next bloody footstep in this trend.The treatment of violence isn't the only creative twist. Soldier takes a novel approach to saved games. Saves are snapshots of the player's position, which enable one to resume play from a given point at a later time. Most three-dimensional shooters allow saves at any point during the game -- a strategy that allows players to finish games more easily, but one that, when abused, can squeeze the fun out of a game by sacrificing its challenge.Soldier gears the number of saves allowed to the difficulty level selected at the start of a new game -- from unlimited at the Effortless level to five at the Medium level and none at the Unfair level. At the harder levels, that turns saving from a simple reflex into a strategic decision. Can you finish the rest of an unseen level with the available saves?Soldier also takes a step toward addressing reduced capacity in injured enemies. In most games, enemies simply pound away at the player until they are killed, regardless of the level of damage they have taken. Soldier of Fortune interrupts this cycle. A shot to the leg may leave a live enemy hopping on one foot, and the hopping means that at least for the moment, the enemy isn't shooting at the player. You can also force enemies to drop their weapons and surrender or flee the field. The game in which enemies and the player lose proficiency as they take damage still awaits us, but in the meantime, it's agreeable to find other ways to resolve combat.Gore finds its justification only in what it adds to game play, and when the novelty of blood-spouting necks wore off, I found myself wishing this advanced damage model had served as inspiration for other elements of the game. The creators seem so taken with the depictions of violence that they have neglected the fear and dread that the carnage should inspire in its victims and perpetrators.Enemies with such diverse vulnerabilities should be smart enough to better protect their nether regions -- they are little more than the usual bunch of dumb bunnies -- and engagements should be smaller and more tactical. After all, when you are going up against an army of enemies who are all blazing away at you, you don't have time to try for critical hits. All you can do is survive.Perhaps these shortcomings are a sign that although the developer has surely pushed the envelope, it hasn't finished addressing it.Soldier of Fortune; published by Activision; $45.99; Windows 95, 98 and NT 4.0-SP5; for mature players.GAME THEORY
To the Editor:Gov. George W. Bush's plan to allow people to put their Social Security in the stock market (front page, May 1) is ill advised. I don't consider Social Security to be my main retirement income, but a fallback, in case the stock market doesn't do well.Mr. Bush seems to want to change my portfolio mix arbitrarily without my consent. He would be better advised to see to it that the current system stays in place. I want some of my retirement to be ''risk free.''ELMER C. HARTMAN  Canandaigua, N.Y., May 1, 2000To the Editor:Gov.
