GLAMOROUS as they may be by reputation, game safaris in East Africa, whether tented or otherwise, have never been truly luxurious, nor did most people expect them to be.It was felt, rather, that the experience should be at least just a little on the rough side, even if you were staying in game lodges and viewing the animals from a Land Rover or a minivan; that in short the authentic safari experience demanded, and was even improved by, a certain degree of character-building discomfort.GLAMOROUS as they may be by reputation, game safaris in East Africa, whether tented or otherwise, have never been truly luxurious, nor did most people expect them to be.It was felt, rather, that the experience should be at least just a little on the rough side, even if you were staying in game lodges and viewing the animals from a Land Rover or a minivan; that in short the authentic safari experience demanded, and was even improved by, a certain degree of character-building discomfort.In theory there is something to be said for keeping things a bit rugged when it comes to East African tourism: There's a romantic appeal to the notion of roughing it on safari, even though people nowadays are likely to be roughing it in permanent camps that have tents with roofs, indoor plumbing and electric lights (until the generator shuts off), or in a safari lodge, even the least luxurious of which have a bar, a gift shop and a swimming pool.But there's a larger philosophical question here. Over the past decade or more, East Africa has been moving steadily toward mass tourism. Some of the game parks -- Amboseli National Park, in Kenya, is a perfect example -- were virtually destroyed by the sheer number of tourists, and on the rare occasion when you saw a lion, the poor animal was instantly surrounded by dozens of minibuses. One felt -- felt strongly -- that there was something degrading about the experience, that too many people were chasing too few animals, and in the process undermining the fragile ecology and turning the park into a dust bowl.Now, the pendulum seems to have begun swinging in the opposite direction (though perhaps too late for Amboseli, alas). In both Kenya and Tanzania, new ideas are taking hold -- of smaller, more luxurious lodges, of placing less reliance on the old idea of constantly moving the tourist around in a vehicle, of a tourism of quality, as opposed to quantity.Our first hint of this change came when we were planning our December safari for four -- my wife, Margaret, and I with friends and neighbors of ours in Dutchess County, Jeff and Sue Lynn. We arranged the trip through Abercrombie & Kent. We wanted very much to go back to Tanzania, especially the Ngorongoro Crater and the Serengeti during the great migration, which we had done several times before.On our first trip, 15 years ago, conditions had been primitive, and the food supply seemed to consist mostly of carrots and eggs. Gradually, over the years, things got better, but Tanzania was still dramatically less comfortable than Kenya, with a bureaucracy that made getting in and out of the country something of a challenge. But today, we were assured, things had changed. A South African hotel consortium had built a new lodge a couple of years ago on the rim of the Ngorongoro Crater that was, to put it bluntly, ''over the top.''''Yeah, yeah,'' we grumbled, but in the face of a barrage of enthusiasm from Abercrombie & Kent, booked into Ngorongoro Crater Lodge.Our first surprise, flying in a charter plane from Kenya into Tanzania, was that everyone at Kilimanjaro International Airport was pleasant, helpful and friendly. On previous visits, it had been like flying into East Germany in the old days, particularly coming from Kenya, toward which there was great suspicion and hostility, but the airport is now pretty cheerful, with well-stocked souvenir shops and smiling bureaucrats. Our luggage went through customs without a search and was loaded onto our chartered Tanzanian Beechcraft. An hour later we landed on the rim of the crater; the airstrip here is often foggy, so many guests of the Ngorongoro Crater Lodge land at Lake Manyara, two and a half hours away at ''game drive speed.'' (During our own 20-minute drive to the lodge, we saw one big old tusker in a field by himself, right next to the road).The lodge was set so close to the rim of the crater that it looked as if it might slide 2,000 feet or so into it; it's as if somebody had built a hotel on the rim of the Grand Canyon. At first sight it has a certain Moorish feel, since it is bordered by a crenelated high pink stucco wall that reminds one rather of those at Fez or Marrakech, but there is an air of fantasy to it, a slightly dotty passion for odd shapes and forms that is more Hollywood than Morocco. Cecil B. De Mille  would have loved this place!A very nice young man meets us and takes us into the lodge's main building -- or one of the main buildings, for, as he explains it, the lodge is built on three different levels, and divided into three separate camps, two with 12 suites each and one with six; each camp has its own central house for dinner, drinks and lounging. Vast windows overlook a sheer drop to the crater floor and a panorama that stretches forever.Scarcely less breathtaking is the decor, to which the phrase ''over the top'' scarcely does justice. In fact, not since I was in Cher's house in Malibu have I been anywhere so extraordinary.Here, competing for attention, are giant fireplaces, African sculpture and weapons, fine bronzes, English country furniture, extravagant and very beautiful tile work in the Moorish tradition, paneled walls in the sumptuous and elegant living room, where everybody gathers for drinks and hors d'oeuvres before dinner, a dining room full of light, air, unexpected corners and fireplaces and tables set with an elegance that would be sumptuous in Paris or New York. The men's room is so unexpected and luxuriously decorated that we all go to visit it -- it's as if Versace had been asked to design a urinal -- only to discover that the ladies' room is even more baroque.A short walk down to our own bungalow -- avoiding the traces of Cape buffalo that have found their way around the wall at night -- brings us to a round hut, in the African tradition, with another splendid view. Outside, beautifully hand-carved wooden doors, the whole thing like a Hollywood set for the chief's hut in a movie; inside, weird ''Phantom of the Opera'' excess: a king-sized bed with a vast carved headboard, so you can lie in bed and look out over the crater; magnificent antique furniture, all veneer and ormolu; high ceilings; vast, velvet drapes; a huge crystal chandelier, and strange, tiny windows on the non-crater sides, with elaborate carved shutters. There is a silver tray with an antique crystal decanter of sherry and antique crystal goblets -- drinks are on the house, we have been told, except for Champagne and Cognac. Furniture is upholstered either in soft leather or dark velvet, with pillows everywhere. The interior design of the hut looks like -- well, frankly, Malibu, but out the window one can see Africa stretching before one's eyes.More surprises. A big old-fashioned bathtub in the middle of the bedroom floor (and even more surprising, scads of hot water, day and night, and thick, luxurious towels), so you can soak and look out over the crater and the far horizon, a shower big enough for half a dozen people, with a tiled seat like that in a Turkish bath, a big fireplace (which is kept burning by unseen hands), magnificent parquet floors, one-size-fits-all Wellies in case of mud or rain. Everything, in short, has been thought of.We have our own valet, who is responsible for our well-being -- looks after the bungalow, brings snacks and drinks, waits on us at meals and summons security guards at night when we want to go to and from the main house, just in case there are buffalo or worse around. And all this is before we've had a meal.But it's the meal that astonishes. The chef (from Claridge's in London, if you please) wrings a miracle out of thin air three times a day (three and a half, if you include teatime): wonderful cheeses, glorious duck, great soups, arrays of exotic fruit and lighter-than-air pastry. Every meal is a surprise and delight, perfectly presented and served, accompanied by excellent South African wines. Anything we want, he will prepare for us, he assures us; we shouldn't feel confined to the menu.It is like being at sea, first class on the old Queen Elizabeth or the Queen Mary, and by the end of lunch it is all we can do to waddle up to the gift shop (very expensive, world-class shopping), back to our beds for a nap, then, after tea, down into the crater itself to see some game.The crater and its game are something special and wonderful, and worth coming halfway round the world to see. Just in case we get hungry en route, the hotel's game driver takes with him a thermos of coffee, iced soft drinks, the kitchen's latest batch of freshly baked biscuits and cookies -- he is as concerned about our comfort as he is to get us close to a lion or a leopard.Dinner is served at 8, and we leave ourselves an hour to join our fellow guests and the management for drinks before the fire in the big living room. There is a wonderful array of sherries and madeiras in cut-glass decanters accompanied by freshly baked hot cheese straws. In the dining room, the fireplaces have been lighted, the lighting is subdued and the African sculpture in alcoves illuminated from above so they stand out with startling effect.No effort is made to push guests into matey conversation -- some are standoffish, some not, to begin with -- but the atmosphere and the charm of the management team soon break down any initial reserve or language barriers, and by dinnertime people are exchanging business cards, scribbled addresses (''If you're ever in Cape Town . . .''), photographs of game and, of course, safari stories.There are several South Africans visiting the lodge from the company that owns it, the mysteriously named Conservation Corporation Africa, which runs equally luxurious and unusual lodges and camps in South Africa, Zimbabwe and East Africa.However unique the Ngorongoro Crater Lodge is, it is also the cutting edge of a trend. Before this sybaritic stay in Tanzania, we had visited Kenya, and found one of East Africa's classic camps also in the course of change, and maintaining its ecological integrity in the process. Wilderness Trails at Lewa Downs near Isiolo, belonging to the energetic and charming Craig family, is in the process of being upgraded to luxury status. Its original six rooms are in three cottages, with each cottage sharing a sitting room and verandah. Two newer cottages have only one bedroom apiece, and more privacy; a separate house an hour's drive away is also available for rent.While the Craigs do not go in for elaborate decor or crystal chandeliers, they now have perhaps the most beautiful swimming pool in the world, one edge of which simply vanishes into space, above a deep canyon through which lion and leopard occasionally prowl. And the wonderful food, served outdoors in great style, will leave you looking for a Stairmaster.Fortunately, since the Craigs own 45,000 acres of the surrounding countryside, you can go on guided and guarded walks to work off some of the food, or on morning horseback safaris, ending in a delicious breakfast cooked out in the bush, so you can eat your eggs and bacon watching zebra and even rhino watching you, then walk back.Accommodations are in thatched cottages, with lovely sitting rooms with open fireplaces and your own self-service bar. The Craigs are a big family, with the elder Craigs still very much involved in the daily doings, and their two sons and their families running things now. They are ideal hosts -- friendly without getting in your way -- and endlessly interesting, with very nice children and dogs, so it's like staying in an English country house, right down to the hearty teas and the coffee and brandy in front of the fireplace at night.The wildlife is hard to beat, particularly when it comes to rhinoceros, which are increasingly rare and hard to see elsewhere, but which at Lewa Downs are given sanctuary and wander close to the house in all ages and sizes. The vegetable garden is well worth seeing, and the house is set in beautiful English gardens, filled with magnificent furniture from African woods made in their own workshops.Here, too, in less flamboyant style, are smaller, more deluxe accommodations, and an effort to put the visitor in a place where the game goes by, rather than going in pursuit of it. If the ecology, and the game itself, is to survive in the wild, smaller and on foot is better, with or without the luxury component. The alternative, perhaps -- God forbid! -- will be game theme parks.In this sense, the Craigs may have set a precedent. From the beginning, after Kenyan independence in 1963, when they opened their house to visitors, they have had game walks, game rides on horseback, bird walks and bird watching outposts for marsh birds. The only game drives are in open four-wheel-drive vehicles.The experience of seeing the animals, unforgettable however many times you do it, is only improved by getting at once closer to them and to nature, and is not diminished by luxury at the end of the day. Nor would it be diminished by a simple tent on the veldt. The point is not luxury, but reducing the number of visitors and vehicles. To see, as we did, a leopard close up in broad daylight -- to watch it for nearly an hour -- is more deeply satisfying than all the museums in the world.If you go in styleReservations were made through Abercrombie & Kent International, 1520 Kensington Road, Suite 212, Oak Brook, Ill. 60523; (800) 323-7308.Ngorongoro Crater Lodge, Tanzania, c/o Conservation Corporation Africa, (27-11) 809-4300, fax (27-11) 809-4400. One of several lodges at the crater rim. Nightly rates range from $800 to $1,000 for two in a double room, depending on the accommodation and the season, including meals, house wines and spirits, beer and butler service. Park fees and transfers are extra, as are cellar wines, Cognac and Champagne.Wilderness Trails, Lewa Downs, Kenya, is represented by Bush Homes of East Africa in Nairobi, (254-2) 571661, fax (254-2) 571665; www.bush-homes.co.ke. Rates start at $660 a night for two in a room, including meals, table wine, beer and activities.United States visitors require a visa to visit Tanzania but not Kenya if vacationing there for less than 30 days. For details:Consulate General of Kenya, 424 Madison Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10017; (212) 486-1300.Tanzanian Mission to the United Nations, 205 East 42nd Street, 13th Floor, New York, N.Y. 10017; (212) 972-9160.MICHAEL KORDA is editor in chief of Simon & Schuster.
What is your deepest thought about, say, coffee? Not Colombian versus Sumatran, latte or espresso; forget that. What I want to know is, when you are thinking about coffee, really thinking, what do you think about? It doesn't really matter. I already know what you think, and besides, you're wrong.I learned the right answer after visiting the Tuxedo Park mansion of Clotaire Rapaille, the French-born medical anthropologist whose method for mining our covert thoughts has compelled nearly 50 Fortune 100 C.E.O.'s to dig deeply into their treasuries. In a field crowded with tired methods for surveying the desires of the American heart and mind -- scenario planning, observational research, focus grouping, ethnographics, content analysis, motive critiquing and Markov chains -- Rapaille's technique of ''archetype research'' is a revival of the psychoanalytic methods popular in the 1950's and 1960's. Pioneered by the Viennese psychologist Ernest Dichter, this technique doesn't bother to ask what people want, but why. Early on, Dichter persuaded Esso to forgo traditional descriptions of its product's superiority by tapping into Americans' aggressive motives for owning cars in the first place. Dichter was behind the phrase, ''Put a tiger in your tank.''What is your deepest thought about, say, coffee? Not Colombian versus Sumatran, latte or espresso; forget that. What I want to know is, when you are thinking about coffee, really thinking, what do you think about? It doesn't really matter. I already know what you think, and besides, you're wrong.I learned the right answer after visiting the Tuxedo Park mansion of Clotaire Rapaille, the French-born medical anthropologist whose method for mining our covert thoughts has compelled nearly 50 Fortune 100 C.E.O.'s to dig deeply into their treasuries. In a field crowded with tired methods for surveying the desires of the American heart and mind -- scenario planning, observational research, focus grouping, ethnographics, content analysis, motive critiquing and Markov chains -- Rapaille's technique of ''archetype research'' is a revival of the psychoanalytic methods popular in the 1950's and 1960's. Pioneered by the Viennese psychologist Ernest Dichter, this technique doesn't bother to ask what people want, but why. Early on, Dichter persuaded Esso to forgo traditional descriptions of its product's superiority by tapping into Americans' aggressive motives for owning cars in the first place. Dichter was behind the phrase, ''Put a tiger in your tank.''While pollsters and others have long sought to track the anarchic flight of our national whimsy, Rapaille's refinement of Dichter's method has a more ambitious goal, which he compares to a psychoanalytic human genome project. He intends to describe all the lasting characteristics that generate the choices we Americans make, year after year, trend after trend. Call it inner-life profiling.In the old days (first Clinton administration), polling was used to search for trends in opinions about anything -- lawn mowers, gay adoption, Newt Gingrich, EggBeaters. Rapaille rejects such methods as prehistoric. ''That's all content,'' he said dismissively (which is tough, since he sounds vaguely like Inspector Clouseau). ''It will all change next year. What I am doing is a kind of physics. I am trying to uncover the unwritten laws. I am discovering the cultural structure of the American mind.'' Rapaille claims he can describe our deepest associations (and for a price, has) with coffee, money, the presidency, cheese, the sun, whiskey, hospital supplies, recycling, barbecue sauce, life insurance agents, NutraSweet, luggage, the abstraction of making a mistake, the forest, a door.Who are we Americans, deep down? Rapaille believes he has an answer. ''I am compiling a database of cultural codes,'' he said, sitting in a Queen Anne chair beneath the 20-foot ceiling of his 120-year-old home, Lindley Hall. It is now crowded with Rapaille's collection of stately busts of Caesar, Apollo, Napoleon, Moli re. Dressed in a black shirt and tight black pants, he ordered a domestic to fetch us some morning beverages. He ran his hand through a Jeffersonian blast of reddish flyaway hair. Rapaille thinks of himself as a latter-day Amerigo Vespucci, a cartographer and pilot major, bringing maps of a Mundus Novus back to his patrons -- Ford, Procter & Gamble, Seagram, AT&T, General Mills, Birds Eye -- in order to better outfit the next wave of caravels, eager to colonize this place once thought to be dark, unachievable and obscure.Now, about the coffee.Rapaille explained that he first discovered the route to our secret feelings about coffee 30 years ago, when he worked in Switzerland with autistic children. Why was it, Rapaille wondered, that these children, who were quite smart, had such difficulty learning language? The answer is now fairly accepted linguistic theory: the children lacked an emotional life, and emotion is understood to be the linguistic glue that keeps meaning alive in our minds. Nearly every word we know has an emotional resonance that, as we grow up, sinks into the unconscious.With this idea, Rapaille then posited that these sublimated emotional memories occupied a place between each individual's unconscious (Freud) and the collective unconscious of the entire human race (Jung). It is a ''cultural unconscious,'' which is closely associated with language and therefore differs from culture to culture, country to country.''When a man and woman have a child, they always have a human being,'' he said. ''And when an American man and woman have a child they always have a little American. But there are no genes for 'American.''' So culture is completely acquired.''There is always a first time we imprint something, and when we do we create mental highways. We make use of these highways all the time and they become unconscious. I realized in Switzerland that it was different from one culture to another.''There is a little window of time when you are young in which to imprint the idea of 'coffee,''' Rapaille said, ''and so coffee in Italy is not the same as coffee in Germany.'' He laughed quietly to himself; this line gets big yuks in Milan. ''And very different in America.'' In Europe, the aroma of coffee can be smelled on nearly every block; in America, the aroma of coffee is almost uniformly experienced indoors.''It occurs usually around age 2 in America, when your mother is cooking breakfast,'' Rapaille said. ''Your mother loves you. She is going to feed you. You are happy,'' Rapaille said. ''This is the American code for coffee's aroma: 'home.''' So when you smell coffee, Rapaille said, your mind summons up childhood sensations of cozy domesticity. He later found further evidence to corroborate his finding: an American real estate agent told him that a common trick before entering a house with a client was to brew a pot of coffee because ''then it becomes a home.'' Rapaille said that 10 years ago he presented a more detailed account of this work to the makers of Folger's.''I told the people at Procter & Gamble, 'Don't care about the taste,''' Rapaille said. ''You have to own the aroma. The commercial we designed has a young man in an army uniform arriving home in the early morning. He goes directly to the kitchen and kkssshtt, opens the package. As the aroma goes upstairs, we see the mother open her eyes, smile and what does she say? She says, 'He's home!'''Rapaille sipped his fresh-brewed coffee.''Folger's has been using that study for more than 10 years, and it's still working,'' he said. ''So that is what I do. I break the code.''Discovering these codes requires a process not all that different from dream analysis. For instance, Rapaille was asked by a French company to find out how the American mind thought about ''cheese'' as compared with the French mind. Most researchers would conduct focus groups; they would ask questions and record responses. That would be a mistake, for the responses, Rapaille believes, would reflect back simply what people think they should say: taste, quality, price.Such straightforward questions -- about cheese or anything else -- are aimed at the cortex, the seat of the intellect. Rapaille directs his queries to what he calls the ''reptilian'' part of the brain, the home of smells, violence, sex, primal emotion.''See, I don't believe what people say,'' he explained, taking me to a room on the second floor. We sat before a Hitachi screen roughly the size of a Volkswagen and watched various tapes of his sessions. Typically, he begins a project by taking a group of about 20 people through a series of word-association games. Rapaille writes the words on a board and then asks the group to identify themes that unite the words. Finally, he has them tell childlike stories based on the concepts appearing on the board. Essentially, he wants to generate lots of little stories. The final session concludes with Rapaille asking his subjects to lie on the floor, some under blankets, some with pillows. In the background, he plays droning massage music for 20 minutes, until the active brain waves of the alert mind calm down to that tranquil moment just before sleep. Having spent the whole day activating their minds with every possible association with ''cheese,'' they are ready to call up the golden nugget Rapaille seeks: the ur-cheese memory.''I am taking you on a train trip,'' he says on one of his tapes. On the screen, his playful French accent carries members of the group back to their teenage years and then to childhood. No one speaks or moves. Finally, he asks them to go back to their earliest memory of cheese. It doesn't have to be the first time they tasted cheese, but the first time they consciously experienced it -- got near it, held it, smelled it, touched it. Then, gingerly, he brings them out of the near-slumber and, as with a dream, asks them to write down the story of what they remembered about cheese. He examines all the collected stories, and when he sees repetition in the narrative, he knows he has found the archetypal association.''In France,'' he said, switching off the television, ''the code for cheese is 'alive.' It is young, mature, old cheese. You smell it to tell the age. When you go to America, cheese is 'dead.' The first impression in America is that smell doesn't matter. Cheese is put in the refrigerator. In France, never. You would not put a cat in the refrigerator because it is alive. But in America, in the refrigerator, in the morgue; you put cheese in plastic like a body bag. It is legally dead, and scientifically dead, by being pasteurized.''The French company selling the cheese had a French commercial showing a woman smelling the cheese, opening it, poking it, touching the Camembert. You could see fingerprints on it. A love affair. Americans saw this commercial in a test and thought it was disgusting. Americans want safety. They want their cheese dead.''Another cultural contrast can be found in Euro Disney. When it opened, Europeans hated it. The park lost $1 million a day. Rapaille explained its immediate failure and subsequent success to a shift in understanding the deeper meaning of ''freedom'' in both places.''Freedom exists on an axis,'' he said. ''There is a second element to it, and in America the other side of freedom is prohibition. They are in tension all the time. Prohibition of alcohol. Today, political correctness.'' Disney World's Magic Kingdom celebrates the cultural concept of liberty while imposing harsh limits on the place itself. No pets are allowed in the restaurants. No smoking. No drinking. The female staff may not wear miniskirts. In Europe, these limitations prompted disgust.''Compare that to the French, where they have freedom but no prohibition,'' he said. ''You can't stop the French from doing anything. A dress code? No earrings, no alcohol, no dogs? The result was that no one came. Why? Because in Paris, the other side of freedom is 'privilege.' The French Revolution was not about abolishing privilege but about killing people with privilege so the revolutionaries could have it themselves.'' Among the major changes Euro Disney made to stem its disastrous losses were special areas for smoking, dogs and drinking. ''So you see islands of privilege,'' Rapaille said. Now the place operates at a profit and is one of Paris's most popular spots.Rapaille can go on, hiking across the landscape of our associations, uprooting one hidden realm of meaning after another. For Americans, he told me, ''trees'' are ''human beings.'' We hug them. They are raised in nurseries. They age into ''old growth.'' With this information, he persuaded the Timber Association of California (timber reminded people of the logger's cry, Timber!, which made them think of ''killing'') to change its name to the California Forestry Association. The group's public imagery ceased to feature fresh-cut logs (''dead bodies'') and avoided defenses of clear-cutting (''holocaust''). An ad that showed a man carrying a ''baby tree'' by the ''hair'' and planting it by stomping it with his boots was replaced with a woman cradling the burlap diaper of a sapling, planting it with her hands, watering it and promising to return.Once you understand the Rapaille method, you start noticing just how often in our mediated day some emotional depth charge is set to go off -- whether it's a television commercial, a Clinton speech or a Hollywood film. For years, there was a certain telephone commercial that had me by the throat. I am talking about that damp little melodrama involving a middle-aged black woman sitting in a chair as she receives her first phone call from her son, newly arrived to his dorm in college. I simply had to watch it. If it came on in a room, I would turn away from what I was doing or whomever I was talking to in order to experience this tiny emotional whippet. Now I see that it wasn't merely the surface sentimentality of the mother-son bond that was plucking my heartstrings. A Rapaille reading would interpret this vignette as an immigrant morality story tailored for the American psyche -- where blackness stood for our country's ongoing sense of striving to better yourself; college was the signifier for having made it. This wasn't sentiment; it was patriotism.Popular divination is nothing new, of course. But for the longest time, it was considered a kind of mystical art. In the last century, William McKinley's ability to sense shifts in the public mood caused a political foe to note that the president had his ear so close to the ground it was full of grasshoppers.These days, gut instinct has been replaced by hard science. In the back of the new soft-cover edition of Dick Morris's book, ''Behind the Oval Office,'' he includes nearly 300 pages of polling data, proposed ads and policy suggestions prepared for Clinton in 1995 and 1996. It's apparent that scarcely an adjective fell from the president's lips without being tested for its emotional voltage. Considering what Clinton survived in recent history, it's hard to argue with polling's efficacy.Although Rapaille, in his own way, will. Even though he admits that Clinton's success can be laid to his talent for staying five minutes behind our collective caprice, Rapaille believes that deeper cultural forces kept Clinton's popularity improbably high. Fortunately for the president, Rapaille said, Americans aren't all that enamored of perfection.Back in the Bush era, when Americans feared that the Japanese might take over, Rapaille was summoned by a corporate sponsor to find out how the United States could adapt Asian high-efficiency management concepts, like ''do it right the first time.''''If only we could be more like the Japanese, is what everyone was saying,'' Rapaille explained as he walked me into the drawing room past a Louis XIV bust illuminated by its own small lamp. Outside, through grand French doors, I could see Lake Tuxedo shimmering on a warm spring day. We sat at a small table and took lunch beneath a wall-size ancient tapestry depicting Solomon's dark brow, contemplative in judgment.''But what we found was that Americans unconsciously didn't want to do it right the first time,'' he continued. ''Now, the question was, why?'' To find the answer, Rapaille and his team set up an experiment with a group of American executives schooled in a management style known as ''zero defects.'' Rapaille told the group to find a way to scale a wall without touching it. If members touched the wall, they would be ''dead.'' He also gave the group instructions for achieving the goal. The Americans ignored the instructions and started screwing up.''Of course, they immediately died,'' Rapaille said. ''They were so upset. But I told them, 'Look here, in the instructions; what does it say?' And they would complain that they hadn't read the instructions. I would say, 'Too bad, there you have it, you are dead.' But they were so upset, they stayed up all night and designed a new way to solve the problem.''So, Rapaille concluded, Americans might say they want to 'do it right the first time,' but they don't really mean it. Americans like mistakes and actually delight in making them because it means that they can keep on improving. ''Zero defects in America,'' Rapaille said. ''This is perfection, and perfection is death. There is nothing else. What Americans want is more breakthroughs. That's why computers are so powerful. Six months later, you can throw yours out because there is a newer one, a better one. Americans love that. The worst thing is when we say, 'It's perfect, the end.' Americans hate that. That's the German attitude. Germans created the standard for beer 300 years ago. It's done. Perfect. So all you do is try to get as close as possible to that perfection. Well, that's completely un-American.''He sipped a glass of red wine and merrily segued into the greatest Rapaillesian character in recent memory.''Bill Clinton fascinates me,'' he said. ''Americans loved him. Why? Because Clinton made mistakes. It means he was learning something and getting better.'' Rapaille said that in the late 80's, Lee Atwater, then working for George Bush p re, hired him to do an archetype study of the presidency. Though financing ran out before Rapaille could complete his work, he was able to gather useful material in the word-association sessions. Participants compared the chief executive to a ''movie character''; they said he could ''make people see things.'' From this, Rapaille was able to identify the core emotional nubbin. Fatherhood? Celebration? Nationalism? No, no. The presidency is: ''cheap entertainment.''''What does he make, $200,000 a year?'' Rapaille asked. ''That's a lot cheaper than Oprah.'' This code is a problem for the two probable presidential nominees.''Gore is boring,'' Rapaille said. ''This is a real problem. Bush is not very intelligent. But then, who cares? Americans have never been impressed by intellectuals.'' So Bush's mediocre mind is not nearly the handicap that Gore's leaden personality is. Rapaille gives Bush the edge, but neither one of them interests him much. He openly pines for Bill Clinton the icon (not the politician). Mistakes weren't Clinton's only asset. America's code, according to Rapaille, is built around ''hope.'' That's why Clinton's slogan in 1992 ''was simply brilliant,'' Rapaille said. ''I still believe in a place called ''hope.''' He's almost a genius.'' Clinton had instinctively hit the grand slam of presidential codes. Mistakes. Cheap Entertainment. Hope.No wonder he's still in office.Rapaille plans one day to distill the essential elements of the American character in a book. ''I have a manuscript called 'Decoding the American Mind,''' he said, which will take his findings and analysis beyond his corporate patrons to the source -- American readers. Although the vast majority of Americans continue to define the national character via real estate metaphors -- frontier, panorama, province -- Rapaille believes that we will ultimately accept his Freudian interpretation of our inner life. For him, it is not a static landscape but something fluid and roiling. ''The inner life of America is not a place -- Canada is a place,'' he explained. ''Maybe the best place in the world. But if you are Canadian and you have a dream, you leave. Why? Because America is not a place. It is a dream.''Jack Hitt is a contributing writer for the magazine. His most recent article was on the new generation of sexual enhancement drugs.
SOMETIMES, even the professionals have to avert their eyes.''I could barely watch it,'' Vance DeGeneres, a veteran comedy writer and performer on Comedy Central's ''Daily Show,'' said of the incident on ''Late Show with David Letterman.''  ''It was almost like watching those films where they're clubbing the baby seal to death.''SOMETIMES, even the professionals have to avert their eyes.''I could barely watch it,'' Vance DeGeneres, a veteran comedy writer and performer on Comedy Central's ''Daily Show,'' said of the incident on ''Late Show with David Letterman.''  ''It was almost like watching those films where they're clubbing the baby seal to death.''The ''it'' was, perhaps, the most uncomfortable moment of political humor of the television season. After weeks of goading by Mr. Letterman, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas agreed to appear by satellite on his show, an encounter that was, by most assessments, a disaster for the Republican presidential candidate. Mr. Bush, hampered by the split-second time delay and projecting an air of being led on a forced march, offered one lame quip after another, including a pun about Mr. Letterman's recent heart operation so strained that it left the host staring, mortified, into the camera.The episode was instructive not only about how truly dangerous a tete-a-tete with a witty talk-show host can be, but also about how much clout television comedy wields in the shaping of political perceptions. In a recent survey by the Pew Research Center for the People and the Press, roughly one in 10 Americans said they routinely gleaned information about the presidential race from late-night talk shows like the ones presided over by Mr. Letterman and Jay Leno; nearly as many said that they regularly obtained political news from other shows, like ''Saturday Night Live'' and ''Politically Incorrect,''  ''The Daily Show'' and ''Mad TV.''The proportion of viewers admitting that they get their politics from television comedy may not be overwhelming. But considering that the 1996 presidential election was decided by a mere eight percentage points, what each and every consumer of comedy on television takes away from the experience can be highly significant.''I tend to believe that,'' said Dick Blasucci, the executive producer of ''Mad TV,'' Fox's Saturday night comedy show. ''Look: what killed Dan Quayle was the beating up by Jay Leno and others. I'm not saying they were taking sides, but I do think that kind of stuff leaves an impression.''Having a serious impact on real events is, of course, the last thing on the minds of most of the writers and performers of political satire on television. ''I just want the politicians and the people who watch our show to know that this is a place where the buck honestly stops,'' said Bill Maher, the no-nonsense host of ''Politically Incorrect,'' ABC's freewheeling after-hours talkfest. Still, as the Bush appearance on ''Letterman'' illustrates, political comedy relies ever more intensively on the willing (and in some instances unwitting) participation of actual officeholders and officeseekers.That is attributable, at least in part, to the blurring of the line between politics and entertainment, a boundary that has been fading since the psychedelic days of ''Rowan and Martin's Laugh-In,'' on which, in 1968, a dour politician by the name of Richard M. Nixon, in a startling cameo, uttered the show's stock phrase ''Sock it to me?'' into the camera. If self-mockery once seemed a bit of an indignity for politicians, nowadays they jump at the chance to make 'em laugh. Members of Congress appear as panelists along with country singers, rappers and actors on ''Politically Incorrect.'' Former presidential candidates -- even former presidents -- show up at benefits as agreeable sidekicks to their ''Saturday Night Live'' impersonators.C-Span has gotten into the act, broadcasting an annual evening of stand-up comedy from Washington, in which reporters like Walter Shapiro of USA Today and lawmakers like Senator Joseph Lieberman of Connecticut perform their 10 minutes of shtick. And in what may just be the slyest marriage of politics and comedy on television, ''The Daily Show,'' the satirical four-nights-a-week news and talk show with the comedian Jon Stewart as host, has hired the former Senator Bob Dole as an election-year commentator. (Mr. Dole declined an interview request.)''The Daily Show,'' with its deadpan reports from a comic corral of field correspondents and sidelong glances at the day's headlines, has developed a reputation for offering some of the shrewdest political foolery on the small screen. ''We had a blast working with them,'' said Todd Harris, who served as press secretary for the New Hampshire primary campaign of Senator John McCain, to which ''The Daily Show'' attached one of its performers, Steve Carell, for a mock news piece.''After the piece came out, we had a tape of it on board the Straight Talk Express,'' Mr. Harris said, ''and every couple of weeks or so Senator McCain stopped everything and said, 'Let's watch the Comedy Central tape!' ''The segment followed Mr. Carell's exploits as he tried vainly to get a seat on Mr. McCain's bus, a conceit that was inherently funny: Mr. McCain had become instantly legendary for the generous access he provided to the press. ''So there was a very humorous irony there,'' Mr. Harris said, ''but there was also a deeper irony in the fact that we were a serious presidential campaign, allowing them to partake of this irony.''It was just the sort of piece that ''The Daily Show,'' and its ongoing ''Indecision 2000'' election coverage, revels in. For the past 16 months, the program's anchor desk has been manned by Mr. Stewart. (Before that, it was the perch of Craig Kilborn, whose talk show now follows Mr. Letterman's on CBS.) Mr. Stewart, along with Madeleine Smithberg, the executive producer, oversees a staff of 60 writers, producers and technicians who work out of the show's headquarters on a desolate midtown Manhattan side street a block from the West Side Highway. The 30-minute program is a kind of comic cocktail of reality and parody. ''We are a fake news organization,'' Mr. Stewart said, ''but we feel the ups and downs that real news organizations feel.''Mr. Stewart sets a benign tone with political guests. There is a compassionate quality to his interviews that reflects a higher level of affection for politics than that displayed in the cranky irreverence of Mr. Letterman or the jokey, disconnected chatter of Mr. Leno. ''I believe if these people come on our show, they should have the respect they're owed by virtue of the office they're in,'' Mr. Stewart said. ''I want them to feel comfortable.''The show, in fact, has gained a following in political circles for its hipness and sense of fun. ''He is so fast, if he were a shortstop, he would pick up everything,'' Representative Dennis J. Kucinich, a Cleveland Democrat, said of Mr. Stewart. ''And he realizes that he is prospecting in very rich territory.''On ''Politically Incorrect,'' Mr. Maher's style is decidedly less ingratiating: he puts everyone on the hot seat. ''Not that I insult the movie stars, but my show lives on the premise that I never pull a punch,'' he said. As a result, he says, some potential political guests remain leery.''Dan Quayle was booked on our show recently and then pulled out,'' Mr. Maher said, adding that he was told that ''something I said'' about the former vice president had upset his handlers and that ''they wanted me to apologize.'' Mr. Maher declined.He is aware, though, that his blunt style has power. Asked, for instance, if he had invited Mr. Bush on his show, Mr. Maher laughed at the improbability of such an appearance. ''I've been so hard on him,'' he said. (He added that he was not a fan of Vice President Al Gore, either.)IT may be just as well that Mr. Bush steers clear of the program, given his performance on ''Letterman,'' a show that has become a kind of political proving ground. Gerard Mulligan, a longtime staff writer, said that Mr. Letterman ''discovered inadvertently'' just how gravely candidates respond to his comic denunciations. For weeks, he complained on the air about Hillary Rodham Clinton's refusal to appear on the show after announcing her campaign for the Senate seat from New York.''He said, 'The road to the Senate goes through this chair,' a spur-of-the-moment thing,'' Mr. Mulligan recalled. Soon enough, Mrs. Clinton was seated opposite Mr. Letterman and submitting to a pop civics test about New York, in which the host quizzed her on the name of the state tree and bird.It is a measure of how important a sense of humor on camera has become to political discourse that candidates feel real pressure to perform. As Mrs. Clinton all but said to Mr. Letterman, her appearance on his show was as obligatory a part of her race as a whistle-stop tour of the Western tier. The tacit and attractive acknowledgment to voters in such a booking is that a candidate is serious about running but not so serious about themselves. ''You have to prove you're a good sport,'' Mr. Mulligan said.The notion of a political personality able to give as good as he gets was what appealed to ''Daily Show'' honchos about signing on Mr. Dole, who will be called on for commentary on the program's continuing coverage of pivotal campaign events. On the campaign trail, Mr. Dole's barbs sometimes came across as a little too sharp, but they are welcomed by Mr. Stewart and company. His hiring brings the phenomenon full circle: the politician as television entertainer about the political process.''My theory on Dole,'' Ms. Smithberg said, ''is that he's like the lawyer who is secretly a musician. Law is the job. And there are these other muscles he always wanted to flex.''TELEVISION/RADIO Peter Marks, a national correspondent for The New York Times, covers media in the presidential campaign.
Jennifer French Bush, the daughter of Virginia Jones Bush of Old Saybrook, Conn., and William Clyde Bush of Bronxville, N.Y., was married yesterday to Thomas Mortimer Evans, the son of Wanda L. Plumer of Upper Marlboro, Md., and George H. Evans of Islesboro, Me. The Rev. Christopher H. Neely, a United Methodist minister, performed the ceremony at Pink Sands, a resort in Dunmore Town, Harbour Island, the Bahamas.Mrs. Evans, 30, was until last summer the head of marketing for Sky Sites, a London company that places advertising in airports. She graduated from the University of Vermont. Her mother is an independent education consultant in New York who helps families place their children in boarding schools, colleges and universities. In his recent tally of the woes afflicting Hartford (April 30), Colin McEnroe neglects to note the city's biggest problem: professional nay-sayers like himself who seem to take perverse pleasure in their Hartford-as-basket-case views.There's plenty of work to be done in Hartford, no doubt about it. But one could counter Mr. McEnroe's list with one equally convincing in its positive tone. Among the items on such a list might be Hartford's recent recapture of its glorious riverfront, the additions under way at the Bushnell Theater and the city's downtown library as well as the Learning Corridor project, which has already put a fresh face on the city's South End.In his recent tally of the woes afflicting Hartford (April 30), Colin McEnroe neglects to note the city's biggest problem: professional nay-sayers like himself who seem to take perverse pleasure in their Hartford-as-basket-case views.There's plenty of work to be done in Hartford, no doubt about it. But one could counter Mr. McEnroe's list with one equally convincing in its positive tone. Among the items on such a list might be Hartford's recent recapture of its glorious riverfront, the additions under way at the Bushnell Theater and the city's downtown library as well as the Learning Corridor project, which has already put a fresh face on the city's South End.Near the end of his piece, Mr. McEnroe makes much of the fact that when his radio station moved out of Hartford, he chose to remain downtown at his own expense. Therefore, he claims, he is no sneering suburbanite.But is a sneering urbanite any better?What's the point of staying in Hartford if one's not going to use one's  talent and influence to move the community forward?CLARE ROSSINI  Hartford

As a union protest at a lumberyard stretched into its seventh month, community groups, religious organizations and high school students have joined workers in criticizing a business they say has locked out employees and refused to pay fair wages. The focus of the protest is Rode & Horn Lumber, a company at 90 Waterbury Street that supplies high-end wood to carpenters and furniture makers.Twelve employees have been demonstrating outside the lumberyard since October, after months of dispute over a new contract. Timothy Lynch, president of Teamsters Local 1205, which represents the workers, said the company tried to break off relations with the union three years ago. Eventually the National Labor Relations Board ordered the lumberyard to negotiate with the union.As a union protest at a lumberyard stretched into its seventh month, community groups, religious organizations and high school students have joined workers in criticizing a business they say has locked out employees and refused to pay fair wages. The focus of the protest is Rode & Horn Lumber, a company at 90 Waterbury Street that supplies high-end wood to carpenters and furniture makers.Twelve employees have been demonstrating outside the lumberyard since October, after months of dispute over a new contract. Timothy Lynch, president of Teamsters Local 1205, which represents the workers, said the company tried to break off relations with the union three years ago. Eventually the National Labor Relations Board ordered the lumberyard to negotiate with the union.But, he added: ''It's been one and a half years, and they've failed to sign a contract. For seven months now they've locked the men out and replaced them with scab labor.''According to Mr. Lynch, employees had been earning an average of $11 an hour and the union wanted to increase wages to nearly $17, the average for city lumber workers. Joshua and Lazer Sternhell, the owners, had offered an increase of 10 cents an hour.In recent months, local religious organizations and community groups have written to the company in support of the workers, many of whom have been with the lumberyard for decades. In March, representatives of several organizations tried to meet with the Sternhells.''They wouldn't meet with us,'' said Stephen Jenkins, a coordinator for Make the Road by Walking, a Bushwick community group that was represented at the meeting. ''We met with a lower-level supervisor, and he said he would pass on our message to them. But we haven't heard from them. It's frustrating.''Students at the nearby Progress High School have discussed the situation in their social studies classes, and several joined in a worker protest on Monday. Many students whose parents work at similar union jobs identify with the workers. ''If they did that to them,'' said Anny Rodriguez, 16, ''they could do it to our parents.''Lazer Sternhell said he sympathized with the workers, but he called the union's demands unreasonable.''We've been accused of slave-driving and mistreating workers,'' he said. ''However, Local 1205 is requiring a 35 percent raise while nationally collective bargaining agreements are 3 percent.''In March, the National Labor Relations Board issued unfair-labor charges against the company. If there is no settlement, the case could go to trial.TARA BAHRAMPOURNEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: WILLIAMSBURG

Allegations that gun lobbyists would be virtual residents of the Oval Office.Vice President Al Gore went on the offensive again and again last week, using a series of campaign appearances across the country not only to advance his own policy initiatives, but to sow suspicion about the goals of his presumed opponent in the general election, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas.Accusations of a ''secret plan'' that would bankrupt Social Security. Intimations of a laxity in the war on drugs. Allegations that gun lobbyists would be virtual residents of the Oval Office.Vice President Al Gore went on the offensive again and again last week, using a series of campaign appearances across the country not only to advance his own policy initiatives, but to sow suspicion about the goals of his presumed opponent in the general election, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas.''Maybe he would pick Charlton Heston as the next surgeon general,'' Mr. Gore said in Chicago, referring to the financial backing Republicans are getting from the National Rifle Association, whose president is Mr. Heston.Mr. Gore's hammering away was a leading indicator of a new, more aggressive phase of the campaign. The retreat of Elian Gonzalez with his father to a Maryland estate seems to have opened up space again on America's front page for campaign machinations, much of them testier. In California, a conservative group, Shape the Debate, has begun running anti-Gore commercials; last week, Handgun Control introduced a spot that said Mr. Bush had signed a law that allows concealed guns in churches and amusement parks.The ammunition for Mr. Gore's attack was provided on Wednesday, when it was disclosed that the nation's gun companies had broken off settlement talks with 31 municipalities across the nation over lawsuits relating to gun violence, in hopes Mr. Bush would win the presidency and usher in a more favorable environment. (In other signs of the changing environment, a panel of Republicans proposed altering the current primary system, to allow only smaller states to vote first.)Mr. Bush, meanwhile, professed to be unfazed by Mr. Gore's jabs, although he couldn't help expressing some disgust. ''Totally pathetic,'' Mr. Bush said to a reporter after being informed that Mr. Gore tells Hispanic audiences that he had hoped his second grandchild would be born on Cinco de Mayo.PETER MARKS
To the Editor:We applaud the support for expanding drug and alcohol treatment expressed by Al Gore and George W. Bush (news article, May 3).Drug courts, which divert nonviolent, first-time offenders to supervised treatment rather than jail, are effective, yet put additional strain on scarce resources. Welfare reforms likewise require sobriety but put little money into treatment and prevention. Increased support from Congress is essential; additionally, the Department of Health and Human Services should release millions of Medicaid dollars currently prohibited for inpatient treatment.To the Editor:We applaud the support for expanding drug and alcohol treatment expressed by Al Gore and George W. Bush (news article, May 3).Drug courts, which divert nonviolent, first-time offenders to supervised treatment rather than jail, are effective, yet put additional strain on scarce resources. Welfare reforms likewise require sobriety but put little money into treatment and prevention. Increased support from Congress is essential; additionally, the Department of Health and Human Services should release millions of Medicaid dollars currently prohibited for inpatient treatment.Substance abuse costs this country $277 billion per year in medical costs, crime and lost productivity, yet only half of those who seek treatment can get it on demand. The support for treatment expressed by the candidates bodes well for our nation's future.TOM MCDANIELS  Director of National Policy  Legal Action Center  Washington, May 4, 2000
HERE is the problem in theory: A good job on the night shift opens up. A mother with several children is not offered the job, which would be a promotion, because her supervisor assumes -- wrongly -- that her family responsibilities prevent her from working nights.Did the supervisor act properly?HERE is the problem in theory: A good job on the night shift opens up. A mother with several children is not offered the job, which would be a promotion, because her supervisor assumes -- wrongly -- that her family responsibilities prevent her from working nights.Did the supervisor act properly?Hardly anyone would say so. Certainly the mother is the only one who knows whether she is able to work nights.Should the supervisor's action be against the law?Absolutely, in President Clinton's view.Is the problem pervasive?No one knows for sure.It is the kind of problem the president loves to address -- the way he has promoted school uniforms to improve classroom discipline and V-chips to block violent programs on television.His solutions cost little. They endear him to his admirers. And his political foes often seem to have been outsmarted.So last week, with a stroke of his pen, Mr. Clinton ordered an end to discrimination against federal workers because they are parents.''Believe it or not, there are still some employers who are reluctant to hire or to promote employees who have children at home,'' he said.His order, he said, sent this message: ''No glass ceiling for parents. The job they are doing at home is more important anyway, and if they can do your job, you ought not to stop them.''The key phrase is ''if they can do your job.''No one would argue seriously, for example, that because an employee cannot work nights, the government should be required by law to create a day-side promotion.A more difficult question is what happens when two people are in competition for employment or a promotion -- a single person who can work long hours and a parent who cannot afford to. Is it discrimination if the long hours are rewarded? Or is it discrimination if they are not?The practical effect of the executive order on those kinds of common situations is far from clear. The White House could not offer a single case of discrimination in the past that the president's executive order would now prohibit.Neither could the federal workers' union, the American Federation of Government Employees.Russ Binion, the president of Local 12, to which Labor Department employees belong, said, ''I know people don't get assignments because they have kids, but I can't give you a specific one.''The staff member who developed the policy, Bruce Reed, the president's chief domestic policy adviser, conceded that he did not know whether this kind of bias was a problem in the government.''We hope that this is not a widespread practice,'' Mr. Reed said, ''but we'd like to be on the safe side.''The executive order was welcomed in some circles as a symbol.''It's a very good thing the president did, because it's a marker,'' said Judith L. Lichtman, president of the National Partnership for Women and Families, a liberal advocacy group. ''This is how you get the conversation to change about what is acceptable and unacceptable behavior.''But as so often happens here, the president's political opponents were infuriated. It would be hard to overestimate the rage Bill Clinton ignites in some quarters nowadays, even over an executive order that may have no effect whatsoever.The response from Representative J. C. Watts Jr. of Oklahoma, chairman of the House Republican Conference, was typical:''This is the latest meaningless proposal from an administration desperately searching for a legacy that will endure after the evening news ends. Having already claimed credit for solving every problem under the sun, the Clinton-Gore team has apparently taken to espousing solutions in search of new problems.''President Clinton first broached the issue in his State of the Union Message last year. As part of a long list of proposals involving children and families, he declared:''I want to ask Congress to prohibit companies from refusing to hire or promote workers simply because they have children. That is not right.''On the president's behalf, Senators Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts and Christopher J. Dodd of Connecticut, both Democrats, introduced legislation last year that would have prohibited discrimination against parents by all employers. The bill went nowhere.So, unable to win support for a national policy, the president issued the executive order, which applies only to federal workers.Its range is narrow.Parents would not be guaranteed any jobs. Someone who could not work long hours because of family obligations would not have to be offered a position that required overtime. A worker who was not always free to travel could not expect a position that often required last-minute trips. A supervisor would be free to discipline an employee who was often late because child-care fell through.It is harder to ascertain what the order would do than what it would not do. White House officials made clear that the order sets a goal and does not give anyone the right to sue the government.The measure would certainly not alleviate the stress many parents face balancing the responsibilities of work and family.It would not seem to help, for instance, a clerk at the Labor Department, a single mother who asked when she was interviewed last week that her name not be used, who said she was sure she had been denied a promotion recently because of her family obligations. When pressed, she acknowledged that she had fallen behind in her work because she had taken so much unpaid leave to deal with a daughter's illness.IT wouldn't interfere in any way,'' said Joe Lockhart, the president's press secretary, ''with an employer's ability to reject workers who aren't able to perform a job in question. It would simply ensure that workers aren't discriminated against on the basis of being a parent.''The problem may be that this kind of discrimination is simply too subtle to prove.
TEN years after recapturing the Continent, Dwight D. Eisenhower calculated that the lessons of D-Day could be usefully applied in persuading  Congress to lace the land with highways. His administration dreamed up the National System of Interstate and Defense Highways and argued that these roads were not only about economic development, they were about national security.''In case of atomic attack on our key cities,'' he wrote in 1955, ''the road net must permit quick evacuation of target areas, mobilization of defense forces and maintenance of every essential economic function.''TEN years after recapturing the Continent, Dwight D. Eisenhower calculated that the lessons of D-Day could be usefully applied in persuading  Congress to lace the land with highways. His administration dreamed up the National System of Interstate and Defense Highways and argued that these roads were not only about economic development, they were about national security.''In case of atomic attack on our key cities,'' he wrote in 1955, ''the road net must permit quick evacuation of target areas, mobilization of defense forces and maintenance of every essential economic function.''Half a century later, the highways he built can barely handle a 5 p.m. crush of commuters in their S.U.V.'s, much less a panicky evacuation of the capital. But if he were alive today, the old five-star might smile to hear the latest Clinton White House strategy. The president and his national security adviser, Samuel R. Berger, have taken up a mantra that granting permanent ''normal'' trading status to China isn't just about profit opportunities, it's also about national security. At the same time, the administration has labeled the AIDS crisis in Africa a threat to national security, and Vice President Al Gore has raised similar fears with his ''new security agenda,'' which includes global warming.Without question there is a case to be made that economic chaos, disease and climatic upheaval can all trigger political nastiness. So all of this new labeling raises a question: Just when does a big problem turn into a national security threat?On trade with China, the Clinton administration argument is that granting normal trade status would reassure the Chinese that America isn't trying to hem them in.''From a national security point of view, it would in my view be a very, very unwise and precarious move to say that the United States doesn't care whether they're part of the world community or not,'' President Clinton told an insurance group last week, a theme he repeated nightly as he tried to win over 40 or so legislators who were still undecided about the China bill.Only days before, the White House was  arguing that the spread of AIDS in Africa would lead to economic collapse, political instability and civil wars that might eventually require American intervention.''I'm not saying that we have a short list of national security threats and East Timor is now off and AIDS is on it,'' Mr. Berger said in an interview. But strife has many origins, he said: ''If it creates instability, chaos, conflict and war, that has national security implications.''Mr. Gore, meanwhile, used a foreign policy speech last weekend to argue for the need for ''forward engagement'' (presumably a Gore-ism for trying to think ahead). He ticked off -- in no particular order of priority -- pandemics, economic inequality, global warming and the digital divide as potential security problems that had to be nipped in the bud.In Mr. Gore's case, the political calculation is obvious: he is trying to portray his opponent, George W. Bush, as a man caught in what he termed a cold-war mindset that sees national security only in the most conventional terms.But it is still unclear whether the new Democratic relabeling of issues is just shrewd political marketing -- to Democrats who don't like trade deals, and to Republicans who don't care for foreign aid, particularly when it involves AIDS -- or a truly new agenda for an age of new global threats.It is hard to tell. As the Clinton presidency winds down, the definition of national security threats has gotten ever fuzzier. Even some senior members of the administration worry privately that the White House regularly overplays its hand and should reserve the national security argument for events tightly linked to the prospect of the United States becoming involved in conflict. ''There's a significant risk of crying wolf,'' one of the president's top security advisers concedes. ''This isn't Sputnik,'' he added, in another allusion to the Eisenhower years, when appeals for education funds could be based on fears that the Russians were well ahead in the race to build the first I.C.B.M.'s.Clearly there is a strong moral argument for helping the destitute ravaged by AIDS, in Africa or elsewhere. And no doubt the disease could lead to political instability. But so can poverty, and the 1.3 billion people who live on less than a dollar a day trigger meetings at the World Bank these days, not in the Situation Room.Advisers to Mr. Bush, eager to portray the current occupants of the White House as long on butter and short on guns, carry the argument one step further: by making the list of security threats too long, they argue, the Clinton administration risks taking its eye off more imminent threats. Or as Paul Wolfowitz, dean of the school of Advanced International Studies at Johns Hopkins University and one of those advisers, wrote recently, AIDS in Africa and the environment are serious problems, but calling them  national security threats carries ''the implication that conventional security is no longer something we need to worry much about.''But this is also an administration repeatedly stung by the criticism that its foreign policy has been a series of belated reactions, rather than the product of any global strategy. So Americans may be ready to welcome anything resembling preparation for new crises, as long as it differentiates between real security threats, potential threats and social work. And it is possible -- though hardly certain -- that after a decade of unchallenged power and prosperity, Americans are ready to think about their national security in broader terms.A decade ago, any serious official who argued that admitting Communist China into a Western trade regime might change China's political culture would have been laughed out of the National Security Council. Today, even some Republicans sound a lot like Bill Clinton when it comes to talking about the benefits of exposing China to a Western-designed legal system or fueling the spread of the Internet. ''China's emergence as a world power is a classic security issue,'' said Richard Armitage, who has served several Republican presidents, ''and if getting them into the world trading system makes them more restrained, a better actor, then I'm for it.''Mr. Clinton's most potent argument may be the one he hasn't made in public, chiefly to avoid offending two of America's closest allies. In the first half of the 20th century, Germany and Japan lashed out in large part because they felt the world was constraining not only their military might, but their ability to manufacture and export. Any global system that reduces trade barriers, the theory goes, also deflates some of those pressures.But non-economic forces also cause wars, and it is a mistake, Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers acknowledges, to ''overemphasize the link between economic forces and future conflict.'' Perhaps that is why Mr. Clinton and Mr. Berger last week opened a new front in the China argument. Rather than argue the economic and political benefits of getting China into the tent, they made the case that keeping it out would court disaster -- that insulting China would strengthen the hand of the People's Liberation Army in its battle over China's direction with Prime Minister Zhu Rongji, the leader of China's move to a market economy. But if the Chinese economy opens too quickly -- forcing tens or hundreds of millions of workers in inefficient state-owned enterprises out of work -- Mr. Zhu could be blamed for that, too.Whatever one thinks of the logic, Mr. Clinton's national security case for letting China into the World Trade Organization seems to be winning some converts. ''The A.F.L.-C.I.O. has an answer to the economic arguments about this deal,'' one undecided congressman -- who asked not to be named -- said last week. ''But they don't have any answers on the security side.'' On the other hand, the effort to reclassify AIDS seems to have fallen flat. No one in either party is talking about reallocating the trillions saved by the Soviet Union's fall on international AIDS programs, or any other foreign aid.But China trade may be different. Eisenhower's highway system is now crumbling, and members of Congress want it fixed. A few who are on the fence about China have suggested that the place to fix the Interstate System is in their districts before Election Day. That might make them more amenable to the Clinton view of national security.Correction:  May 14, 2000, Sunday  Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about national security issues truncated a comment from Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers. As reported, Mr. Summers said it was a mistake to ''overemphasize the link between economic forces and future conflict'' because noneconomic forces also cause wars. But the main point of his comment was, ''When people are prosperous and hopeful, they don't look for men on horseback.''Correction: May 14, 2000, SundayBecause of an editing error, an article last Sunday about national security issues truncated a comment from Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers. As reported, Mr. Summers said it was a mistake to ''overemphasize the link between economic forces and future conflict'' because noneconomic forces also cause wars. But the main point of his comment was, ''When people are prosperous and hopeful, they don't look for men on horseback.''
In a series of brisk exchanges last week, Vice President Al Gore and Gov. George W. Bush laid out their disagreements over gun control, foreign policy, tax cuts, Social Security and Mr. Bush's record in Texas. Perhaps because he is struggling to stay even with Mr. Bush in the polls, Mr. Gore was on the attack almost every day, using highly personal language to derogate his opponent's policies. The subtext, however, was not about policy. It was about experience and temperament. Mr. Gore, with his customary lack of subtlety, was suggesting that Mr. Bush is an untested leader with half-baked ideas.  Stressing the value of experience is a time-honored strategy for the more seasoned candidate in presidential contests. But it comes with no guarantee of success. Otherwise we would never have had presidents named Carter, Reagan and Clinton.Jimmy Carter has been on both sides of the experience strategy. He won as a new face in 1976, but when he tried in 1980 to depict the Republican challenger, Ronald Reagan, as unready for the White House, the tactic backfired. Mr. Reagan was a deft campaigner and debater who skillfully parried Mr. Carter's attempt to make him appear a lightweight. That bit of history bears a cautionary message for Mr. Gore. Even though the vice president is the best debater in presidential politics today, Mr. Bush could gain significantly with a better-than-expected performance. For now, he is arguing that the vice president's extreme attacks distort his record and insult the voters.In a series of brisk exchanges last week, Vice President Al Gore and Gov. George W. Bush laid out their disagreements over gun control, foreign policy, tax cuts, Social Security and Mr. Bush's record in Texas. Perhaps because he is struggling to stay even with Mr. Bush in the polls, Mr. Gore was on the attack almost every day, using highly personal language to derogate his opponent's policies. The subtext, however, was not about policy. It was about experience and temperament. Mr. Gore, with his customary lack of subtlety, was suggesting that Mr. Bush is an untested leader with half-baked ideas.  Stressing the value of experience is a time-honored strategy for the more seasoned candidate in presidential contests. But it comes with no guarantee of success. Otherwise we would never have had presidents named Carter, Reagan and Clinton.Jimmy Carter has been on both sides of the experience strategy. He won as a new face in 1976, but when he tried in 1980 to depict the Republican challenger, Ronald Reagan, as unready for the White House, the tactic backfired. Mr. Reagan was a deft campaigner and debater who skillfully parried Mr. Carter's attempt to make him appear a lightweight. That bit of history bears a cautionary message for Mr. Gore. Even though the vice president is the best debater in presidential politics today, Mr. Bush could gain significantly with a better-than-expected performance. For now, he is arguing that the vice president's extreme attacks distort his record and insult the voters.Down the road, however, he will have to engage Mr. Gore's points more directly. The vice president is right to raise questions about Mr. Bush's achievement in education, the environment, health care and budget issues. He may have exaggerated Mr. Bush's lack of budget experience, but his point that Texas has a weak-governor system is a valid one.On foreign policy, Mr. Gore is also raising some fair questions about Mr. Bush, though there is a fine line between the license granted politicians who speak in generalities and outright distortion. The vice president accuses the governor of having a cold-war ''mindset'' that treats China and Russia as ''enemies.'' Mr. Bush says he has gone out of his way to assert the contrary. But Mr. Bush would withdraw loans and credits to Russia over its crackdown in Chechnya and abrogate the Antiballistic Missile Treaty. These two steps would be dangerously confrontational.Even so, Mr. Gore goes too far in accusing Mr. Bush of being an isolationist. As his father's son, he would be heir to policies -- and advisers -- that are international in outlook. As for China's status as a trade partner, Mr. Bush's position is the same as that of the Clinton administration.The arena where Mr. Gore has used his toughest language, surprisingly, is the budget. He repeatedly labels as perilous both the governor's $1.3 trillion tax-cut plan and his proposal to carve private investment accounts out of the Social Security system. In fact, Mr. Gore's reliance on the word ''risky'' for almost every Bush proposal probably should inspire someone to send the vice president a thesaurus. His point, however, is right. The tax cut, which Mr. Gore says would actually cost more than $2 trillion if you included the extra interest expenses from not paying down the debt, is ill-advised. And Mr. Bush has not addressed warnings from such stellar Republicans as Alan Greenspan that a big tax cut now could hurt the economy.It is of course an exaggeration for Mr. Gore to say that Mr. Bush has a ''secret plan'' for Social Security. There is something to be said for Mr. Bush's not getting lost in details, as former Senator Bill Bradley did earlier this year on the health issue. But the governor needs to flesh out his ideas on Social Security privatization. He must also explain how he would pay for his tax cut and at the same time increase military and education spending without jeopardizing other vital programs.There is a risk that the public could be turned off by bitter exchanges over policy minutiae and budget numbers. But such debates take the measure of the candidates. For Mr. Gore they reveal a policy aficionado who also has a gladiatorial instinct for verbal combat. For Mr. Bush they reveal someone who prefers to be aloof from detail, but who may not be able to pull that off with the ease of a Ronald Reagan. As the debate over experience continues, the candidates will be eyeing the polls for a reading on what the voters make of Mr. Bush's desire to float above the fray or Mr. Gore's desire to plunge into it.
Nothing enraptures lawmakers in an election year like a prolonged discussion about the needs of school children, an issue that ranks sky high in importance for voters.This week, the Senate delved into the year's most important education bill, a piece of legislation that would provide nearly $15 billion in education money, most of it for impoverished students. Democrats fashioned a ''war room'' with a chalkboard, school desks and computers, where senators conducted on-line chats about education. Republicans countered with snazzy charts and a steady flow of news conferences inside and outside the Capitol.Nothing enraptures lawmakers in an election year like a prolonged discussion about the needs of school children, an issue that ranks sky high in importance for voters.This week, the Senate delved into the year's most important education bill, a piece of legislation that would provide nearly $15 billion in education money, most of it for impoverished students. Democrats fashioned a ''war room'' with a chalkboard, school desks and computers, where senators conducted on-line chats about education. Republicans countered with snazzy charts and a steady flow of news conferences inside and outside the Capitol.But behind all the razzle-dazzle lies one startling possibility: This could be the first time in 35 years that an education bill so bogs down over partisan differences that it is vetoed by a president, if it does not get yanked from the Senate floor altogether.''I've never seen things so contentious,'' said Christopher Cross, a former senior Republican aide in the House who is now president of the nonprofit Council for Basic Education. ''And I've never seen them take so long to enact a piece of education legislation. We are now well into the second year, and it looks as if they won't get anything enacted.''Instead of trying to write bipartisan legislation, Republicans and Democrats have seized the debate to showcase their opposing remedies for ailing schools. The fact that Vice President Al Gore and Gov. George W. Bush of Texas have turned education into a signature issue has only served to infuse this year's Senate debate with partisan rancor.Fuming Democrats say they never bungled the education bill, a measure revising and extending federal school programs that comes up every six years, when they were in charge. They accuse Republicans of trying to jam through proposals that would devastate low-income schools. ''The Democrats never made this a partisan issue,'' said Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts, who is the Senate dean on education issues.
