''It's inexcusable.''Republicans reply that Democrats purposely want to thwart the bill so they can turn around and label Republicans anti-education on the campaign stump and hold their advantage with voters on the issue. They say Democrats are beholden to the teachers' unions and so entrenched in the status quo they do not want to try anything new.''We have functioned for 35 years under a system developed by Democrats in Congress,'' said Senator Judd Gregg, Republican of New Hampshire. ''And we've had 35 years of kids who haven't been able to read or write.''If the bill founders this year, the consequences would not be catastrophic, which is one reason the Senate does not feel compelled to compromise. The Department of Education, and the local schools, would still receive their $14 billion under the current regulations without a change in policy.But the wrangling over the bill illustrates just how far apart the two parties stand in addressing the frustrations of parents, and demonstrates how deeply politicized the question of education has become on Capitol Hill.''In a way, you have both playing to the extremes of their parties,'' said Amy Wilkins, the principle partner for the Education Trust, a nonpartisan, nonprofit organization that focuses on poor children. ''Are these guys going to grow up or are they going to continue to posture?''As it stands now, President Clinton is likely to veto the bill if Republicans stay wedded to several of their proposals. One would send billions of dollars directly to the states through block grants, giving governors leeway over how to spend the money.Democrats say the states need to be held responsible for how they spend their money. Republicans maintain that their bill would tie the money to improved academic performance.''There is virtually no accountability on the Republican side with the blank-check approach they use in their block grants,'' said Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the Democratic leader.A second component would permit some disadvantaged students to switch public schools and take their federal dollars with them, a move Republicans said would prompt underachieving schools to shape up. Democrats argue that the measure would drain money away from the schools that need it most.What's needed, Democrats argue, is more money to spend on more teachers, to fix decrepit school buildings and to help poor children. This remedy, which originated with President Clinton, is widely supported by the teachers' unions,The legislation and the debate crystallizes the fundamental differences between the two parties.Despite deep philosophical divisions, each side has made concessions. Republicans, who vowed a few years ago to dismantle the Department of Education, have increased federal spending on education several years in a row. And Democrats are more willing to demand accountability for education programs.Frustrated with the lack of consensus, a small group of moderate Senate Democrats, led by Senator Joseph I. Lieberman of Connecticut, and Evan Bayh of Indiana, is pushing alternative legislation that poaches ideas from both parties. The two senators agree that local school districts need more money and more flexibility to spend the money they get, but they also need oversight.In the House, Representative Nancy L. Johnson, Republican of Connecticut, and Representative Charles B. Rangel, Democrat of New York, have banded together to pass a bipartisan bill on school construction.These efforts at compromise could well be thwarted by the forces of election year politics. ''People want to be concerned about having an issue,'' Mr. Lieberman said last month.Despite the endless debate on education policy in Washington and on the campaign trail, education experts and lobbyists say both parties end up distorting the influence the federal government has on a child's education. The $15 billion being talked about is only about 7 percent of the budget for all education spending, and the bulk is directed at disadvantaged children.''The public is going to be led to believe that problems will be solved at the national level, and they won't be,'' said Mr. Cross of the Council for Basic Education. ''They are solved school by school.''
Mark Katz, presidential comedy writer, was pacing in the wings of the Washington Hilton like a nervous father-to-be while President Clinton delivered his lines at the White House correspondents' dinner last Saturday night.It was the high point of Washington's silly season, a kind of political sweeps, and Bill Clinton was lampooning himself as the quintessential Lonely Guy in the twilight of his presidency. His performance at the dinner won accolades as his funniest ever. Mr. Clinton showed home movies of himself running after his wife with a lunch bag, watching his laundry dry and bicycling through the Old Executive Office Building; the video has been replaying in the capital's offices all week.Mark Katz, presidential comedy writer, was pacing in the wings of the Washington Hilton like a nervous father-to-be while President Clinton delivered his lines at the White House correspondents' dinner last Saturday night.It was the high point of Washington's silly season, a kind of political sweeps, and Bill Clinton was lampooning himself as the quintessential Lonely Guy in the twilight of his presidency. His performance at the dinner won accolades as his funniest ever. Mr. Clinton showed home movies of himself running after his wife with a lunch bag, watching his laundry dry and bicycling through the Old Executive Office Building; the video has been replaying in the capital's offices all week.Being funny at the annual dinners of the Alfalfa Club, the Gridiron Club, and the associations of White House and broadcast correspondents, has become serious business in Washington, and Mr. Katz is a regular writer on the circuit. ''A good joke will last a week,'' said Mr. Katz, who also helped write Vice President Al Gore's speech at this year's Gridiron dinner. ''And a bad joke will appear in their obituary.''The rules are strict. No sexually explicit humor. The radio talk show host Don Imus shocked Washington with his raunchy jokes about the president at the radio-television correspondents' dinner in 1996. Stay away from ethnic jokes. Former Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato learned that lesson the hard way when he tastelessly imitated an Asian accent in a radio talk show about Judge Lance A. Ito of California. Nothing too mean. The Gridiron Club's motto applies broadly to most Washington humor: singe but do not burn.Because the dinner speakers are mostly powerful politicians with large egos, leading Washington humorists agree that the key to success is self-deprecation. ''Self-deprecation allows you to get away with more,'' says Landon Parvin, who often writes jokes for prominent Republicans, including former Secretary of State James A. Baker.''Take aim at yourself and then pick your spots after that,'' Mr. Katz agrees. ''You must earn the right to make fun of others by making fun of yourself.''At the White House correspondents' dinner, Mr. Clinton made sure to singe himself first and brought down the house when he said: ''A year from now, I'll have to watch someone else give this speech. And I will feel an onset of that rare affliction, unique to former presidents. AGDD: Attention-Getting Deficit Disorder.''Self-deprecation was also the centerpiece of Vice President Gore's successful monologues at the Gridiron dinner, in 1994, 1997 and last March. At the 1994 dinner, Mr. Gore made fun of his reputation for stiffness by being wheeled into the dais on a handcart. This year, he told the assembled journalists that ''there are some things I won't do to become president. I won't hold a press conference.'' He also drew roars by asking plaintively: ''This isn't a fund-raiser, is it?''But he did not miss a chance to lampoon his presumed Republican rival for the presidency, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, who he said ''thinks fettuccine Alfredo is the Italian prime minister.''Writing Washington humor can be tricky, not only because the jokes must be topical, but also because, ''You never know exactly what might go over the line,'' says Mr. Parvin. The 51-year-old scribe, who dreams up jokes at his home in Fredericksburg, Va., has mostly written for Republicans, but also helped write lines for Robert S. Strauss, the prominent lawyer and former Democratic National Committee national chairman, at this year's Gridiron dinner. Much of his time is spent writing serious speeches for politicians and corporate executives.''I write for people I like,'' he says.Mr. Parvin helped President Ronald Reagan use humor as a shield against his age, his glamorous background and even his relaxed work habits. But his big break came at the Gridiron dinner in 1982. He wrote the lyrics for a song, ''Secondhand Clothes,'' sung by Nancy Reagan, which parodied her taste for designer clothes.Mr. Katz, 36, formed the Soundbite Institute, a humor-writing consulting business, seven years ago in his apartment on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, after losing his job at an advertising agency. He is the institute's ''resident scholar.''In 1993, Mr. Katz wrote a speech for Madeleine K. Albright, who was then the United States ambassador  to the United Nations, that sparked laughter from President Clinton. He has since written for Mr. Clinton, Mr. Gore and Hillary Rodham Clinton.Mr. Katz says he likes to test ''the line'' in his humor writing. ''I try to figure out where the line is, walk directly up to it and say hi,'' he said. ''The challenge is writing right on the line.''One problem, both Mr. Katz and Mr. Parvin say, is that being funny has become a test for politicians. ''These are big pressure events,'' Mr. Parvin says.Humor has become another proving ground, especially for presidential candidates. Besides handling stand-up at the annual Washington dinners of media barons, politicians and lobbyists, politicians are expected to appear on the late-night Leno and Letterman shows, and on ''Saturday Night Live.''Mr. Gore has improved his timing and delivery in recent years, but can still be a bit rigid. Mr. Bush has yet to make a major Washington appearance as a humorist (he did a short speech at the Alfalfa Club in 1998) but his remarks did draw a few laughs at a recent Republican fund-raising dinner. His appearance on the Letterman show in March, however, drew chilly reviews.Presidents rarely bomb. ''A president gets laughs easier,'' Mr. Parvin says.In his last year in office, Mr. Clinton seems to have mastered humor and is having a great time using jokes to get in some last digs. At the radio and television correspondents' dinner, he won over the crowd with a gibe at ABC News's handling of Leonardo DiCaprio's interview with the president for the network's Earth Day special. ''Don't you news people ever learn?'' the president asked. ''It isn't the mistake that kills you, it's the cover-up.'' (Credit for this line apparently belongs to the White House deputy press secretary, Richard L. Siewert, not Mr. Katz.)The White House spokesman, Joe Lockhart, says it is Mr. Clinton, not his writers, who has become funnier. ''The president's delivery and ability to understand the timing of a joke is 95 percent of this,'' he said.
President Clinton has become a crucial behind-the-scenes player in the 2000 campaign, serving as a tactical adviser for House, Senate and gubernatorial candidates around the country.Although the spotlight has shifted to Vice President Al Gore and Hillary Rodham Clinton, prominent Democrats portray Mr. Clinton's role as that of an enormously valuable Strategist in Chief. They describe him as a sponge for absorbing political statistics -- a skill that is all the more enhanced because he has run twice in all 435 Congressional districts. And he willingly brings his well-honed political instincts to bear while exerting the power of the presidency to elect Democrats.President Clinton has become a crucial behind-the-scenes player in the 2000 campaign, serving as a tactical adviser for House, Senate and gubernatorial candidates around the country.Although the spotlight has shifted to Vice President Al Gore and Hillary Rodham Clinton, prominent Democrats portray Mr. Clinton's role as that of an enormously valuable Strategist in Chief. They describe him as a sponge for absorbing political statistics -- a skill that is all the more enhanced because he has run twice in all 435 Congressional districts. And he willingly brings his well-honed political instincts to bear while exerting the power of the presidency to elect Democrats.Mr. Clinton has been seeking election or re-election since 1974, when he was defeated in a race for Congress. And the president's closest advisers say that although he is no longer running himself, his passion for electoral politics has never receded. They also cite another, more personal, reason for Mr. Clinton's deep involvement: he wants to burnish his own legacy with the election of Mr. Gore to succeed him, the installation of Mrs. Clinton as senator from New York and the return of the House to Democratic control.''The guy can't live without a campaign in his life,'' said Senator John B. Breaux, Democrat of Louisiana. ''Life is a campaign for him. He needs a campaign to keep him going. This guy is not going to go into an igloo and freeze away. He can't help but advise.''Politicians and historians say they have never known of a president so deeply immersed in politics -- or a White House that, even during a lame-duck period, was so focused on polls and electoral considerations.The president is particularly engrossed in the first lady's race, and to a lesser degree in Mr. Gore's. But his involvement in campaigns from coast to coast is extraordinary.Mr. Clinton is much more than a fund-raiser in these campaigns, even as he has collected millions of dollars for House and Senate candidates. He offers candidates pointers on television and radio advertising scripts. He played a significant role in urging some prospects to run in the first place, and he often schedules trips and policy announcements with an eye to helping specific contenders.This portrait of Mr. Clinton has been gleaned from interviews with more than two dozen candidates and strategists, as well as lawmakers on Capitol Hill and officials at the White House and at the Democratic National Committee. Joe Lockhart, Mr. Clinton's press secretary, turned down a request to interview the president; some of Mr. Clinton's advisers said they were worried that it would seem unpresidential for him to discuss his activities openly.''He's the ultimate junkie,'' said Senator Robert G. Torricelli of New Jersey, chairman of the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee. ''He has the best walking knowledge of anybody in American politics.''Referring to Representative Ron Klink's drive to oust Senator Rick Santorum of Pennsylvania, Mr. Torricelli said: ''Last night he called me about the Klink race. He said he was convinced Klink could beat Santorum. He said, 'I want to do something in Philadelphia to bring our base in for Klink. I know he can carry western Pennsylvania, but he may have trouble consolidating the base in the east.' ''The president's network of contacts is vast because he has stumped in more than half the Congressional districts, his advisers say.Mr. Klink said that he telephoned the White House after he won his primary in April and Mr. Clinton ''took my call immediately.''''It's not just lip service,'' Mr. Klink said. ''He's really focused on this race. He can open doors with other individuals by telling them that this race is very meaningful to him.''Sometimes Mr. Clinton calls candidates on the telephone. More often, he grabs them to talk politics during his travels or at the White House.Craig Smith, a former Clinton political director, said he was at the White House recently to watch an Arkansas Razorbacks basketball game. At halftime, Mr. Smith said, the president cornered a group of his guests and held forth about the Democrats' presidential prospects in several states.He suggested that Mr. Gore not write off North Carolina in November, even though Mr. Clinton lost the state twice. If the Gore campaign takes that advice, it may cause the Bush campaign to rethink its own electoral tactics.''He came over and said, 'How do you think the math is working?' '' Mr. Smith said. ''He said, 'I think North Carolina looks good.' '' But Mr. Smith said he cautioned Mr. Clinton that the Democrats should think twice about pumping resources into the state.''I told him that state broke my heart -- twice,'' Mr. Smith said. ''But he said, 'I think we've got a shot.' ''Others who have talked politics with Mr. Clinton said he was preoccupied with the need for Democrats to win the loyalty of Hispanic voters. They said he had even spoken in detail about the importance of married Protestants. And, they said, he was particularly intrigued by contests in Michigan, New Jersey and Florida, where Mr. Gore has been pressing his campaign amid the tumult over the administration's handling of the Elian Gonzalez case.''Clinton is obsessed with Florida,'' the case of the Cuban boy ''and how it impacts,'' Mr. Torricelli said.Mr. Clinton still convenes political meetings twice a month or so in the ornate Yellow Oval Room in the White House family quarters. The sessions are not as pressing as they were when they were held weekly before the 1996 campaign, and the group of participants, which often numbers close to two dozen, is usually larger than the more exclusive club of the past. Mr. Gore does not attend anymore.Nevertheless, Mr. Clinton assembles his top aides, some cabinet secretaries and others to hash over how Democrats are performing and to look for ways to use his presidency to help candidates.At the start of the sessions, Mark Penn, a presidential pollster, reviews the latest surveys on an overhead projector. The discussion that follows is freewheeling, with Mr. Clinton -- who often chews on an unlighted cigar -- sounding at times like a political operative.''He is a full-time campaign manager at these meetings,'' one participant said. ''The entire meetings are discussions of how this would be good for Al or for the first lady and how he can help the legacy. Clinton is constantly saying, 'This would help Al.' ''Participants at the group's most recent meeting, in April, recalled that Mr. Clinton said he wanted to accept invitations to speak at college graduations in areas with high concentrations of minorities, like Shiprock, N.M., where he thought his appearance would help spur interest in Mr. Gore's campaign.A favorite pastime of the group is mocking Republicans in Congress, particularly when they do something that hurts them in the polls.James Carville, an architect of Mr. Clinton's victory in 1992, said of the president: ''If he calls me it would be to chat about Gore and Hillary. But I've had him tell me ideas for brochures in Senate races. He's a rare combination of somebody who's got the brains and the gut.''Joe Andrew, the national chairman of the Democratic National Committee, said he was dazzled by the president's knowledge of one Congressional district in Indiana, Mr. Andrew's home state. ''He said the Eighth Congressional District is one that goes back and forth -- the bloody Eighth,'' Mr. Andrew said. ''He knew that the southern part of the district was more conservative than the northern part. But he knew that in the southern part there had been tremendous growth because of a Toyota plant that opened there. And he knew of the Whirlpool plant in the northern part that had closed.''Michael J. Lapolla, the manager of Union County, N.J., who is seeking a House seat, said he ran into the president at a White House Christmas party last year. ''As soon as he found out what I was running for, he said he liked our chances and he knew just about everything about the district,'' Mr. Lapolla said.Mike Honda, a state assemblyman from San Jose, Calif., said Mr. Clinton helped persuade him to run for an open Congressional seat this year.Mr. Clinton has taken a particular interest in the campaign of Representative Rush D. Holt of New Jersey, a freshman in a tight race. ''His knowledge of New Jersey politics, and about my race in particular, is astounding,'' Mr. Holt said.Bill Nelson, the state insurance commissioner in Florida, who is running for the Senate, said Mr. Clinton went out of his way to praise him at a dinner of Floridians in Washington last November -- a move that he said helped considerably in persuading Democrats to take a serious look at his prospects. ''The President stands up in front of all these distinguished Floridians and proceeded to say very kind things about me,'' he said.Mr. Clinton is particularly involved in Mrs. Clinton's Senate campaign. One participant at a meeting with Mrs. Clinton's advisers said it was the president's idea that he not utter a word at his wife's official announcement of her candidacy in February.''When the issue came up of whether he would speak at Hillary's announcement, he weighed in and said, 'No,' '' the participant said. ''He said, 'I don't think that's right. This is her day.' There were plenty of people arguing the other way because it seemed unnatural for him not to speak. But it was a good judgment.''Despite Mr. Clinton's interest in his wife's race, Mr. Torricelli said the president does not fully grasp the unusual assortment of parties on the ballot in New York. ''He knows New York politically less than a lot of the other states,'' Mr. Torricelli said. ''He doesn't quite understand the mix of all those lines.'' Referring to Senator Charles E. Schumer of New York, he said, ''He calls Schumer and gets his opinion and calls me and plays off where we might differ.''While in past years some candidates have urged Mr. Clinton to stay clear of their districts, most of those interviewed said they were grateful for the president's wisdom and did not view him as an unwelcome meddler. ''He's not a Mr. Buttinski,'' Mr. Carville said.Yet some candidates were not so willing to bow before Mr. Clinton's expertise, perhaps out of fear that they might appear too close to the president. ''I've been in elective office over 20 years in Michigan,'' said Representative Debbie Stabenow, who is running for Senate and campaigned with the president this week. ''I know my state very well.''Asked how often he takes advice from Mr. Clinton, Tony Coelho, Mr. Gore's campaign chairman, said: ''I'm not going to go there.''
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday returned to what has been a solid source of support throughout his political career -- the Liberal Party, and its leader, Raymond B. Harding -- and asked for the party's backing as he sets his sights on the United States Senate. But Hillary Rodham Clinton also appeared before the same group, arguing that her views were more in touch with the Liberal ideology than were those of the Republican mayor.Mr. Giuliani and Mrs. Clinton each spent an hour in private at a Manhattan hotel with the policy committee of the Liberal Party, the first step in the party's move toward choosing its nominee by June 6. This usually barely noticed rite for candidates in New York drew a bustle of attention yesterday, evidenced by a lineup of cameras and security officers, reflecting the state and national political implications that have become attached to the decision by Mr. Harding's party.Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday returned to what has been a solid source of support throughout his political career -- the Liberal Party, and its leader, Raymond B. Harding -- and asked for the party's backing as he sets his sights on the United States Senate. But Hillary Rodham Clinton also appeared before the same group, arguing that her views were more in touch with the Liberal ideology than were those of the Republican mayor.Mr. Giuliani and Mrs. Clinton each spent an hour in private at a Manhattan hotel with the policy committee of the Liberal Party, the first step in the party's move toward choosing its nominee by June 6. This usually barely noticed rite for candidates in New York drew a bustle of attention yesterday, evidenced by a lineup of cameras and security officers, reflecting the state and national political implications that have become attached to the decision by Mr. Harding's party.''This is not my first time being interviewed by the Liberal Party,'' Mr. Giuliani said as soon as he left the meeting, grinning as he noted his longstanding ties with one of the smaller parties that his advisers believe could provide the winning margin in this election. When a reporter asked if he considered Mr. Harding a close adviser, Mr. Giuliani responded: ''I consider Ray Harding to be more than a close adviser. I consider him a close personal friend.''Mrs. Clinton pointed to the same friendship in remarks that seemed to lower expectations on her chances of winning the support of a party that almost invariably backs the Democratic candidate in statewide elections. ''I'm well aware of the mayor's relationship with Mr. Harding and the party,'' she said. ''But I came today to ask for their consideration, based on the issues that I'm talking about in this campaign and what I would do in the Senate.''As Mrs. Clinton knows, the only time a Democrat running for statewide office won without the cross-endorsement of the Liberal Party occurred in a Court of Appeals race in the 1970's, when judges to the state's highest court were still elected. Mr. Giuliani's aides noted this fact in a handout they distributed to reporters just before Mrs. Clinton left the committee meeting to talk with reporters.The Liberal Party has helped Mr. Giuliani's electoral success as mayor, not so much because of the relatively few votes he drew on the Liberal line, but because the party's support has allowed him to blur his ideological designation, making it more comfortable for some Democrats to vote for him.Mr. Harding was able to steer the endorsement to Mr. Giuliani with relatively little difficulty during his three races for mayor. But this high-visibility Senate race has presented the party with a particularly complicated choice. And it has put Mr. Harding in the position of choosing between the potential future of the 55-year-old party and his loyalty to a man who is a close friend and a source of jobs for his family and party.In an unusual display of public dissension, some Liberal Party members have said in recent days that they would oppose backing Mr. Giuliani, saying it would be a betrayal of the party's philosophy to send another Republican to the Senate.  And if Mr. Harding backs Mr. Giuliani, he risks losing a presidential candidate: Mrs. Clinton's aides have been pushing Vice President Al Gore to decline the Liberal Party line if the party backs Mr. Giuliani.Mr. Gore's aides said yesterday that he might accede to Mrs. Clinton's request. They said he would put off the decision as long as possible, giving him time to assess whether he needs the Liberal Party to win in New York (right now, his aides think he does not), as well as to see whether Mr. Giuliani stays in the race.Peter Ragone, a spokesman for Mr. Gore's campaign, said that the vice president was now beginning a closer look at the thicket of independent parties in New York, and that he would ''consider the endorsement'' of any party that shared his views. However, Mr. Ragone added, ''the vice president is a strong supporter of Hillary Clinton, and our campaign will do everything we can to elect her the next senator from New York.''Several of Mr. Harding's friends have tried to convince him that the Liberal Party's standing might be permanently damaged if it supports Mr. Giuliani and he defeats Mrs. Clinton this fall. And the advantage that Mr. Harding now enjoys by having Mr. Giuliani in City Hall ends in a year even if the mayor loses, because he will not be allowed to run for a third consecutive term.Mr. Harding has told friends that he will delay a decision as long as possible, in no small part to see whether Mr. Giuliani stays in the race. The mayor learned recently that he has prostate cancer and has said his medical condition would determine whether he stayed in the race.The Liberal Party endorsement has been important to Mr. Giuliani's political success to date, but he may be taking some risks in aggressively seeking its support in this race. For one thing, taking the Liberal Party line means giving up the Conservative Party line, said the Conservative Party chairman, Michael Long, who said it was ideologically dishonest for one candidate to run on both lines. The Conservative Party historically has been as critical to statewide Republican candidates as the Liberal has been to Democrats.''What he did today -- with Hillary, no less -- they both went and knelt at the altar of Ray Harding, who in fact gave us Bella Abzug, John Lindsay and Mario Cuomo,'' Mr. Long said. ''That sends a clear signal to the world that he wants to run with Al Gore, he wants to keep the Liberal tradition, and I don't know who the real Giuliani is.''In addition, running as the Liberal candidate is likely to complicate Mr. Giuliani's efforts to portray Mrs. Clinton as a liberal. That has been the thrust of his fund-raising appeals, and statewide Republican candidates have, for a decade, routinely attacked their Democratic opponents as liberal.When Mr. Giuliani was asked yesterday whether he considered Mrs. Clinton a liberal, he demurred. ''I think it would be overly simplistic to put labels on people,'' he said. ''I think you can say somebody is a liberal on something and moderate on something else and conservative on something else.''Turning the question to himself, Mr. Giuliani said: ''I think about me, they would say, he's conservative on economic matters, he's conservative on law and order. But he's moderate, and possibly even liberal, on social issues. It would depend on the part of the country you're in. In New York City, I'm often seen as very conservative. I travel south and west, I'm seen as very liberal. I like that, actually.''Mr. Harding greeted Mrs. Clinton politely when she arrived at the meeting at the Intercontinental Hotel, but, one participant said, asked no questions, sitting quietly in the back of a room that was thick with cigarette smoke.Mr. Giuliani and Mrs. Clinton share positions in their support of abortion rights, gay rights and gun control, as Mr. Harding noted after the meeting. But Mrs. Clinton pointed out some differences between them on issues of concern to Liberals, including her opposition to Mr. Giuliani's school voucher program,  and her criticism of the large tax cuts being advocated by Republicans in Washington.Asked her view of what the Liberal Party stood for, she responded: ''Based on what I know of it and what I've read about it, it stands for a sort of positive, progressive tradition in New York politics, and the kind of issues we've talked about. Very strong support for public education.  Strong support for child care and working families. Strong support for a minimum wage increase.''
Speculation has been especially intense since Gov. George W. Bush of Texas raised the possibility that he might choose Gov. Tom Ridge of Pennsylvania as a running mate. Not only does Mr. Ridge hail from an important battleground state with 23 electoral votes, but he also happens to be a close friend.Still, whenever Governor Ridge's name comes up, the point is almost always made that unlike Governor Bush, Governor Ridge favors abortion rights, hardly something that will endear him to the powerful Republican right. No matter, Governor Bush has said time and again, his friend merits consideration as a top prospect.Speculation has been especially intense since Gov. George W. Bush of Texas raised the possibility that he might choose Gov. Tom Ridge of Pennsylvania as a running mate. Not only does Mr. Ridge hail from an important battleground state with 23 electoral votes, but he also happens to be a close friend.Still, whenever Governor Ridge's name comes up, the point is almost always made that unlike Governor Bush, Governor Ridge favors abortion rights, hardly something that will endear him to the powerful Republican right. No matter, Governor Bush has said time and again, his friend merits consideration as a top prospect.Governor Ridge's critics think otherwise, and they seem bent on driving their point home.At a time when Mr. Ridge surely would prefer to be viewed as a governor who has cut taxes, improved schools, reformed welfare and cleaned up the environment, the Pro-Life Caucus in the Pennsylvania legislature is pushing hard to strip $4.3 million for family planning out of the state budget, arguing that the money is ''contributing to the abortion process.'' Mr. Ridge wants to keep the money in and, if the past is prologue, he will fight.When the issue came up in 1995, he managed to outmaneuver the caucus, even though a majority of the legislature is anti-abortion. And in 1996, he worked a compromise, retaining state money for use for family planning in general but agreeing that none would be used for abortions or abortion counseling.The head of the Pro-Life Caucus, State Representative Jerry Birmelin, a Republican from Pike County in the northeast corner of the state, says that while the governor might prefer that the funds issue not be on the legislative agenda at this point in the presidential campaign, the timing had nothing to do with him. ''Not my goal,'' Mr. Birmelin said the other day. ''It's not centered on him or anything he's doing.''
Theirs was a belated arrival, but the Philadelphia Phillies finally made an appearance in the 2000 season last week.Until they peeked out from their realm of repose, sort of like the groundhog on Feb. 2 in another Pennsylvania town, the Phillies seemed as if they might just take a pass on this season. Until they erupted for 14 runs and a second successive victory against Cincinnati, the Phillies had shown no evidence of life. Their vital signs were as comatose as their third-base coach's signs were unproductive.Theirs was a belated arrival, but the Philadelphia Phillies finally made an appearance in the 2000 season last week.Until they peeked out from their realm of repose, sort of like the groundhog on Feb. 2 in another Pennsylvania town, the Phillies seemed as if they might just take a pass on this season. Until they erupted for 14 runs and a second successive victory against Cincinnati, the Phillies had shown no evidence of life. Their vital signs were as comatose as their third-base coach's signs were unproductive.''We just haven't hit,'' General Manager Ed Wade was saying as the Phillies began their game against the Reds last Thursday.Wade was explaining his team's putrid first month. ''It's nothing more complicated than that,'' he said. ''Collectively, we've gotten off to a horrible start offensively. It's tough to win games when you're not scoring. Looking back at our club coming out of spring training, you wouldn't figure it was a team that couldn't score runs.''The night before, the Phillies defeated the Reds for only their third victory in the last 15 games, and they had raised the National League's lowest batting average by .003 to .230. But even after they erupted with a 21-hit barrage before Wade's eyes and sent the team average soaring to .242, they remained the league's lowest-scoring team.They also ended their series with the struggling Reds and began a three-game weekend series with the Atlanta Braves, whose lead over them, 11 games following the split of the first two games, is the largest margin in the major leagues. A groundhog couldn't have dug a deeper hole.''We can't go back and change a 7-17 April,'' Wade said. ''We realize what that means. We can't do anything about it. I think some people would like us to throw up our hands and surrender. But we don't do that. Our guys aren't made that way.''Players, however, tend to try to do too much when confronted with rampant adversity. A player in an 0-for-18 slump tries to get three hits in one at-bat. Teams distant from first place try to make up six games in one night.''I think it's been impressed upon them that we can't approach it that we're going to make up for 7-17 in four days,'' Wade said. ''We have to continue to play the game the right way and hopefully mount up more wins than losses. We need a couple teams in our division to slow down a little bit. I know they ran off a 15-game streak, but the Braves hopefully can't do that another time or two.''If the Phillies harbor thoughts of upending the Braves this season, they can put their efforts to better use, like trying to catch the Mets, who have had their own nightmarish experience since winning nine in a row, a streak that now seems a little less remote than ancient history.The Phillies played their first 23 games without Curt Schilling, their No. 1 pitcher and the soul of the team. Last season the Phillies resembled a wild-card contender until Schilling went on the disabled list with an ailing right shoulder.They were four games back in the wild-card race when Schilling pitched for the last time before going on the disabled list in August. When he returned nearly four weeks later in September, they trailed the Mets by 13 1/2 games.Returning last week following off-season shoulder surgery, Schilling, who last night pitched an 11-hit shutout against the Braves, is viewed as a catalyst who can stir the team. Wade sees that possibility, but he expressed a cautionary note.''People are trying to link our problems in the latter stages of last season with the problems at the beginning of this season,'' the general manager said. ''I think they're unrelated.''Not even Schilling has repeatedly won games in which the Phillies scored no more than three or four runs, an offensive development that occurred in 19 of the first 25 games. With basically the same hitters last season, the Phillies finished in the top half-dozen teams offensively.But they went to Atlanta last in total bases and only one home run ahead of the lowest home run total. They had been last in home runs before Mike Lieberthal and Rob Ducey connected against the Reds on Thursday for the team's first home runs in six games.Last season, Lieberthal, Doug Glanville, Bobby Abreu and Alex Arias were the team's .300 hitters. Right now only Abreu is on that level. A five-hit game Thursday raised Glanville's average by 34 points to .284; it's now .286. Lieberthal is up to .275. Arias is hitting .088. Others not contributing offensively included Ron Gant (.231), Desi Relaford (.213) and Kevin Jordan (.159).''We feel good and continue to feel good about our lineup,'' Wade said. ''The best alternative we have right now is to be patient. The wolves at this point have a lot of suggestions about knee-jerk reactions we should be having. But you can't make decisions based on knee-jerk reactions. The dumbest thing we could do is be impatient and make moves based on what has happened.''Expos' Express StallsThe Montreal Expos seemed to be off to a promising season. Then they arrived in Colorado. The Expos, with a 14-9 record, should have been suspicious; the Rockies had just scored 29 runs in a three-game series with the Mets, even though they lost two of the games. But Colorado did not lose any of the three games with the Expos, amassing 43 runs and 55 hits.''It's not like you can't explain it,'' said Jim Beattie, the Expos' general manager, a witness to the series in Colorado. ''You can explain it. We just didn't pitch well. I don't know if we go in there and say we can't pitch here. We pitched up. We hung a lot of sliders, breaking balls, changeups. We didn't pitch inside well. Jeffrey Hammonds hit a grand slam on an 0-2 fastball. We just didn't locate fastballs. That has nothing to do with pitching in Denver or anywhere else. We made a lot of bad pitches. So it's explainable.''Indians Look to ReboundThe joke could be on the Indians. Frustrated by their failure to win a World Series, the Indians fired Manager Mike Hargrove and named Charlie Manuel, their hitting coach, to replace him. General Manager John Hart said the team needed a new voice in the dugout. The problem is that new voice may be lulling the Indians to sleep.Cleveland's five-time division champions are struggling through the kind of start they thought they left behind when they became a force in the American League six years ago. This season, however, matches the start they had in 1997.That April, they were not in first place for 17 successive days. Today marks the 17th successive day they have not been in first this season. Their record is 14-13, the same as it was three years ago. The Indians went on that season to fall two outs short of winning the World Series.'That's Business'At 22, Jermaine Dye played in the World Series for the Atlanta Braves. At 26, Dye is a star for the Kansas City Royals.''It doesn't matter what team I'm on, as long as I'm in the big leagues fulfilling a dream,'' Dye said. ''It would have been nice to play my whole career in Atlanta, but it didn't work out. Maybe someday I'll get a chance to go back there, but right now I'm happy where I am.''After hitting .281 as a Braves rookie in 1996, Dye figured to be with them for a while. The next year, he said, he had a good spring and prepared to settle in, especially after David Justice and Marquis Grissom were traded late in spring training. ''I thought I was going to be slotted in to play every day,'' Dye said. ''All of a sudden I got traded'' -- two days after the other trade.Dye said he did not know how to react to being traded for the first time, especially at such a young age. But, he added: ''I knew Kansas City wanted me and liked me a lot. I just needed to go over there, put on a new uniform and realize I'm on a new team.''Dye struggled his first two seasons with the Royals; in fact, he spent part of each season in the minor leagues. But last season he blossomed with a .294 batting average, 27 home runs and 119 runs batted in. That performance set him up for what he has done early this season.Entering yesterday's schedule, he led the American League in home runs (12), doubles (13), slugging percentage (.784), total bases (91) and extra-base hits (25). He was tied for second in hits (42), tied for sixth in runs scored (24), fourth in runs batted in (29) and fourth in hitting (.362).But he was not among the leaders in outfield assists, as he was last season when his 17 assists were tied for first. ''This year I don't have any,'' he said. ''This year guys aren't running on me.''The Power CompanyBefore batters hit 931 home runs this April, the most productive April for home runs was in the 1996 season. If this season proceeds like that one, the home run frequency is very likely to slow. That April produced 2.30 home runs a game, but the average for the entire season wound up at 2.18 a game. This April's average was 2.56.Big Deals, Small NumbersThe biggest moves the Cincinnati Reds made last winter were the acquisitions of Ken Griffey Jr. and Dante Bichette. A year earlier, they traded for Michael Tucker. Those three formed the Reds' starting outfield on opening day. Griffey is hitting .211, Bichette .222 and Tucker .162.Detroit did not figure on a .225 average for Juan Gonzalez when it traded for him and offered him a $140 million contract. But then Gabe Kapler, who went to Texas in the Gonzalez trade, is hitting .200. Reggie Sanders was traded to Atlanta and is hitting .139. Mark McLemore signed with Seattle as a free agent and has a .204 average.While Derek Bell floats in the high .300's for the Mets, Roger Cedeno is hitting .202 for Houston.Some other bad early averages of players who aren't new to their teams: Tony Clark, .155; Rey Ordonez, .179; Ray Lankford, .187; Homer Bush, .192; Jose Offerman, .198; Rickey Henderson, .203; Cliff Floyd, .203; and Eric Karros, .204.BASEBALL: NOTEBOOK
Fusaichi Pegasus, the $4 million colt named for the flying horse of mythology, came flying through the homestretch at Churchill Downs today to win the 126th Kentucky Derby by a length and a half over Aptitude and give further evidence that racing has a brilliant new star.The bay son of Mr. Prospector not only became the first favorite to win the Derby since Spectacular Bid did it 21 years ago, but he also did it with style, finesse and power. And he behaved professionally, avoiding the balkiness that had threatened his career both in races and workouts.Fusaichi Pegasus, the $4 million colt named for the flying horse of mythology, came flying through the homestretch at Churchill Downs today to win the 126th Kentucky Derby by a length and a half over Aptitude and give further evidence that racing has a brilliant new star.The bay son of Mr. Prospector not only became the first favorite to win the Derby since Spectacular Bid did it 21 years ago, but he also did it with style, finesse and power. And he behaved professionally, avoiding the balkiness that had threatened his career both in races and workouts.His jockey, Kent Desormeaux, left his whip at his side and let the horse render one more virtuoso performance. And Fusaichi Pegasus glowed through this one, moving relentlessly from 15th place in the pack of 19 on the first turn until he bolted into the lead as they turned for home. He shifted inside to save ground, then shot to the outside to get into the clear, while 153,204 spectators at Churchill Downs, the second-largest crowd in Derby history, roared in wonder.''When the rail opened,'' said his English trainer, Neil Drysdale, ''he took flight. Then he had to wait for his chance to go outside, and he did. He's a very talented horse.''Drysdale, who missed his one previous chance to win the Derby in 1992 when the second favorite, A. P. Indy, was scratched with a bruised foot on the morning of the race, completed a week of high success.He was elected to racing's Hall of Fame on Tuesday, and won America's most prestigious race four days later, following the exact path taken last year by the trainer D. Wayne Lukas.The man who paid the $4 million to buy the horse as a yearling, Fusao Sekiguchi, a 65-year-old venture capitalist from Tokyo, said through an interpreter, ''When I laid eyes on this colt, I knew he was going to be a Derby winner.''Then, looking ahead to the Preakness in two weeks and the Belmont Stakes three weeks later, he said, ''As an owner, yes, I would like to challenge for the Triple Crown.''Desormeaux, who won the Derby two years ago aboard Real Quiet, gave an emotional tribute to ''a brilliant horse,'' and said with enthusiasm: ''When Mr. Sekiguchi put his money on him, he was just a pretty horse. But this pretty horse can run.'' Then, with poetic flair, the jockey added: ''He floated around there, and we became one.''Fusaichi Pegasus ran the mile and a quarter in 2:01 for the sixth-fastest time in Derby history, and he had to turn on the heat against a cast of exceptional rivals. Aptitude, who ran third behind Fusaichi Pegasus in the Wood Memorial in New York three weeks ago, finished strongly for second place, four lengths in front of Impeachment, with More Than Ready fourth. Drysdale's other entry, War Chant, never threatened and finished ninth.The winner, who has now won five of six races, crushed the dreams of a full cast of dreamers who made the Derby a storybook scenario.Jenine Sahadi failed to become the first female trainer to win the Derby when The Deputy, winner of the Santa Anita Derby, never fired and finished 14th.''He did his best,'' she said. ''He didn't have any real trouble. He just didn't fire.''Todd Pletcher, entering his first Derby with four horses, saw them finish third (Impeachment), fourth (More Than Ready), 11th (Trippi) and dead last (Graeme Hall). But the 32-year-old onetime assistant to Lukas remained positive, saying:''We showed we belonged here. When More Than Ready cut the corner into the stretch, my heart started pumping. The distance may have been just a little far for More Than Ready. Not as much as everyone said, but a little far. Impeachment is a late bloomer. He was beginning to show interest in the stretch. He bulled his way down the rail and closed a ton of ground. All in all, it was a pretty good day.''But it was a day of mixed emotions for the sentimental star of this year's class of 3-year-olds, Hal's Hope, the winner of the Florida Derby, and his 88-year-old breeder, owner and trainer, Harold Rose. The rags-to-riches colt led the field with his front-running speed for half a mile in 454/5  seconds, three-quarters in 1:094/5  and one mile in 1:353/5 . But then he tired and dropped back, fading to 16th place and puncturing his owner's hope.''When I saw the fractions, I got nervous,'' Rose said. ''You just can't go that fast. I did think he would run a little better, but he just went too fast too early. I guess we go back home with him. I don't know what's next right now.''Then there was Wheelaway, who sprang into prominence when he won the Tampa Bay Derby in March and finished third behind High Yield in the Blue Grass. He made a run from eighth after half a mile, then gradually moved to sixth after three-quarters of a mile, fifth after one mile and third entering the stretch. But he was overrun by the closers, and finished fifth.''I just collared Captain Steve and thought at the three-sixteenths pole that I'm the winner of the Kentucky Derby,'' the jockey Richard Migliore said. ''I hit him to ask for a little more, and he went inside and slowed me up. But it was the biggest rush I ever had.''Another story line centered on two colts from the Middle Eastern emirate of Dubai: China Visit, who finished sixth, and Curule, who ran seventh. They were regarded with some suspicion by many racing analysts because they had only six races between them, all but one of them in Dubai, where the Maktoum family expressed determination to extend its racing empire. They didn't, but both horses ran strong races and perhaps moved Sheik Mohammed al-Maktoum and his brothers closer to their goals.The trainer Bobby Frankel, gratified that Aptitude ran second to the favorite after running third in the Wood, said: ''He ran great, but he just got outrun. We're going to the Belmont, but we're not going to the Preakness.''Lukas, who has entered 38 horses in the Derby in 20 years and won with four of them, watched with dismay while his three starters struck out: Exchange Rate ran 12th, High Yield 15th and Commendable 17th. And High Yield had run in the money in 11 of his 12 starts.''They ran flat for whatever reason,'' he said. ''You know, there is always an explanation of some kind. We've been there before. I was disappointed in all three of them because all trained so well for the race. But you know, it's a horse race, and sometimes it's unexplainable.''But to Desormeaux, the Kentucky Derby was very explainable.''Once we straightened away and I got him in the clear,'' the winning jockey said, ''I kissed at him and asked him to run, and he accelerated. And it was over at that point. He took off like the best horse I've been involved with at this stage of the game.''FINISH LINESSaturday's telecast of the Kentucky Derby marked the end of a long run for ABC, which had been the Triple Crown network for many years. Next year the Derby will move to NBC as part of a five-year Triple Crown package. Race officials hope the switch will provide more promotion and exposure for the Derby, which has had declining ratings. The Derby, however, falls in the middle of the National Basketball Association playoffs, which NBC also televises. When they failed to support him, he picked up a loss.The Boston Red Sox ace matched a career-high with 17 strikeouts yesterday, but was outdueled by Steve Trachsel, who pitched a three-hit shutout to lead the Tampa Bay Devil Rays to a 1-0 victory.When Pedro Martinez tried to support his teammates, he got suspended. When they failed to support him, he picked up a loss.The Boston Red Sox ace matched a career-high with 17 strikeouts yesterday, but was outdueled by Steve Trachsel, who pitched a three-hit shutout to lead the Tampa Bay Devil Rays to a 1-0 victory.''He goes out there and pitches that way, and we can't score one run to support him,'' Red Sox first baseman Brian Daubach said. ''I feel almost as bad as last year, when we lost in the playoffs.''The loss ended Martinez's 13-game winning streak, and he'll have an extra day to stew over it: The Red Sox announced in the ninth inning that he had withdrawn the appeal of his five-game suspension and will start serving it today. He is scheduled to pitch Friday, one day later than normal.''Probably the best thing to do is move on, put things behind us,'' Boston Manager Jimy Williams said. ''Go ahead and serve the five games and then pitch.''Martinez (5-1) fanned six batters through two innings and had 12 strikeouts after five. The 17 strikeouts were the most in the majors this season and matched Martinez's 17-strikeout one-hitter against the Yankees on Sept. 10.''When he took the mound, he decided he wasn't going to give an inch,'' said Trachsel (2-2), who walked three and struck out a career-high 11 for his third career shutout. ''I knew it was going to be a tough game.''Martinez struck out Miguel Cairo to start the eighth for No. 16, then Gerald Williams grounded out before Dave Martinez singled and stole second. Vaughn worked the count full before singling to center.Martinez was making his scheduled start despite receiving a five-game suspension on Wednesday, three days after he hit Cleveland's Roberto Alomar with a pitch. He was allowed to pitch pending the appeal.''He decided to do that because this allows him to take his regular turn Friday in Baltimore,'' said Dan Duquette, the Red Sox general manager. ''It's better for us that Pedro is focused on his next start rather than go through the process.''INDIANS 8, BLUE JAYS 6: Catcher Einar Diaz hit a go-ahead two-run single in the eighth inning and Cleveland ended its six-game losing streak.Diaz is hitting .447 (21 for 47) since replacing Sandy Alomar in the starting lineup. Alomar, who is on the 15-day disabled list with a strained right hamstring, could rejoin the Indians on Monday.Homer Bush's run-scoring double gave Toronto a 6-5 lead in the seventh, but the Indians rallied for two runs on Diaz's single. Toronto starter Chris Carpenter left after walking Jim Thome. Reliever Paul Quantrill then gave up a hit to Richie Sexson and walked Travis Fryman before Diaz singled to right.Quantrill (0-1) took the loss. EVENTSDevotionOn the occasion of the marriage of the Renaissance aristocrats Andrea Gualengo and Orsina d'Este in 1469, Taddeo Crivelli and Guglielmo Giraldi, the foremost manuscript illustrators of Ferrara, produced a prayer book. Sometimes whimsical, sometimes pious and moving, its illuminations on pages measuring only 4 1/4 by 3 1/8 inches combine the spirituality of the Middle Ages with Renaissance naturalism. Regarded as the greatest Italian manuscript in the J. Paul Getty Collection, the Gualenghi-d'Este Hours goes on view tomorrow at the Getty Center in Los Angeles as the focus of a new exhibition. Through July 30, ''The Gualenghi-d'Este Hours: Art and Devotion in Renaissance Ferrara'' includes related objects from the British Museum in London, the National Gallery in Washington and the Museo Civico of the Palazzo Schifanoia in Ferrara, Italy. Information: (310) 440-7300.EVENTSDevotionOn the occasion of the marriage of the Renaissance aristocrats Andrea Gualengo and Orsina d'Este in 1469, Taddeo Crivelli and Guglielmo Giraldi, the foremost manuscript illustrators of Ferrara, produced a prayer book. Certainly not the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington, where a 15-day festival of Irish arts begins on Saturday night at 8. ''Island: Arts From Ireland'' encompasses dance, music, film, drama, poetry, visual arts and readings. The gala opening concert, with the author Frank McCourt as host, focuses on the links among the music of Ireland, Scotland and the United States from the mid-19th century to the present. Featured performers include Mary Black, Elvis Costello, Emmylou Harris, Maighread and Triona Ni Dhomhnail, Ricky Skaggs and members of the Riverdance company.
