One great cultural divide in our nation's capital is between the ostensibly off-the-record white-tie Gridiron dinner, which has been roasting presidents for 115 years, and the star-studded, made-for-TV affair of the White House Correspondents Association.The Gridiron, run by 60 of the Washington newspaper elite, is steeped in a bipartisan tradition of good-humored satire; it ''singes but never burns.'' The much larger W.H.C.A. affair, which properly includes electronic media, has been known to get out of hand, not only in oratorical taste but in the hot-tickety competition of its follow-up parties.One great cultural divide in our nation's capital is between the ostensibly off-the-record white-tie Gridiron dinner, which has been roasting presidents for 115 years, and the star-studded, made-for-TV affair of the White House Correspondents Association.The Gridiron, run by 60 of the Washington newspaper elite, is steeped in a bipartisan tradition of good-humored satire; it ''singes but never burns.'' The much larger W.H.C.A. affair, which properly includes electronic media, has been known to get out of hand, not only in oratorical taste but in the hot-tickety competition of its follow-up parties.Though a few singers are pros, the pencil fogies of the Gridiron dress in outrageous costumes and put on an amateur-theatrical set of skits and songs. (In this, my rookie year as a member, I appeared in a bunny suit, grimly determined to demonstrate good-sportsmanship.) The W.H.C.A. features instead a performance by a celebrated emcee. At both dinners, the highlight is the response of the main satiric target, who is frequently the president or vice president.Here is where a difference in the cultural style of Washington audiences illustrates the difference between political wit and political humor.In olden times, roasted pols responded with witty speeches replete with self-deprecating ''in'' jokes, often written by Liz Carpenter or Paul Keyes, a Gridiron tradition continued this year as Democrat Bob Strauss showed how political wit could sting without overstepping. Sometimes an unexpected performance substituted for wit: Nixon and Agnew plonked out a duet on the piano, or Nancy Reagan stole the show with a song. This year, a quintet of women cabinet members, starring Janet Reno, stopped the show with ''Thank Heaven for Grown-Up Girls.''Inside-the-establishment stuff works because of the intimacy of a live performance directly in front of a usually adversarial audience. But broadcasting does not lend itself to inside-the-brainwaves wit; as the physicist Werner Heisenberg uncertainly theorized, the wide observation of the comic performance changes the stimulus to laughter.Consider the performances this year of Clinton and Gore. If you watched TV last week -- from interviews with emcee Jay Leno to televised excerpts released by the White House on news programs everywhere -- you saw highlights of the undeniably boffo show put on at the W.H.C.A. dinner by the president.Clinton stimulated sympathy for his pangs of departure with well-produced outside stuff. His production culminated in a filmed scene of an abandoned Clinton running after the campaigning first lady's car, holding up a bag and shouting ''You forgot your lunch!'' Thus did the White House effectively use the forum provided by the convulsed press to show the general public that the Clintons were adept at poking fun at themselves. The humor was broad and professional, in the sure-fire style of Lucy and Desi.By contrast (and both are Democrats, so this is a nonpartisan analysis), Gore at the Gridiron emulated a style perfected two generations ago by John Kennedy at a memorable Al Smith memorial dinner in New York. Hard to believe, but Gore, like J.F.K., played to the people in the room with an unexpectedly light touch, using lines attuned to his politically sensitive audience.Everyone present knew that Gore's greatest campaign vulnerability is his denial of prior knowledge about illegal fund-raising. Many in the audience were aware he had claimed to have been out of the room when his aides were discussing this; he had even suggested he may have been off to the john after drinking a lot of iced tea. Few accept this.So Gore reportedly stepped to the lectern and asked for a glass of iced tea. Small laugh. He took the glass and slowly drained it all the way to the bottom, as the tittering grew. Then he carefully returned the glass to the waiter and delivered the punch line: ''I can't stay long.''That went over as nicely suggestive but clean, topically pointed and disarmingly self-directed. Just as Clinton's ''You forgot your lunch!'' was designed to elicit a belly laugh from a national audience, Gore's ''I can't stay long'' was intended to induce a grudgingly appreciative chuckle from an opinion-molding audience.One was broadcast humor, the other political wit. That's the difference in responses at two press dinners that seem cultural worlds apart.
Gov. George W. Bush has never been considered much of a wordsmith. But bit by bit, he is developing a political dictionary all his own.For example, when Vice President Al Gore distorts the Texas governor's record and proposals, at least as Mr. Bush sees it, Mr. Gore is not ''lying,'' two syllables that never escape Mr. Bush's lips. Rather, Mr. Gore is behaving in a manner that is ''disappointing,'' four syllables that the governor much prefers and has begun to use ad nauseam.Gov. George W. Bush has never been considered much of a wordsmith. But bit by bit, he is developing a political dictionary all his own.For example, when Vice President Al Gore distorts the Texas governor's record and proposals, at least as Mr. Bush sees it, Mr. Gore is not ''lying,'' two syllables that never escape Mr. Bush's lips. Rather, Mr. Gore is behaving in a manner that is ''disappointing,'' four syllables that the governor much prefers and has begun to use ad nauseam.And while Mr. Bush, the de facto Republican presidential nominee, says that he will soon identify numerous ways in which the government can save money, none of these plans will be ''cuts,'' a four-letter word that the candidate avoids. They will be ''savings'' that make the government more ''efficient'' -- kinder, gentler terms.It is a name game all the more interesting for the fact that Mr. Bush, with little smiles and wiggles of his eyebrows, wholly acknowledges that he is playing it. And this unspoken but unmistakable admission has precipitated endless rounds of semantic jousting between Mr. Bush and reporters, who are constantly trying to get him to say what he clearly means.On his campaign plane on Wednesday, as he flew from Austin to Palm Springs, Calif., he said the vice president was demonstrating a predilection to ''stretch the truth.''Was that not the same as lying?''I'm just disappointed,'' Mr. Bush said, with a ''nice-try'' twinkle and grin. ''I think that's the word I'd like to use. It's a disappointing thing.''Mr. Bush, a savvy enough candidate, understands that in politics, diction establishes tone, and tone is everything. And he turns to euphemisms to resolve inherent tensions in his campaign, like his pledge to run a positive race and his simultaneous resolve to wage an aggressive fight that exposes what he believes to be Mr. Gore's shortcomings.He did the same thing in the primaries, watering down the nouns and verbs he used to describe and disparage his principal opponent, Senator John McCain of Arizona. Mr. Bush's mantra at the time was that Mr. McCain ''says one thing and does another.''Did that not make the Arizona senator a ''hypocrite''?Mr. Bush flinched at the mere suggestion. No, he said, it made the senator a man practiced in the ways of ''Washington,'' a word that was perhaps dirtier but much less explicitly mean-spirited.Support From Far AwayThroughout the Republican primaries, the Bush campaign trumpeted seemingly any and every endorsement, whether it came from the governor of a large state or the secretary of a small sewing circle.But last week, the Bush campaign took that tendency to the outer limits.Mr. Bush showed reporters in the back of his campaign plane a recent copy of Weekly World News, a supermarket tabloid, with a cover story on the extraterrestrial support he was receiving. The front page featured a photograph of the governor standing beside an oblong, hairless, vaguely reptilian space alien.This was not to be taken lightly. As the newspaper noted, the same intergalactic kingmaker had backed Bill Clinton when he was first elected president in 1992.And as Mr. Bush noted, his alien encounter was further proof of his commitment to expanding the Republican Party's appeal.''New faces, new voices,'' he said as he held the front page high. ''It goes to show I'm willing to reach across certain demographic lines.''Earthier ExchangesThe exchange also went to show what a prankster and funnyman Mr. Bush fancies himself, a persona on vivid display last week.Mr. Gore was hurling accusations and put-downs in the governor's direction, and Mr. Bush was laughing, establishing a contrast that may not have been accidental in the least.His humor was broad. Asked by reporters during an airborne news conference one afternoon if he would be giving a lengthy stump speech at the airport in Palm Springs, he blanched.''Not outdoors!'' he gasped, alluding to the desert heat and one of its less attractive effects on the human body. He tugged at the portion of his dress shirt covering his underarms.  ''Pit city,'' he said.He recalled his exodus from Washington the week before, after several campaign stops there, and how one local man reacted to the passing of yet another motorcade by pulling down his pants.But Mr. Bush said the man was really ''mooning authority.''The governor seemed a bit less sanguine when the topic turned to a profile, in a major magazine, of the campaign's chief strategist, Karl Rove. Mr. Bush has a thing about advisers eclipsing the candidates they serve.And he jokingly wondered what he should expect next: a Playgirl magazine pictorial of his campaign manager, Joe Allbaugh? Mr. Allbaugh is older and burlier than a typical centerfold, but Mr. Bush had a vision.''I'm going to have him wear a bikini bathing suit,'' he said.
The latest numbers offered a stunning contradiction: a 3.9 percent unemployment rate, the lowest in 30 years, and two major national polls showing Gov. George W. Bush of Texas leading Vice President Al Gore by 5 percentage points.To put that contrast in perspective, the last time a president's party lost the White House in good times was 1920. And even then, the country was recovering from the double-digit inflation of World War I.The latest numbers offered a stunning contradiction: a 3.9 percent unemployment rate, the lowest in 30 years, and two major national polls showing Gov. George W. Bush of Texas leading Vice President Al Gore by 5 percentage points.To put that contrast in perspective, the last time a president's party lost the White House in good times was 1920. And even then, the country was recovering from the double-digit inflation of World War I.So why isn't the booming economy blowing Mr. Bush away? Have the rules changed?Perhaps.First, the economy has stayed strong so long that most people are not worrying about it. Peter D. Hart, a Democratic pollster, said, ''It doesn't sit there as a major worry that people talk about.'' Robert Teeter, a Republican pollster who collaborates with Mr. Hart on the NBC News/ Wall Street Journal poll, said one reason for Bush support among older people was that ''only about 6 percent of the old people have economic worries.''Second, Mr. Gore does not get credit for the way things are. Polls show the public gives it to President Clinton and Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board.That may be reasonable enough, but Mr. Gore's own weakness as a candidate compounds that problem. After all, Mr. Gore is campaigning on a promise to keep the same economic policies Mr. Clinton has followed, while Mr. Bush's central campaign message is that he wants a very big tax cut.But the NBC/Journal poll showed that only 27 percent of voters thought Mr. Gore was very likely or fairly likely to pursue policies that would keep the economy strong, compared to 32 percent who said that of Mr. Bush. (Both of them enjoyed less credence than they did in December, when 36 percent had confidence in Mr. Gore and 43 percent in Mr. Bush.)The NBC/Journal poll had Mr. Bush ahead, 46 percent to 41 percent. A Gallup Poll for CNN and USA Today had the Bush lead at 49 to 44. Both polls were taken the last weekend of April, and the margin of sampling error for the NBC/Journal survey was plus or minus three percentage points, one less than for the Gallup Poll.Mr. Gore has simply not capitalized on winning his party's nomination more easily than Mr. Bush won his or achieving quickly the party unity and support from Bill Bradley that Mr. Bush is still seeking from Senator John McCain.Mr. Teeter said the data in the NBC/Journal poll explained it. ''Gore is not a very good candidate,'' he said. ''He is not a very likable candidate.'' Mr. Teeter argued that Mr. Gore's frequent attacks on Mr. Bush ran the risk ''of looking like the guy who is out of his time,'' out of step with an optimistic country.Though Mr. Teeter agreed that a strong economy was a major factor in retaining a president or his party, he said the most ''likable'' candidate had won most postwar elections. The clearest exception was 1968, when a losing war, civic turmoil and rising inflation helped Richard M. Nixon edge out Hubert H. Humphrey. In 1976, Mr. Teeter said, both Jimmy Carter and President Gerald Ford seemed likable.Still, these are early days. When the nomination contests ended in March, public interest in the campaign plummeted, and surveys by the Vanishing Voter project of the Joan Shorenstein Center on the Press, Politics and Public Policy at Harvard University show that knowledge about the candidates has also declined.There is no question that the Gore message in the summer and fall will emphasize continuity and accuse Mr. Bush of risking prosperity for a needless tax cut. Comparisons with the last Republican administration are inevitable, but will have special bite because the phrase ''Bush recession'' will surely be used.Mr. Hart, while conceding Mr. Gore's weak standing, cited a focus group he conducted last Tuesday in a Philadelphia suburb as offering hope for Mr. Gore. Everyone in the group of 12, whether he or she favored Mr. Bush or Mr. Gore, ''wanted the same policies,'' he said. ''They didn't want to tinker with the economy.''''Al Gore is sitting on a gusher,'' Mr. Hart said, if he can find a way to identify himself with the voters' desire for continuity.The best evidence that it is not too late for Mr. Gore comes from a New York Times/CBS News Poll taken in May 1988. That was the last time a vice president ran to succeed a popular president in an economic boom. Gov. Michael S. Dukakis led Vice President George Bush, 49 percent to 39 percent. It did not last.
This was the year that the hip-hop singer with a dragon tattoo stole the spotlight from the folk dancers.He called himself Double O, and he strutted in a black tank top across the stage at yesterday's Asian Pacific American Heritage Festival, his left arm emblazoned with a blue dragon. As a deep bass pounded across Union Square Park, he ripped into rhyme. ''I'm what you want, what you need,'' he sang. ''Oh baby, please come home with me.''This was the year that the hip-hop singer with a dragon tattoo stole the spotlight from the folk dancers.He called himself Double O, and he strutted in a black tank top across the stage at yesterday's Asian Pacific American Heritage Festival, his left arm emblazoned with a blue dragon. As a deep bass pounded across Union Square Park, he ripped into rhyme. ''I'm what you want, what you need,'' he sang. ''Oh baby, please come home with me.''''It's like the Asian urban outlet that was never exposed before,'' he said to a reporter as he kissed a female fan after the show. ''I think we're on the tip of the iceberg. I think it's going much farther.''In recent years, acts like Double O have gradually taken center stage at the 21-year-old festival, edging out more traditional fare like Korean folk drumming and Malaysian dancing. Chalk it up to younger organizers taking over the programming and a younger audience attending  the event. Since 1997, organizers said, more professionals in their 20's have dropped by, more companies focusing on that market have paid for banners and booths and more contemporary performers have been brought in.The changes mirror larger trends in certain segments of New York's Asian-American community -- namely, the growing visibility of young Asian-American professionals in what is considered mainstream culture, and the emergence of popular art forms that voice their sensibilities.Many of the thousands who attended yesterday's festival came with cell phones, sunglasses and slick hair, and they were less interested in the martial arts demonstrations than in the erotically charged lyrics of Double O.''We want to make sure the general audience and our community see a reflection of what we are today,'' said Chuck N. Lee, one of the festival organizers. ''That's why we have the contemporary stuff.''The festival was started in 1979 by the Coalition of Asian Pacific Americans when President Jimmy Carter designated Asian-American Heritage Week. (President George Bush later expanded the designation to encompass the month of May). For many years, it drew several hundred people, most of whom had ties to the 30 or so nonprofit groups that set up booths. These included organizations like the Chinatown Health Clinic and the Basement Workshop, an arts collective.Most of the festival financing came from state grants, fund-raisers and rents for the booths. But since the late 1980's, corporate sponsorship has become increasingly common. That backing has only intensified in recent years, especially as many companies have become aware that Asian-Americans have the highest average household income of any ethnic group in the nation -- $46,637 in 1998, according to the United States Census Bureau.Although nonprofit groups still dominated the 100 or so booths yesterday, many business executives said events like the festival provided convenient access to the Asian-American market, which is otherwise not easily reached. There are virtually no magazines or television shows that cater specifically to it, unlike for the African-American or Hispanic population.''We want to show support for the event, to help fund it and bring in artists,'' said Betty Huang, marketing director of Community Connect, which operates a Web site called Asianavenue.com. ''On the other side, it's a good way for us to get our name out there.''And those coming to the festival are increasingly younger, and more  have full-time professional jobs that are not associated with the nonprofit groups, said Ramon Gil, president of the group running the festival.Scholars say this change reflects a general demographic shift in the last decade or so within many Asian-American communities. Immigration laws passed in 1965 have resulted in more white-collar immigrants entering the country and an entire generation of children growing up in the United States in the 1980's and entering the workplace.But the increasing commercial presence at the festival has raised concerns among some people who worry that corporations may overshadow the work of nonprofit groups.And when the visibility of the professional Asian-American class increases in mainstream culture, the awareness of working class immigrants and their problems can get lost, said Robert Ku, a professor of English and of Asian-American Studies at Hunter College.But festival organizers said they had been careful to keep the event grounded in its original purpose. For instance, career-oriented groups at the festival, like the National Association of Asian-American Professionals, often run mentoring programs to help recent immigrants or students.Besides drawing a larger corporate presence, the festival's younger organizers and audience have also led to a significant shift in the entertainment lineup this year. Organizers said this was the first year that contemporary pop singers outnumbered musicians specializing in traditional Asian styles.''I think it will be encouraging for people to see that there are Asian Pacific Americans performing this nontraditional and unusual path,'' said Toni Wang, a 28-year-old aspiring diva who belted out R&B-inspired lyrics on the main stage.''She's not bad,'' said Marc Wong, 32, a computer technician at Goldman Sachs, as Ms. Wang began her third song. ''Then there was that guy Double O. He didn't sound like a typical Asian-immigrant-family type of kid. He was obviously a guy who had soaked himself in a particular kind of American culture.''
Gov. George E. Pataki, hoping to keep his political choices open, has continued to raise money through two political action committees that he set up outside New York to enhance his national profile.The stated purpose of those committees, which bear the name ''21st Century Freedom,'' is to help Republican candidates around the country who share his views. But campaign records show that most of the total of $892,573 raised so far has been used to benefit Mr. Pataki by building new political alliances and subsidizing an increasingly expensive political apparatus that helped him win two terms as governor.Gov. George E. Pataki, hoping to keep his political choices open, has continued to raise money through two political action committees that he set up outside New York to enhance his national profile.The stated purpose of those committees, which bear the name ''21st Century Freedom,'' is to help Republican candidates around the country who share his views. But campaign records show that most of the total of $892,573 raised so far has been used to benefit Mr. Pataki by building new political alliances and subsidizing an increasingly expensive political apparatus that helped him win two terms as governor.The out-of-state PAC's -- one was formed under federal law, and the other in Virginia, where there are no limits on contribution amounts -- have channeled $67,433 to state and federal races outside New York. Yet they have paid at least $126,944 to Mr. Pataki's longtime pollster, Arthur Finkelstein; $118,046 to his political consultants, Kieran Mahoney and Adam Stoll; and $190,653 to a half-dozen campaign aides who are or have been on his payroll for years.Other money has been used to hire prominent Republican consultants who could help Mr. Pataki in a future run for national office. For instance, Benjamin L. Ginsberg, an elections specialist at the Washington law firm of Patton Boggs, whose clients include Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, billed $7,264 in legal fees as recently as March. Stephen Moore, an economist with the Cato Institute in Washington, received $27,500 for fine-tuning Mr. Pataki's fiscal proposals, while Peggy Noonan, a speechwriter for Presidents George Bush and Ronald Reagan, was paid $10,000 to polish his words.The money figures are the latest the committees had available. In the case of the Virginia PAC, they cover all of calendar 1999; the federal PAC's figures cover the period from January 1999 to March 31, 2000.Although Mr. Pataki has not revealed his political plans, it is clear that he commands substantial resources that could be mobilized on short notice. In the last week, politicians and lobbyists have speculated that Mr. Pataki may do just that to run for the Senate against Hillary Rodham Clinton if the probable Republican candidate, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, is forced to drop out because of his prostate cancer.Mr. Pataki, the most successful political fund-raiser in the state's history, has brought in a total of more than $3.2 million in contributions since January 1999, including $2.4 million through his main campaign fund, Friends of Pataki, which is based in New York.He has already spent more than two-thirds of that money -- mainly on political consultants, salaries for his full-time campaign staff members, travel and fund-raising expenses -- even though he does not face re-election until 2002.''It's a complete change in culture,'' said Assemblyman Richard L. Brodsky, a Democrat from Westchester County who has criticized Mr. Pataki and Republican leaders for their aggressive fund-raising practices. ''There is no election cycle anymore; it's flat-out fund-raising from the inauguration to the next election.''Zenia Mucha, chief political adviser to Mr. Pataki, said money from all three committees had enabled the governor to travel around the country and build support for the party. ''The governor feels very strongly about promoting the Republican agenda of smaller, more effective and efficient government, lower taxes, individual freedom and other issues that are part of it,'' she said. ''We have and will continue to use these PAC's to disseminate and promote that message.''Many lobbyists and other regular contributors complain that they are paying heavily for Mr. Pataki's growing political activities. They say privately that Mr. Pataki's campaign aides have aggressively encouraged them to send donations to the Virginia or federal PAC's as a way to skirt New York's contribution limits.''Now they call and ask us to make out two or three checks instead of one,'' said a lobbyist who had given several thousand dollars to Mr. Pataki's committees but spoke on condition of anonymity because the issue had become so sensitive.Under New York election law, a corporation's contributions to all candidates and committees is limited to $5,000 a year. The law also limits an individual's donation to a governor's general election campaign to $30,700 over the four years of his term. But several corporations and individual donors would have exceeded those limits if their donations to all the committees were tallied up.Bell Atlantic, one of the state's largest employers, contributed $50,000 to the Virginia committee -- 10 times the corporate limit in New York -- in addition to $50,500 in largely unregulated soft money to the Republican Party's housekeeping committee. Although Mr. Pataki's PAC is separate from the Republican committees, they often transfer money back and forth.A real estate developer, Peter S. Kalikow, contributed $25,000 to the Virginia PAC and $12,500 to Friends of Pataki, a total of $37,500, which is more than the state's limit for individual donors. He also directed $12,500 to the Republican state committee, and his company, H. J. Kalikow, gave $5,000 to the state committee.The Virginia PAC collected $291,400, or more than half its total contributions, from New York businesses, residents and other political committees. The federal PAC, which is barred from accepting corporate donations and limits individuals to $5,000, still raised $356,073 including $138,375 from New Yorkers.Blair Horner, legislative director for the New York Public Interest Research Group, said Mr. Pataki's multiple committees had made a sham of the state's campaign finance laws. ''It essentially means there are no campaign contribution limits for governor,'' he said. ''Those who are seeking to curry favor can give as much as they want.''Ms. Mucha rejected such criticism. ''This gives us the ability under the law -- which, the last time I looked, both parties were doing -- to go out to other states and other arenas and talk about the governor's successful record in New York and the principles of the Republican Party,'' she said.To some extent, Mr. Pataki's out-of-state committees have helped finance Republican aspirations in other parts of the country. The Virginia PAC contributed $28,000 to 12 Republican candidates running for the State Legislature in New Jersey, and $28,100 to 8 Republican candidates in Virginia. The federal PAC contributed $11,333 to 11 Republicans from Vermont to Arizona who are running for federal office.But campaign records show that most of the money has been used to further Mr. Pataki's own political interests. There was little real difference in how the money was spent from the three committees -- indeed, the same political consultants drew regular payments from each one.
For months, Jim Florio has been daring Jon S. Corzine, his opponent in the Democratic primary for the Senate, to meet him in a debate. And Mr. Corzine, whose many assets do not include a gift for the sound bite, has responded as though Mr. Florio were offering to buy him a drink of hemlock: no thanks. Maybe later.Later has arrived.For months, Jim Florio has been daring Jon S. Corzine, his opponent in the Democratic primary for the Senate, to meet him in a debate. And Mr. Corzine, whose many assets do not include a gift for the sound bite, has responded as though Mr. Florio were offering to buy him a drink of hemlock: no thanks. Maybe later.Later has arrived.Until now, the New Jersey Senate contest has largely consisted of Mr. Corzine's demonizing the former governor in expensive television commercials, and Mr. Florio's indicting Mr. Corzine's Wall Street background in the newspapers, while the four all-but-unknown Republicans have been all but invisible in the news media.But with the start of the debate season this week, the two Democrats will finally engage in direct give-and-take, and the Republicans may actually get some attention.To Mr. Florio, who has been denigrating Mr. Corzine's proposals as hopelessly naive, the initial Democratic encounter on Thursday will be the first opportunity to challenge Mr. Corzine on the costs of his ambitious plans for universal health care and free college tuition, or to quiz him on the workings of Washington, where Mr. Florio spent 15 years in the House of Representatives.Mr. Florio, whose wide early lead in the polls has been eroding, can be expected to draw as sharp a contrast as possible between himself and Mr. Corzine, the former co-chairman of Goldman, Sachs & Company; in recent speeches, he has said Democratic voters must choose between an amateur politician and a professional.To Mr. Corzine, who drew national attention not long ago when he admitted making insulting remarks about Italian-Americans, whose advisers have become inured to his mangling of applause lines, and who seems to shy away from the rough-and-tumble of confrontation, the four debates scheduled with the combative Mr. Florio will pose a crucial test of mettle and preparation.To voters, the debates promise the chance for some political theater after more than a year of mere previews, since Senator Frank R. Lautenberg announced that he would not seek another term. Both Mr. Florio and Mr. Corzine are said to be a bit thin-skinned, and the two have developed a barely concealed disdain for one another.The first debate, on Monday, will showcase the Republicans: Robert D. Franks, a four-term congressman from Union County; William L. Gormley, a veteran state senator from Margate, near Atlantic City; James W. Treffinger, the Essex County executive; and Murray Sabrin, a college finance professor.Both of this week's debates, which will be taped in Trenton, are being sponsored by The New York Times and the New Jersey Network, which will broadcast them statewide.In addition to a number of candidates' forums around the state, the Republicans will debate again on May 22 on the cable channel News 12, and then on May 26 on WPVI-TV, the ABC affiliate in Philadelphia. The primary is on June 6.Aides to each of the four Republicans said they expected that the debates would be watched by relatively small numbers of likely primary voters. Rick Shaftan, a consultant to Mr. Sabrin, said the ABC telecast, scheduled for the Memorial Day weekend, seemed ''designed to guarantee minimal viewership.''But he and others said that news coverage of the events could help stir interest in what is otherwise expected to be a low-turnout election.Clifford Zukin, a pollster and professor at Rutgers, said debates rarely decided elections anywhere but at the presidential level, although he said that they could change the tone of campaign news coverage. ''Suppose something happens: flubs, gaffes, insults, someone being skewered,'' he said. ''Local TV loves that kind of thing. If that happens, then there will be the indirect effect. Local news is the sleeping 800-pound gorilla.''On the Democratic side, Gerald M. Pomper, another political science professor at Rutgers, predicted that each candidate had as much to lose as to gain in the debates.''Everybody's strengths are also their weaknesses,'' he said. ''Florio will be very informed on all kinds of policy questions, but he may seem boring and arrogant. Corzine may be less informed, and may therefore look like more of a fresh face.''Mr. Corzine has been studying for the debates as if cramming for a final exam. Robert C. Janiszewski, the Hudson County executive, said he had played the role of Mr. Florio in about five practice sessions, with Robert Shrum, a media consultant, and Steven Goldstein, a co-manager of the campaign, also taking turns acting the former governor's part.Mr. Florio has held only one practice debate, his aides said.Despite all that practice, Mr. Corzine's advisers painted Mr. Florio as the heavy favorite. ''The strategic reason for Florio to want 400 debates is he knows he's the polished, professional politician and Jon's not,'' Mr. Janiszewski said. ''I think the public's gotten weary of that. But Florio's not thinking that way. Corzine just needs to be himself.''Other supporters of Mr. Corzine stressed that voters were electing a senator, not a semanticist or a specialist on the legislative process.''If depth of knowledge about government won elections, then both Jimmy Carter and Walter Mondale would've beaten Ronald Reagan,'' said Orin Kramer, an adviser to Mr. Corzine. ''And if political debating skills won elections, Michael S. Dukakis would've beaten George Bush, and Mario Cuomo would still be governor of New York.''Still, Mr. Florio's aides said that Mr. Corzine appeared to be hedging against a meltdown before the cameras. Mr. Corzine declined an invitation to a League of Women Voters debate that was to have been carried by the ABC-TV affiliates in New York and Philadelphia.Instead, after Thursday's debate on the New Jersey Network, there will be debates on May 15 on WLIB-AM (1190), which is the premier black talk radio station in Manhattan but has only about 75,000 listeners in New Jersey; on May 16 at a synagogue in Livingston, sponsored by the MetroWest Jewish Federation, which has not even sought a broadcast partner; and on May 18 on News 12, which is available in fewer than 60 percent of the state's households.''We have a great deal of respect for NJN and Channel 12, but their viewership is low,'' said Jim Lanard, a Florio spokesman. ''We can only conclude that the Corzine campaign has made a strategic decision to keep the candidate off the broadcast TV stations.''Mr. Goldstein, of the Corzine campaign, responded: ''This is like what Roseanne Roseannadanna said: if it's not one thing, it's another. First Jim Florio, who avoided debates throughout his career, moaned and groaned about Jon not debating him. Then Jon agreed to not one, not two, but four debates. We suggest Jim Florio take a chill pill.''

More than seven years after the broccoli-bashing presidency of George Bush, vegetables and fruit still have not caught on with the public, despite the health benefits.Fewer than one-fourth of Americans eat the five daily servings of fruit and vegetables recommended by federal health officials and the National Cancer Institute, a survey has found.More than seven years after the broccoli-bashing presidency of George Bush, vegetables and fruit still have not caught on with the public, despite the health benefits.Fewer than one-fourth of Americans eat the five daily servings of fruit and vegetables recommended by federal health officials and the National Cancer Institute, a survey has found.The report, published in a recent issue of The American Journal of Public Health, found that some progress had been made in the period studied, 1990 to 1996.In the first year, only 19 percent of Americans reported eating five servings a day; in the last, 22.7 percent did.But most of that improvement, the researchers said, took place before 1994, and a leveling off has since occurred.The survey, conducted in 16 states, involved telephone calls to up to 32,000 people a year. They were asked six questions, including how often they drank juice or ate fruit. They were also asked how often they ate potatoes (French fries and potato chips did not count).Those interviewed were also asked about exercise.The highest proportion of people who met the dietary recommendations were men and women 65 and older, whites, college graduates and people who exercised.''Although progress from 1990 to 1994 was encouraging,'' the report said, the survey suggested that further efforts were needed, especially among inactive and obese people.VITAL SIGNS: NUTRITION
Happy National Teacher Day! There's still time, people, to send your children's instructor a little remembrance -- a box of cookies, a nice book, some Microsoft stock you aren't using anymore. Meanwhile let's take a moment to discuss the ever-soaring state of Standards in Education.Obviously, Higher Standards require well-qualified teachers, and it is for this reason that 39 states have adopted basic skills tests for new faculty. Unfortunately, 36 of these states waive said test when they're short on staff, leaving a certain number of students in the hands of educators who have not necessarily proven their ability to name the days of the week.Happy National Teacher Day! There's still time, people, to send your children's instructor a little remembrance -- a box of cookies, a nice book, some Microsoft stock you aren't using anymore. Meanwhile let's take a moment to discuss the ever-soaring state of Standards in Education.Obviously, Higher Standards require well-qualified teachers, and it is for this reason that 39 states have adopted basic skills tests for new faculty. Unfortunately, 36 of these states waive said test when they're short on staff, leaving a certain number of students in the hands of educators who have not necessarily proven their ability to name the days of the week.Some of you may find it strange that individuals who cannot pass a basic skills test would go into teaching in the first place. Perhaps they were lured by the opportunity, offered in many overcrowded districts, to eat lunch at 10 o'clock in the morning. Perhaps they felt peculiarly suited to a career where salaries begin, on average, at $8,000 a year less than other professions and end, on average, at $24,000 less.Nevertheless, we have not seen so much political commitment to better schools since the 1988 campaign, when George Bush and Michael Dukakis each announced he intended to become the ''education president.'' The golden age of pedagogy that everyone expected to flow from this contest somehow failed to arrive. Now Al Gore and George W. Bush trade assault e-mail on the subject every single day. Mr. Bush cannot talk enough about the way he's improved the schools in Texas. He is particularly voluble about having ended social promotion, about how he insisted that no Texas child go from the third grade to the fourth until he or she could read at grade level.''It's important to have high standards,'' he told a county Republican gathering a while back, using a Bush ian gesture that indicates the height he had in mind was about five feet.In truth, the first kids who will ever be affected by that policy are currently in kindergarten. This is the classic political approach to the setting of standards on any topic. You want to be strict about the required levels of achievement, but loose about the timetable. The ideal due date, in fact, is the year after whoever sets the standards leaves office. If Mr. Bush is lucky, by the time Texas third graders start getting held back, he'll be in Washington preparing for his re-election campaign.Amazing the things you can accomplish with long-term projections. Residents here in New York have already been informed that come 2004, the state debt will suddenly shrink to manageable proportions and our high school seniors will be able to pass challenging tests in math, english, science, history and global studies in order to graduate.In the bad old days, New York reserved what we call Regents exams mainly for students who planned to go to college. But now we're going to test everybody -- the special ed students, the kids who arrived last week from Guatemala. And why not? Every child is important, and just because he or she is going to school in double shifts or studying science in a laboratory that was built when Teddy Roosevelt was a teen doesn't mean we don't care enough to demand the very best.None of this is necessarily as crazy as it seems. Some school officials seem to be setting themselves up for a standards debacle in hopes that when the great disaster finally occurs and kids start failing in droves, an outraged public will ante up the money for smaller classes, better-paid teachers, newer buildings, etc. The only problem with this theory is that a whole generation of students will wind up being used for cannon fodder.''Everybody's worried about the kids caught in the middle,'' says Abigail Thernstrom of the Massachusetts state board of education.To be fair to Mr. Bush, Texas is actually making an attempt to set the bar higher without whopping it over the heads of the children who happen to get caught in the transition. This year the teachers started getting additional training, and the students' skills are being tested regularly so those who start to fall behind can get special tutoring. A timetable that actually prepares kids for the standards they're supposed to meet is definitely not silly.Bragging about it as if anything has actually happened, however, is ridiculous.

The group says it is spending several thousand dollars to buy air time, but Republican officials assert that the amount is closer to $100,000.PRODUCER -- MacWilliams, Cosgrove, Smith, Robinson of Washington.ON THE SCREEN -- A still photo of Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, closing in tightly on his left eye. Cut to a shot in which a man is shown tucking a large silver pistol under his belt buckle. Scenes of a rustic church and children riding on a carousel dramatically break apart, like a smashed mirror, to reveal a grainy video clip of Kayne Robinson, first vice president of the National Rifle Association, talking emphatically to an audience of N.R.A. members. Concludes with a shot of the White House.THE SCRIPT -- Male announcer: ''George Bush says if you want to know what he'll do as president, take a look at his record.'' Female announcer: ''As governor of Texas, Bush signed the law that allows carrying concealed handguns for the first time in 125 years.'' Male announcer: ''And he signed the law that allows carrying those concealed handguns in churches, nursing homes, even amusement parks.'' Female announcer: ''No wonder the N.R.A. says'': (voice of Mr. Robinson) ''If we win, we'll have a president'' (here Mr. Robinson's words are spliced to bring two sentence fragments together) ''where we work out of their office.'' Female announcer: ''Tell Governor Bush: The White House is our house.'' Male announcer: ''And it shouldn't belong to the N.R.A.''ACCURACY -- It is true that Mr. Bush has often sided with the National Rifle Association in legislative battles in his more than five years as governor. Over the objections of gun control advocates, he signed legislation allowing people to carry concealed handguns, allowing handguns to be taken into churches and prohibiting local governments from suing gun manufacturers. The N.R.A.'s executive vice president, Wayne LaPierre, also recently helped raise at least $250,000 at a major Republican Party fund-raiser honoring Mr. Bush. But Mr. Bush has at times tried to distance himself from the organization, by supporting mandatory trigger locks for new handguns and criticizing Mr. LaPierre for asserting that President Clinton had tolerated a certain level of gun violence for political reasons.SCORECARD -- By trying to depict Mr. Bush as a pawn of the N.R.A., the advertisement seeks to make him seem like an extremist on gun control issues, because the N.R.A. is widely perceived as intransigently opposed to any restrictions on gun ownership. Also, it suggests that the governor is not his own man, that he is beholden to powerful right-wing interest groups. The advertisement is not being shown widely enough to affect many voters directly, but Handgun Control is clearly hoping that journalists in Washington and Texas will use it to write critical stories about Mr. Bush. The group is also running the spot in several cities with hotly contested Congressional races in which gun control may become an important issue, including Lansing and Columbus.James DaoTHE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE AD CAMPAIGN
The latest polls show George W. Bush just a whisker ahead of Al Gore in overall voter approval ratings. But when asked about environmental protection, voters give Mr. Gore a double-digit advantage over Mr. Bush. Mr. Gore has begun to exploit this edge; in a speech last month, for example, he said Mr. Bush was only ''pretending to care'' about the environment.Other critics have attacked Mr. Bush's record, too, brandishing air quality statistics, which show that Texas ranks worst among states in total tons of air pollution.The latest polls show George W. Bush just a whisker ahead of Al Gore in overall voter approval ratings. But when asked about environmental protection, voters give Mr. Gore a double-digit advantage over Mr. Bush. Mr. Gore has begun to exploit this edge; in a speech last month, for example, he said Mr. Bush was only ''pretending to care'' about the environment.Other critics have attacked Mr. Bush's record, too, brandishing air quality statistics, which show that Texas ranks worst among states in total tons of air pollution.But as it turns out, the Texas governor's record is far better than activists allow. Governor Bush has tackled environmental problems creatively, with a new approach that emphasizes cooperation over conflict.Let's look at air quality. There are two reason why emissions in Texas are high. First, the state is large and produces much of the nation's oil and oil-based chemicals. The rest of the country enjoys the goods made possible by this production; Texas shoulders the burden.Second, Governor Bush's predecessors paid relatively little attention to air quality. Mr. Bush backed an initiative that made Texas only the third state in the nation to require pollution reductions from older power plants that had been exempted from the standards set for more modern ones. By 2003, the Bush plan aims to cut nitrogen oxide emissions, a component of smog, in half. The program included some voluntary commitments by companies, as well as requirements.This program represents a new environmentalism, which recognizes that most people and most companies want to do the right thing, and encourages them to do so through incentives.Governor Bush also expanded the ''clean industries 2000'' program, which was started in 1992 by Gov. Ann Richards. To participate, companies committed to cutting their toxic or hazardous waste in half by this year; in exchange, they may display a special environmental logo. So far, 185 companies have together eliminated more than 43 million tons of hazardous waste and reduced energy consumption by 11.3 million kilowatt hours. Through this and other programs, Texas actually led the nation in reducing toxic releases in 1997, the most recent year for which figures have been reported.During the governor's tenure, Texas has also encouraged voluntary conservation efforts. Starting with a budget of $100,000, and climbing this year to $2.5 million, a landowner incentive program is the first government plan in the country to pay qualified landowners up to $10,000 to help conserve rare species on their property. By using incentives, it has managed to do what the federal Endangered Species Act has not done -- inspire landowners to voluntarily make their land attractive to threatened animal species.Another conservation effort has helped farmers and ranchers develop plans for helping wildlife survive on  some 10 million acres. On state lands, Mr. Bush led in the creation of a privately financed endowment, bolstered by state appropriations, to restore and maintain every state park, wildlife area and fish hatchery.Some environmental groups don't like Mr. Bush's approach, which emphasizes incentives and voluntary agreements. But what matters are  results. Are pollutants being reduced? Is habitat being protected? Are old hazardous-waste sites getting cleaned up? On this score, Governor Bush's performance looks surprisingly good.Lynn Scarlett is executive director of the Reason Public Policy Institute.
As the Congressional vote on permanent normalized trade relations for China draws closer, Vice President Al Gore is stepping up his activities to promote it.As the Congressional vote on permanent normalized trade relations for China draws closer, Vice President Al Gore is stepping up his activities to promote it.He spoke more forcefully yesterday for the agreement than he usually does. And today he plans to attend a White House meeting with President Clinton and former Presidents Gerald Ford and Jimmy Carter, among others, to lobby for the measure, which Congress is to vote on later this month.Mr. Gore has been tepid in his support so far for the agreement, largely because organized labor, which backs him, opposes it. But speaking up for it serves Mr. Gore's political purposes now by helping to counter the impression, reinforced during the controversy over Elian Gonzalez, that he does not take principled stands and instead panders to those whose support he seeks.At the annual meeting of Associated Press publishers and editors yesterday in New York, Mr. Gore did not raise the China issue, but was asked about it in a question-and-answer session. Uncharacteristically, he delved into the reasons he believed the trade bill should pass; normally, when he mentions the issue at all, he gives it fairly short shrift.''This doesn't reduce any U.S. tariffs; it only reduces Chinese tariffs,'' he said at the Associated Press meeting, which was held at St. Bartholomew's Church in Midtown Manhattan.''If we turned it down,'' he added, referring to the World Trade Organization, ''it wouldn't keep China from coming into the W.T.O.; China would come into the W.T.O. anyway.''Failing to approve the trade agreement, he said, would not hurt China but would put the United States at a ''severe disadvantage'' with its own trading partners.Today, the vice president will appear in the East Room at the White House with President Clinton, former Presidents Ford and Carter, and two former secretaries of state, Henry A. Kissinger and James A. Baker III.A White House spokesman, Jim Kennedy, said that former President George Bush, the father of Mr. Gore's Republican rival, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, was invited, but ''due to a scheduling conflict, he is not able to attend.'' Governor Bush supports the trade agreement.Mr. Gore's commitment to the matter has been in some doubt since he won the endorsement of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. last fall. He said then that he supported it, leading two of the organization's most powerful members, the Teamsters and the United Auto Workers, to withhold their endorsement of his candidacy.Mr. Gore has tried to win over James P. Hoffa, president of the Teamsters union, but Mr. Hoffa, who is up for re-election and faces his own internal politics, has recently expressed more interest in the third-party candidacy of Patrick J. Buchanan, who also opposes the treaty.Mr. Gore has said he has called some members of Congress to push them to support the treaty, but has not said how many. Aides say he has made calls from his campaign plane and from his office and that if the vice president did not want to appear in the East Room today, he would not do so, suggesting that he sees some political benefit in standing with President Clinton on an issue that the administration has advanced as important to the economy.THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE VICE PRESIDENT
Many suburban schools have been able to think of lagging achievement by minority students as a city problem, one far away from their comfortable test scores and solid real-estate values. Their worries about test scores usually seem to revolve around who  will be closest to the top -- whether the numbers might make, say, Chappaqua's schools look better than Scarsdale's.But when the New York State Board of Regents last week decided to grade schools based partly on how well their black and Hispanic students score, not just how students score over all, it moved the debate on standards to a far more controversial realm, one that will force suburbs to confront difficult issues about race as well as a threat to their reputations.Many suburban schools have been able to think of lagging achievement by minority students as a city problem, one far away from their comfortable test scores and solid real-estate values. Their worries about test scores usually seem to revolve around who  will be closest to the top -- whether the numbers might make, say, Chappaqua's schools look better than Scarsdale's.But when the New York State Board of Regents last week decided to grade schools based partly on how well their black and Hispanic students score, not just how students score over all, it moved the debate on standards to a far more controversial realm, one that will force suburbs to confront difficult issues about race as well as a threat to their reputations.The challenge they face is now far thornier than simply raising overall test scores, educators say. They must close the stubborn gap that leaves black and Hispanic students -- even those with well-educated and more affluent parents -- trailing their white peers.''They're going to fail a lot of districts if they do this,'' said Paul Kelleher, superintendent of schools in Lawrence, which ranks high both on the list of Long Island's wealthiest communities and on the list of districts with the largest number of poor students. ''This achievement gap is in every school, it's true even in communities that have a middle-class African-American community.''Almost every suburb has at least a small population of black and Hispanic students, but they have been able to hide low scores in an average lifted by the good performance of affluent white and Asian students. Under the new rules, which for the first time will grade every school in the state as meeting, exceeding or falling below standards, the state could declare a school with high average test scores ''below standards'' if minority students at the school, even a handful, scored low.The new grades focus on what has become known as the achievement gap by making suburban parents stakeholders in solving it. Low achievement by minority students will no longer be a remote issue; it will affect the public perception of their schools and local property values.The Regents' move reflects a change in policy that has been occurring nationwide. Five other states evaluate schools based on how well their minority students score, and the United States Senate is debating a bill this week that would require all states to do the same. The experience of other states,  particularly Texas, suggests that tying school grades to achievement by race offers hope for lifting minority achievement.In New York, however, suburban superintendents say that the new grading policy is too onerous, that it will result in failures in many traditionally good school systems that could result in middle-class parents fleeing to private schools.In two years as superintendent, Mr. Kelleher of Lawrence has focused intensely on narrowing the achievement gap, increasing teacher mentoring for minority students and creating peer support networks to try to counter the notion prevalent among many black teenagers that doing well in school is ''acting white.''Mr. Kelleher and other superintendents applaud the state for highlighting the gap. They disagree, however, with grading schools on it.''The long-term data indicates very clearly there are not quick fixes,'' said Sherry King, superintendent of schools in Mamaroneck, in Westchester County. ''I'm not sure telling us that tomorrow there will be a new report card in the public view is going to change anything.''Ultimately, superintendents say, punishing schools where minority students do not do well ends up making diversity look like a bad goal. ''When you have socioeconomically diverse communities, then you have these scores printed, it's sometimes hard to convince people that the mixes we're trying to seek are what we want,'' Ms. King said.More affluent white parents in a racially mixed school, she suggested, might think their children would be better off in another, less diverse district, or a private school.Many superintendents said that separating scores by race makes them uncomfortable.''It puts a negative spin on it,'' said Linda Kelly, the superintendent in New Rochelle, where 44.7 percent of the students are white, 30.2 percent are black and 21.2 percent are Hispanic. ''We're proud we're a gateway community. We have diversity, and we think it's the greatest kind of education.''Still, more and more educators and parents have begun focusing on the gap in the last year. In October, the College Board released an extensive report documenting the gap. Fifteen diverse middle-class communities nationwide, including Montclair, N.J., have begun sharing ideas on how to close the gap.Massachusetts and California recently decided to assess schools based on performance by race, as New York plans to do. In a presidential campaign event to mark National Teachers Day today, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas plans to discuss ways to close the gap.Texas, which for nine years has graded schools based on data broken out by race, offers the strongest evidence that the grading of schools tied to race might close the achievement gap.In schools that received poor grades, teachers began focusing more intensely on writing and math. Parents and students held pep rallies encouraging students to study hard and do well. Schools plastered the walls with sloganeering posters and reminders of tips that might come in handy on a math exam.The result: Texans ranked first among all black fourth graders in the nation on the federally administered National Assessment of Educational Progress and Hispanic Texans sixth. California's black fourth graders, by contrast, ranked 36th, and New York's Hispanic fourth graders ranked 30th.As with many tests, some critics contend that Texas teachers are merely ''teaching to the test,'' that they have become exclusively focused on test preparation. That, they say, is not the same as education.But Amy Wilkins, a policy analyst for the Education Trust, a Washington-based nonprofit group that focuses on minority and disadvantaged students, said such criticism minimized the improvements in teaching in Texas.''Some people claim this is 'drill and kill,' '' she said. ''But more, you see teachers just teaching at a higher level.''People say, 'They're so poor, you can't expect much of them,' But if the kids are going to get out of these communities, you have to push them. 'Pity the poor' is going to get these kids nowhere.''
Although the Clinton administration has made ''humanitarian intervention'' a centerpiece of its foreign policy, it has done a poor job of delivering emergency aid to the people who need it, an internal State Department report says.The ''humanitarian factor has become central to senior policy makers' deliberations over U.S. foreign policy priorities,'' the report states. But the officials who are responsible for easing human suffering in foreign crises have little influence over high-level decision making, and in some cases are deliberately shut out, the study says.Although the Clinton administration has made ''humanitarian intervention'' a centerpiece of its foreign policy, it has done a poor job of delivering emergency aid to the people who need it, an internal State Department report says.The ''humanitarian factor has become central to senior policy makers' deliberations over U.S. foreign policy priorities,'' the report states. But the officials who are responsible for easing human suffering in foreign crises have little influence over high-level decision making, and in some cases are deliberately shut out, the study says.The report, written by a top adviser to Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright, chronicles the billions of dollars in emergency assistance that have been sent to Afghanistan, Kosovo and Sudan to help people whose lives have been disrupted by war and to Honduras in the aftermath of a big hurricane in 1998.Last year, when Serbian forces began expelling ethnic Albanians from Kosovo several days after the start of the NATO bombing campaign, senior administration officials publicly insisted that they were prepared for Serbian actions. Despite that, there was little food and shelter  on hand as hundreds of thousands of refugees flooded into Macedonia and Albania.The report describes the administration's main funnel for assistance to the expelled Kosovars, the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, as suffering from ''weak leadership'' in the region and adds that the administration was unable to change this.In Sudan, where the United States has spent more than $1 billion in the last 10 years trying to ease suffering in longest-running civil war in Africa, the report says the assistance has become so routine that it now appears to act as a substitute for peacemaking efforts to resolve the conflict.The report, initiated by Morton H. Halperin, director of policy planning at the State Department, and based on interviews with senior administration officials, is an unclassified document. But it was not made public until now.It was obtained under the Freedom of Information Act by the National Security Archive, a group that specializes in collecting government documents through requests and suits. The report was completed in January and has been submitted to Dr. Albright's office.In outlining options for improving response, the report suggests that the relief programs run by the Agency for International Development could be folded into the State Department.This is one step short of what Senator Jesse Helms, the North Carolina Republican who is chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, has been recommending since he took charge of the panel in 1995.Mr. Helms, who favors abolishing the agency as an independent entity and putting it into the State Department, said he believed ''bringing A.I.D. into the State Department will mean more effective use of the aid,'' his spokesman, Marc Thiessen, said.On the campaign trail, the two presumptive presidential candidates have differing views of the ''humanitarian intervention'' policy. George W. Bush Jr. has said he would be much more selective in deciding where and when the United States would intervene. Vice President Al Gore supported the interventionist policy in a recent major speech. Mr. Gore was instrumental in preventing the agency from being melded into the State Department years ago.In its account of how unprepared the administration was to meet the needs of the Kosovo refugees, the report points to shortcomings by American intelligence officials.Instead of anticipating an outpouring of refugees, the administration was expecting the opposite, that nearly a million people would be displaced in Kosovo in the bombing.''The prevailing worst-case scenario was that one million Kosovars would be displaced internally, prohibited from exiting, and remain largely inaccessible, in the context of an ongoing air war and a NATO determination not to launch a ground invasion,'' the report said.As for Sudan, the report added, many in the administration believed that top officials had exerted too little effort to resolve the conflict. That has been partly caused by deep divisions in the administration on Sudan, with some favoring total isolation and even more help to rebels in the south. In addition, officials responsible for the large assistance expenditures have been excluded from crucial decisions.Officials from A.I.D. and the State Department who managed the assistance program were not consulted when the administration decided to shut the American embassy in Khartoum in the mid-1990's because of security concerns. The closing undermined Washington's ability to talk to Khartoum about helping civilian war victims, the report said.
THE ISSUESCUOMO SEEKS BUSH STAND ON GUN BILL  Housing Secretary Andrew Cuomo added his voice yesterday to the chorus of Democrats who have called on Gov. George W. Bush of Texas to clarify his position on federal legislation that would prohibit lawsuits by local governments against gun manufacturers. Mr. Bush signed such legislation in Texas, and suggested last week that he would do the same in Washington. In a telephone news conference yesterday, Mr. Cuomo, who has tried to negotiate settlements between gun makers and cities that have sued them, called Mr. Bush's remarks vague. He asserted that the gun makers, who have broken off talks in recent months, would return to the table if they knew Mr. Bush opposed such legislation. Bush aides accused Mr. Cuomo of politicizing the issue. ''Instead of spending their time distorting and misrepresenting Governor Bush's priorities, the Clinton-Gore administration ought to spend more time enforcing our existing gun laws,'' said Scott McClellan, a spokesman for Mr. Bush.James Dao (NYT)THE ISSUESCUOMO SEEKS BUSH STAND ON GUN BILL  Housing Secretary Andrew Cuomo added his voice yesterday to the chorus of Democrats who have called on Gov.
