Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani withdrew from the most celebrated Senate race in the nation yesterday, saying that his health and his still-undecided treatment for prostate cancer were more important to him than his campaign against Hillary Rodham Clinton.In an emotional, riveting news conference, which he began in an uncharacteristically nervous voice, Mr. Giuliani said he wanted to devote his remaining 18 months in office to becoming a better mayor -- one who reaches out to minorities -- as well as becoming a better person. He took his listeners along on a psychological journey, holding out the possibility that his illness had changed him.Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani withdrew from the most celebrated Senate race in the nation yesterday, saying that his health and his still-undecided treatment for prostate cancer were more important to him than his campaign against Hillary Rodham Clinton.In an emotional, riveting news conference, which he began in an uncharacteristically nervous voice, Mr. Giuliani said he wanted to devote his remaining 18 months in office to becoming a better mayor -- one who reaches out to minorities -- as well as becoming a better person. He took his listeners along on a psychological journey, holding out the possibility that his illness had changed him.''I used to think the core of me was in politics, probably,'' Mr. Giuliani said. ''It isn't. When you feel your mortality and your humanity you realize that, that the core of you is first of all being able to take care of your health.'' [Page A14]A short time later in his half-hour of remarks in the City Hall Public Hearing Room, which was crowded with more than 35 television cameras from around the world as well as hundreds of supporters, teary campaign aides, members of his administration, reporters and friends, the mayor said confronting his ''limits'' had allowed him to see himself differently. ''You realize you're not a superman and you're just a human being.''He added: ''This is not the right time for me to run for office. If it were six months ago or it were a year from now or the timing were a little different, maybe it would be different. But it isn't different and that's the way life is.''The state Republican Party reacted with sympathy, but immediately pledged support for Representative Rick A. Lazio of Long Island as the choice to replace the mayor. Party leaders said they were worried about the race but relieved that Mr. Giuliani had made a decision after weeks of reviewing his options.''I understand and respect his decision to put his health first,'' said Gov. George E. Pataki. Mr. Lazio said Mr. Giuliani ''had the best interests of New Yorkers in mind,'' and he added that he was ready to run. ''I'm looking forward to this,'' he said.Mr. Lazio's pending entry and Mr. Giuliani's withdrawal instantly changed what had been an overheated, entertaining race of national interest into a more traditional campaign. City Hall, which in recent weeks has been a jangling nerve center, settled into a new calm after the mayor left shortly after 6 p.m.Mrs. Clinton, who telephoned the mayor shortly after his announcement, said afterward, ''I certainly hope and pray, as I know all New Yorkers do, that he will have a full and speedy recovery.'' Asked if she would miss the mayor as an opponent, Mrs. Clinton replied, ''Well, I think we should just wish him well as a person.''Mr. Giuliani's campaign and City Hall staffs greeted him with a standing ovation when he entered the news conference yesterday, and applauded him when he spoke of his mayoral successes. Many have been uneasy in recent days, as the mayor's deliberations generated uncertainty at City Hall and at his campaign headquarters.At the news conference, Mr. Giuliani said he had wavered in recent days on whether to stay in the race, and had been up much of Thursday night agonizing over his decision. But he said he finally reached it yesterday morning after speaking to a few close friends. Earlier on Thursday night, he appeared at a nationally televised town hall meeting at the 92nd Street Y in Manhattan, where he gave no indication of his intentions.''When I went in last night to the town hall meeting and I saw the people outside saying, 'Run, Rudy, run, Rudy, run, Rudy,' I had, you know, half the time last night I felt like I wanted to run,'' Mr. Giuliani said. ''And half the time I felt like I shouldn't do it.''I stayed up last night going back and forth about what's the right decision and what isn't the right decision. I believe this is the right decision. And I think somehow, somewhere, some way, this is all for the best.''Mr. Giuliani's life has been in a near-constant state of turmoil the last three weeks, much of it recorded by a persistent and expanding press corps. On April 27, the mayor announced that he had prostate cancer. On May 3, he said he had a ''very good'' friend, Judith Nathan. On May 10, he announced that he was seeking a separation from his wife, Donna Hanover. Ms. Hanover, who was surprised by the announcement, responded that same day by announcing that the couple's troubles had begun years earlier because of a relationship between her husband and a staff member.Ms. Hanover's press secretary identified the staff member as Cristyne Lategano-Nicholas, Mr. Giuliani's former director of communications, and said Ms. Hanover believed that the relationship had been intimate. Both the mayor and Ms. Lategano-Nicholas have denied that the relationship was sexual.Although Mr. Giuliani has been holding increasingly personal news conferences, in which he has ruminated openly about his life, he reached a new level of introspection with yesterday's announcement. ''I also believe that, you know, things happen in life for reasons that sometimes you only figure out afterwards,'' Mr. Giuliani said. ''And there is something good that comes out of this. A lot of good things come out of it. I think I understand myself a lot better. I think I understand what's important to me better.''But that ''doesn't mean there's going to be a new Rudy,'' the mayor said, making light of his frequently combative personality. ''I think that's silly.''Mr. Giuliani also sought to redefine the remaining months of his mayoralty, promising that he would try to embrace the minority groups he has alienated in the past. His administration, he said, will try to make sure that it ''accomplishes the goal of, you know, reaching every person that we can reach and making sure that every New Yorker feels that I'm dedicated to them, that I want to protect them, that I want to help them, and that I want my time as mayor to count for everybody.''Later, he said he wanted to figure out how he had placed a ''barrier'' between his administration and the city's minority residents. He also said, abruptly, that he wanted to increase the number of people covered by health insurance because of what he has been through. ''One of the things that I felt from the beginning of this and continue to feel is a tremendous sense of compassion for the people that have to make decisions like this alone,'' he said. ''One of the things maybe that I can do is figure out how we accelerate making sure that people are covered -- I mean, there are a lot of things that I think I can accomplish that I haven't accomplished before.''C. Virginia Fields, the Manhattan borough president, who has been a frequent critic of the mayor, said that she was ''very hopeful that he will, indeed, work to overcome the many barriers that face too many New Yorkers.'' The Rev. Al Sharpton, one of Mr. Giuliani's most vociferous critics, said that he wished Mr. Giuliani well, but that he did not see his withdrawal from the race ''as a political loss for the people of the state.'' Mr. Sharpton also said that he was now more inclined to run for mayor in 2001.Although Mr. Giuliani had repeatedly said in the days after announcing his illness that he would first make a decision on his cancer treatment and then decide on the race, he said yesterday that his thinking had been flawed.''I didn't organize this,'' he said. ''I mean, I didn't understand the impact of this. It was, what I thought at first was, O.K., I'll take a week or two, or three, whatever it takes, to figure out what the treatment is. I will then decide on the treatment, I'll then look at the treatment and I'll figure out, does that mean I can run or I can't run.'' Mr. Giuliani added, ''I know it sounds silly, but I thought of it like a budget decision or a legal decision.''But Mr. Giuliani said the decision, which could be either surgery to remove the prostate or radiation, had turned out to be far more difficult than he ever imagined -- in part, he said on Thursday, because of possible side effects. Although surgery is the choice of most men of Mr. Giuliani's age, which is 55, and has a high cure rate, it also causes impotence and incontinence in many patients. Doctors say that radiation, particularly in the form of ''seeds'' inserted into the prostate, has less effect on sexual function, but its long-term cure rates are not known.Although doctors said that Mr. Giuliani would have been physically able to continue in the race no matter what treatment he chose -- if he was willing to campaign part time over the summer -- Mr. Giuliani said yesterday that he did not want to run a race when he was not operating at 100 percent.''My concentration isn't going to be there,'' he said. He added that ''nobody can tell you in percentages what the side effects are going to be. You can be fine, you can be terrific, or you can have problems and then you won't be able to carry out your commitment.''The mayor said that he would continue to mull over his treatment options in the coming weeks, and that his decision would not be ''a political matter'' but a personal one. He said again, as he has repeatedly, that his decision not to run was based on his health, not on his unraveling marriage or personal problems.Joannie Danielides, Ms. Hanover's press secretary, said that the mayor telephoned his wife and informed her of his decision shortly before his announcement. Ms. Hanover recently hired Helene Brezinsky, a prominent Manhattan divorce lawyer.Both Ms. Hanover and Mr. Giuliani are living at Gracie Mansion while they work out a separation agreement.''They talked briefly,'' Ms. Danielides said. ''She's concerned for his health and will try to help him with that.''Before he made his announcement, Mr. Giuliani also informed Mr. Pataki; William D. Powers, the state Republican Party chairman; Trent Lott, the Senate majority leader; Senator John McCain and Gov. George W. Bush, whom Mr. Giuliani endorsed for president.''I told Rudy that I understood it was a very difficult decision for him to make, and our prayers are with him,'' Mr. Bush said. ''He is my friend whether he's the candidate or not for the United States Senate.''Mr. Giuliani told his staff of his decision shortly after his 11 a.m. radio call-in show on Friday, when senior members of his administration could be seen moving in and out of his office with grim faces. A short walk away, on Maiden Lane, the site of the Giuliani campaign headquarters, young volunteers were devastated. Bruce J. Teitelbaum, Mr. Giuliani's campaign manager, who had privately and consistently worried that Mr. Giuliani would withdraw, said he would go on vacation, and he began turning requests for interviews with the mayor over to Mr. Giuliani's City Hall press secretary, Sunny Mindel. ''The campaign is effectively over,'' he said.Although Mr. Giuliani said that he was ''pretty sure'' of his decision even before the radio show, he did not let on, even during a long, melancholy response to ''Eileen in Queens,'' who had called to say that she would vote for Mr. Giuliani, but not for Mr. Lazio if the mayor dropped out.The mayor thanked her, then said: ''Believe me, if you have ever faced a decision like this, you realize it is much deeper, it is much more difficult, it involves many more parts of you, involves every part of you, actually. And it involves you really calculating what are the most important things in your life.''At the close of Mr. Giuliani's announcement, a reporter asked the mayor if he felt closer to God.''I hope he's closer to me,'' he replied.THE MAYOR'S DECISION: THE OVERVIEW
The Selling of''Free Trade''Nafta, Washington, and the Subversionof American Democracy.By John R. MacArthur.388 pp. New York:Hill & Wang. $25.The Selling of''Free Trade''Nafta, Washington, and the Subversionof American Democracy.By John R. MacArthur.388 pp. New York:Hill & Wang. $25.You would have to go back to the 19th century to find a trade battle in Congress that was as divisive as that over the North American Free Trade Agreement in 1993. What has been needed is a dispassionate study that gets past the sound and fury. John R. MacArthur's study, ''The Selling of 'Free Trade,' ''is not really that. It mixes a passionate attack on the treaty with a journalistic account of its passage and effects. Die-hard opponents of the agreement will probably like this book. Others may find it irritatingly one-sided.Nafta emerged from at least three different impulses: first, Mexican officials, frightened by a growing foreign debt that was crippling their economy, wanted to attract American investment; second, American businesses wanted to be able to invest in Mexico free from export restrictions and domestic content rules, and from the ultimate threat of expropriation; and third, American officials and policy makers, worried about political instability and a torrent of illegal immigrants, wanted to incorporate Mexico into a Common Market-type arrangement that would lead to the revival of its economy, the reform of its government and the reduction of cross-border tensions.MacArthur understands the first two impulses. He understands that Nafta was primarily an investment agreement rather than a free trade treaty. But he plays down or ignores Americans' broader concerns. Nafta, he insists, was ''entirely about money.''MacArthur, the president and publisher of Harper's Magazine, is at his best describing the lobbying that occurred after the treaty was signed and went to Congress in August 1993. He shows how business lobbyists worked hand in glove with the treaty's Congressional supporters. But he has surprisingly little to say about the negotiations themselves, or about the domestic political conflicts that occurred while the treaty was being negotiated. His account of these tends to render shades of gray as black. When the Bush administration proposed that Congress agree to a fast-track vote (up or down without amendments), Richard Gephardt, the House majority leader and a Democrat, backed Bush on the condition that the treaty contain rules on labor standards and environmental protection. MacArthur dismisses this position as nave and opportunistic. (Gephardt ''was presumably ambitious to be liked by the sort of people, honest or not, who can make you president.'')A year later, during the presidential campaign, Bill Clinton, under the influence of Gephardt and two advisers, Derek Shearer and Richard Rothstein, adopted the same position. MacArthur treats Clinton even more contemptuously than he does Gephardt. He says Clinton ''had already made up his mind on trade to the point where there was no substantial difference between his position and Bush's.'' Clinton's stand, he says, was primarily based on fund-raising. That assertion leaves little middle ground between those adamantly opposed to Nafta and those enthusiastically in favor. MacArthur may be right, but when I covered the negotiations I found otherwise.In the Nafta negotiations, Clinton and Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative, earnestly attempted to get Mexico and Canada to agree to set up commissions that would have significant punitive powers. They failed, primarily because of Mexican and Canadian opposition, as well as opposition from the Business Roundtable and Republicans in Congress. But they also failed because the A.F.L.-C.I.O., instead of trying to work with the administration, took a position of unequivocal opposition to the treaty in any form. Clinton and Gephardt found themselves caught between business-style internationalism and labor protectionism.The resulting treaty was flawed. MacArthur's view, which also became Gephardt's, was that it should have been rejected, but MacArthur now criticizes Gephardt and John Sweeney, the A.F.L.-C.I.O. president, for failing to press for Nafta's repeal on the grounds that it has worsened the condition of Mexican and American workers. In drawing this conclusion, MacArthur ignores two important considerations.He acknowledges that Mexico was in difficult straits on the eve of Nafta, but he attributes these problems to the Mexican government's abandonment of older high-tariff import substitution policies. Under these policies, MacArthur writes, there was ''less social inequality and more purchasing power for the average Mexican.'' But he fails to note that before the 1980's, the Mexican economy was propped up by oil earnings. When oil prices began to fall, the economy began to stagger, and it is still not on its feet. Nafta may not have improved Mexico's economy, but it is not clear that it has made things worse.The second consideration has to do with the impact of American investment in Mexico on American jobs. Investment increased somewhat after Nafta was signed, but the boom in American investment in Mexico predated Nafta. And if that investment had not gone to Mexico, it might have ended up in Central America or Asia, not in the United States. If Nafta depressed American wages, it did so indirectly -- by giving credibility to corporate managers' threats that if a union organized or demanded too much for its workers, the company would move to Mexico. Modifying Nafta to strengthen its labor and environmental commissions could benefit both American and Mexican workers, but repealing the treaty doesn't hold any obvious promise for Mexico, the United States or Canada.To MacArthur's credit, he has tried his best to make a potentially dull subject interesting by treating himself as a character in his narrative; by interspersing long interviews with lobbyists, politicians and affected workers; and by telling the story of one factory in New York that was affected by Nafta. But he is not the most artful author, and the book sometimes drags. It would have been much more lively at half the length. But it probably would not have been any more accurate a portrayal of the choices facing American policy makers and citizens in 1993.John B. Judis is a senior editor at The New Republic and the author of ''The Paradox of American Democracy.''
You've got to believe that the old man, wherever he is now, enjoyed his own funeral Mass. The climax was Cardinal Bernard Law's eulogy to the career and mission of Cardinal John O'Connor. ''What a great legacy he has left us in his constant reminder that the church must always be unambiguously pro-life,'' Law said, his strong Brahmin voice resonating throughout the nave. And then, after a stunned pause, the applause grew, first from the back of the cathedral, then spreading to the front, as the assorted politicians found themselves rising uncomfortably to the occasion. I doubt if Cardinal O'Connor had ever made more people less comfortable in his lifetime. And it wasn't for lack of trying.What O'Connor meant by ''pro-life'' was all-encompassing. He was as opposed to abortion as he was to the death penalty, and after the late Cardinal Bernardin of Chicago, he was perhaps the most effective exponent of that position in recent memory. For O'Connor, as for the current pope, life is life is life. From conception to natural death, our first duty is to defend it. Where there's legitimate doubt about exactly what kind of life it is -- the life of an unborn child or a senile invalid or a convicted murderer -- we should always veer toward the side of clemency. To do otherwise is to play God, or to risk a subtle cheapening of human life that can in turn lead to a deeper disregard for it. Treat a fetus as disposable, and before too long the mentally handicapped or terminally ill will see their own right to life as negotiable as well.You've got to believe that the old man, wherever he is now, enjoyed his own funeral Mass. The climax was Cardinal Bernard Law's eulogy to the career and mission of Cardinal John O'Connor. ''What a great legacy he has left us in his constant reminder that the church must always be unambiguously pro-life,'' Law said, his strong Brahmin voice resonating throughout the nave. And then, after a stunned pause, the applause grew, first from the back of the cathedral, then spreading to the front, as the assorted politicians found themselves rising uncomfortably to the occasion. I doubt if Cardinal O'Connor had ever made more people less comfortable in his lifetime. And it wasn't for lack of trying.What O'Connor meant by ''pro-life'' was all-encompassing. He was as opposed to abortion as he was to the death penalty, and after the late Cardinal Bernardin of Chicago, he was perhaps the most effective exponent of that position in recent memory. For O'Connor, as for the current pope, life is life is life. From conception to natural death, our first duty is to defend it. Where there's legitimate doubt about exactly what kind of life it is -- the life of an unborn child or a senile invalid or a convicted murderer -- we should always veer toward the side of clemency. To do otherwise is to play God, or to risk a subtle cheapening of human life that can in turn lead to a deeper disregard for it. Treat a fetus as disposable, and before too long the mentally handicapped or terminally ill will see their own right to life as negotiable as well.Advocates of this ''seamless garment of life'' argument (the phrase was Bernardin's) can point to public opinion polls to show how the issues of abortion and the death penalty are related. Since the 1960's, support for legal abortion and the death penalty have tracked each other closely. Between 1972 and 1974, for example, the moment Roe v. Wade initiated the era of mass abortion in America, support for the death penalty also rose by 10 percent. Pure coincidence? According to the General Social Survey of the University of Michigan, Americans who opposed all legal abortion in recent years were twice as likely as other Americans to oppose the death penalty. On the other hand, those supporting legal abortion in every circumstance -- the abortion-rights absolutists -- were the group least likely to oppose capital punishment. It's just another area of life where the old right-left paradigm doesn't quite work anymore.At least in theory. In practice, politicians holding the consistent life-life position are as rare as they are gutsy. In the House of Representatives, I have been able to find only one man -- Representative Chris Smith of New Jersey -- who publicly opposes both abortion and the death penalty in principle and has a voting record to prove it. Among the other 30 to 40 anti-abortion Democrats, I couldn't find any with an unequivocal record against capital punishment. In the punditariat, I know of only two major writers, Nat Hentoff and Christopher Hitchens, who have doggedly resisted the pressure of their liberal allies and stuck to their life-life convictions. In the broader political arena, Pat Robertson, to his credit, has recently succumbed to doubts about the death penalty and called for a moratorium. But Robertson, like Illinois's governor, George Ryan, wants a moratorium only because he is concerned that some innocent people are being executed, not because he thinks it is wrong to kill under any circumstance.Others on the right hold more confused views. George W. Bush supports a constitutional amendment to ban abortion in most cases, and yet as governor of Texas he has personally signed the death warrants of more than 120 people -- about a sixth of all the condemned prisoners executed since capital punishment was revived in the 1970's. In an interview with Talk magazine last year, he even made fun of one of the victims of Texas' death row, Karla Fay Tucker, mocking her pleas for mercy. And despite growing DNA evidence of the innocence of many death-row convicts across the country, Bush has shown not even a glimmer of concern that the Texas judicial system might be flawed. Or take the vociferously anti-abortion representative Henry Hyde. Two years ago, Hyde said: ''I look for the common thread in slavery, the Holocaust and abortion. To me, the common thread is dehumanizing people.'' And yet Hyde has personally championed legislation that significantly curtails the judicial review of death-row appeals. Even Alan Keyes, that peerless defender of unborn life, turns out to be a supporter of criminals' deaths. He said earlier this year, ''I think that there are circumstances under which it is essential . . . that we have and apply the death penalty in order to send a clear moral message to people throughout our society that we will not tolerate that kind of disrespect for life.'' In other words, if you want to support life, enforce death.Liberals have honed a different compromise. The American Civil Liberties Union passionately supports the right of women to abort their potential children and vehemently opposes the right of government to execute proved murderers. That's also the position of the National Organization for Women, The New Republic and the New York Times editorial page. Liberals, of course, insist that they are not inconsistent, because they believe a fetus is not a person, while a criminal clearly is. But even if a fetus is not a person, is it not in some sense alive? And shouldn't any form of human life be worthy of at least some moral weight in a decision about its own life or death? It's also true that in a just conviction a criminal is guilty of murder, while a fetus in a legal abortion is guilty of nothing. Should culpability play no role in the question of who gets to die -- or are only the criminals worthy of empathy? And if part of the opposition to the death penalty springs from its physical cruelty, as it surely should, then how exactly can many death-penalty opponents support what some activists have called ''partial-birth abortion,'' a procedure that makes the electric chair seem positively comfy? Yet several Catholic senators are uncomfortable with giving a lethal injection to a criminal but defend crushing the skull of a viable partly born fetus. Go figure.Bill Clinton's signal contribution to this debate was to construct a new and powerful centrist position. Call it ''double death.'' Double-deathers consistently back the right to abort and the right to execute. Clinton twice vetoed legislation that would have banned late-term abortion, and famously interrupted his election campaign in 1992 to approve the execution of a mentally incapacitated prisoner in Arkansas. For Clinton, and other double-deathers, this combo has a powerful political rationale. The formula signals to the feminist left that Clinton is one of them (can I have your check now, please?), and it signals to the centrist right that he's not Michael Dukakis (can I have your vote now, please?). Under Clinton, execution rates have duly soared, the federal death penalty has been extended to a broadening array of crimes and the legal right to abort a fetus has become Democratic Party gospel. Clinton's heir, Al Gore, once had moral qualms about abortion. But he's a quick study and is now an absolutist defender of abortion rights and a fervent supporter of capital punishment. The same goes for Rudy Giuliani, whose commitment to the legality of certain kinds of killing has made him as tenacious a double-deather as Hillary Clinton.No wonder they squirmed in their pews. Life, after all, is a precious and precarious thing. But nothing as precarious as a politician's consistency.
In a rousing speech to an A.F.L.-C.I.O. convention in New Jersey, Vice President Gore used the attack word secret seven times. It is now his favorite adjective, having temporarily replaced risky (as in the phrase, pronounced as one word, riskytaxscheme).He was blazing away at Governor Bush's proposal, not yet detailed, to allow individuals to divert a portion of their Social Security taxes into the stock market. Gore charged that Bush believed ''it would be best not to let you, the voters of this country, in on the secret plan before the election. . . . He is suppressing the details of how his plan would work and refusing to divulge what his secret plan really is.'' At a subsequent news conference, he evidently felt that secret was not pejorative enough and added, redundantly, a ''private secret plan.''In a rousing speech to an A.F.L.-C.I.O. convention in New Jersey, Vice President Gore used the attack word secret seven times. It is now his favorite adjective, having temporarily replaced risky (as in the phrase, pronounced as one word, riskytaxscheme).He was blazing away at Governor Bush's proposal, not yet detailed, to allow individuals to divert a portion of their Social Security taxes into the stock market. Gore charged that Bush believed ''it would be best not to let you, the voters of this country, in on the secret plan before the election. . . . He is suppressing the details of how his plan would work and refusing to divulge what his secret plan really is.'' At a subsequent news conference, he evidently felt that secret was not pejorative enough and added, redundantly, a ''private secret plan.''That sinister phrase -- secret plan -- has resonance to veteran rhetoricians and students of presidential campaigns. In the 1968 primaries, candidate Richard Nixon was searching for a way to promise he would extricate the U.S. from its increasingly unpopular involvement in Vietnam. The key verb to be used was end, though it would be nice to get the verb win in some proximity to it.One speechwriter came up with the formulation that ''new leadership will end the war and win the peace in the Pacific.'' Nixon made it part of his stump speech, and the juxtaposition of end and win -- though it did not claim to intend to win the war, but only the peace -- drove his major opponent for the G.O.P. nomination, Gov. George Romney of Michigan, up the wall.When a U.P.I. reporter pressed Nixon for specifics, the candidate demurred; the reporter wrote that it seemed Nixon was determined to keep his plan secret, though he did not quote Nixon as having said either secret or plan. But this gave Romney a chance to slam back at his opponent's promise. In what became the centerpiece of his stump speech in the snows of New Hampshire, Romney demanded to know, ''Where is your secret plan?'' That question skillfully presupposed an assertion of not just a general promise but also a detailed plan, and soon it became widely accepted that Nixon had said, ''I have a secret plan to end the war.''Years later, when a New York Times columnist attributed that direct quote to Nixon, a White House speechwriter challenged him to find the quote in anything taken down by pencil or recorder at the time. The pundit searched high and low and had to admit the supposed remark was unsourceable. (Look, the Nixon speechwriter was me and the columnist was my current colleague, Tony Lewis; I didn't have to research this.)During Ronald Reagan's run for re-election in 1984, Democrats took a leaf from the Romney playbook and charged him with having a secret plan to raise taxes after the election. This forced Reagan to say defensively he would raise taxes only ''as a last resort'' and reminded politicians that the old secret-plan charge had legs.Even Gore, a few weeks before he leveled the tried-and-true phrase at Bush, showed he was aware of its old-chestnuttiness. In a hilarious, deadpan, self-mocking speech to the Gridiron Club in Washington, he was widely reported to have said he had a secret plan to win the White House: he would claim credit for all the good stuff that had happened in the past eight years and dissociate himself from the bad stuff.Meanwhile, George W. Bush has been using an attack word of his own to characterize the Gore approach to Social Security: ''For eight years,'' he wrote in a fund-raising letter, ''Clinton/Gore has had history's greatest opportunity to reform Social Security. They chose to demagogue the problem, not repair it.''I kept this letter, sent to me by its recipient, Leila Hadley Luce of New York, to note the use of the beslashed singular subject Clinton/Gore, followed properly by the singular verb has, but then followed incorrectly by they. Clinton/Gore is a team and takes an it.But Mrs. Luce's covering note questioned the use of the ''new verb,'' to demagogue. Originally a noun, this was formed from the Greek demos, ''people,'' and agogos, ''leading''; it meant ''leader of the mob'' and now has the derogatory meaning of ''a politician who appeals to people's emotions.'' The noun can be used attributively to do the work of an adjective: Robert Southey in 1812 denounced ''the venom and the virulence of the demagogue journalists.''Governor Bush cannot be faulted for using demagogue as a verb. It was coined in that form by James Harrington in his 1656 utopian theory, ''Commonwealth of Oceana.'' He picked up the noun coined five years earlier by Thomas Hobbes and wrote of a time ''when that same ranting fellow Alcibiades fell a demagoging for the Sicilian war.'' In 1890, The Cincinnati Commercial Gazette wrote of President Benjamin Harrison, ''The president never thought of demagoging the matter.''Note the lack of a u in those usages of what most of us would until recently spell as demagoguing. But we live in a non-U world; just as catalogue and dialogue have been dropping their ue endings, so too will demagogue soon enough be spelled demagog, with its gerund demagoging.It's a hard word for the mob to handle; demagogic is pronounced with the final g soft, rhyming with logic, but demagoguery has the final g hard, rhyming with toggery. (Get away from that e-mail key; there is such a word. It means ''clothing.'')Will Gore now assail Bush for harboring a secret plan to attack him for demagoguery? Will Bush lash back in a debate by demanding he spell it? Both sides are now armed.
WHAT hath George Clooney wrought? Six weeks after Mr. Clooney used his star clout to get the drama ''Fail Safe'' broadcast live -- in black and white on national television -- entertainment-industry trade publications have already reported plans for two other live dramas. One is on CBS with Julie Andrews as the star; the other is on HBO with Glenn Close as co-executive producer. Other projects are in the talking stages.Optimists see this as the glimmer of a possible second golden age of television. More likely it's just the latest in reality programming. Bored with seeing attractive young people on MTV's ''Real World'' work out their emotional problems on camera? Not thrilled enough about the prospect of strangers voting one another off a desert island near Borneo while the whole world watches in CBS's forthcoming ''Survivor''? Instead you can watch actual famous people put themselves in potentially embarrassing situations and hope for the worst.WHAT hath George Clooney wrought? Six weeks after Mr. Clooney used his star clout to get the drama ''Fail Safe'' broadcast live -- in black and white on national television -- entertainment-industry trade publications have already reported plans for two other live dramas. One is on CBS with Julie Andrews as the star; the other is on HBO with Glenn Close as co-executive producer. Other projects are in the talking stages.Optimists see this as the glimmer of a possible second golden age of television. More likely it's just the latest in reality programming. Bored with seeing attractive young people on MTV's ''Real World'' work out their emotional problems on camera? Not thrilled enough about the prospect of strangers voting one another off a desert island near Borneo while the whole world watches in CBS's forthcoming ''Survivor''? Instead you can watch actual famous people put themselves in potentially embarrassing situations and hope for the worst.''Maybe somebody will make a mistake; that's half of the appeal,'' says Jeff Kisseloff, the author of ''The Box: An Oral History of Television 1920-61.''  ''It's just a gimmick. It's not the golden age of television.''The potential for disaster seems to interest the press. Articles about ''Fail Safe'' referred to the show's being broadcast three hours later on the West Coast, ''mistakes and all,'' and asked producers to comment on what would happen if an actor forgot a line or tripped over a wire. The answer: we'll just keep going. Much like the actors appearing on stages across the country on any given night. Theater actors are full of stories about losing their place or their pants or their props and riffing their way through. Now there's excitement.The same sort of fascination also works its way into possibly apocryphal stories about those live television plays in the 1950's: the night the corpse didn't realize the camera was still on him and got up and walked away, for instance. But the energy of those shows didn't come only from immediacy.''In the old days they were flying by the seat of their pants,'' says Mr. Kisseloff. To compare broadcasting a live television play in 2000 to doing one 45 or 50 years ago is, he says, ''like getting into an airplane and thinking you're taking the same risks as Orville and Wilbur Wright.'' The people working in television in the 1950's were, he says, ''young and talented and excited -- everything that this is not.''Ron Simon, curator of television at the Museum of Television and Radio in New York, couldn't agree more. ''There were new voices and original scripts, creating a voice and a mood for television, creating a whole language,'' he says. ''There was a whole community of technical people'' thrilled to be specializing in a brave new field.And, as Mr. Simon points out, there was Fred Coe, the producer -- legendary within the television industry -- who nurtured writing talents like Paddy Chayefsky, Horton Foote and Gore Vidal. The teleplays they created were largely, he says, about ''contemporary life in the 50's.''  ''Marty,'' for instance, the 1953 television play written by Chayefsky, was not just about an unmarried young butcher with a possessive mother and no ideas for what to do on Saturday night, but about the transition from ''tradition to modern values,'' from prewar to postwar thinking. ''Fail Safe'' -- which starred Richard Dreyfuss, Brian Dennehy, Harvey Keitel and Noah Wyle -- was based on a 1964 movie and dealt with the cold war anxieties of the early 60's.The next big live network drama is also an adaptation of an older work, although its concerns are less specifically tied to a particular era. CBS is set to do a live broadcast in late fall of ''On Golden Pond,'' which most people know as the 1981 film starring Katharine Hepburn, Henry Fonda and Jane Fonda. Julie Andrews will star as the devoted wife of a physically frail retired college professor, helping him through the terrors of aging. The roles of her husband and their angry, alienated daughter, Chelsea, are still to be cast.Craig Anderson, who directed the original stage play by Ernest Thompson (first at the Hudson Guild Theater, then on Broadway in the late 70's), is directing the television version. And he is doing it, he says, just because it's a challenge.''This is an opportunity to mix my two lives,'' says Mr. Anderson, referring to his live theater work and his career as a television producer. ''There aren't any rules.''At least that's a golden-age attitude. Mr. Anderson is considering using a turntable set, which would move as the actors walked (''It has a little bit of moviemaking in it''), and hopes to ''invent some new cameras'' designed for the dual demands of television and theater. ''On Golden Pond'' will be staged in Los Angeles, and the broadcast will include views of the black-tie audience, which, it is hoped, will laugh and cry at the appropriate times.Still, it isn't much of a risk to present a story that has had thousands of stage productions since the film was nominated for 10 Academy Awards and won three, including Mr. Fonda's first and only.If there are going to be original plays in television's future, they may come from Father Lucky Productions, the company set up with HBO by Ms. Close and by Robert Pastorelli, who starred on the CBS sitcom ''Murphy Brown'' as the artist, house painter and nanny Eldin. Variety, the trade newspaper, reported that Father Lucky would develop and produce a series of dramas to be performed live and would begin by commissioning four dramas. No one at HBO was willing to discuss the project because, a publicity representative said, it was too early in the process.Maybe it shouldn't be surprising that a company like Father Lucky would be formed by two actors. Live performance may be a much bigger charge for those on the screen or the stage than for the people watching them. ''That relation between performer and audience is what acting is all about, what theater is all about,'' says Mr. Anderson, echoing a theater truism. If the relative profitability of feature films, television and live theater are any indication, though, the audience has not always shared that passion.Or maybe it's just that we see plenty of live television already.It's true that prime time programming consists mostly of filmed comedies and dramas and the daytime soap operas long ago switched to videotape. Even the late-night talk shows are taped hours (sometimes days) before they are broadcast. But the morning infotainment shows like ''Good Morning, America'' and the ''Today'' show are live, and Americans seem as thrilled now as their forebears were in the early 50's to stand outside the shows' studio windows and wave. Most sports events and awards shows are live. (The Oscars broadcast is particularly enjoyable in this respect because it's still afternoon in Los Angeles when the movie stars arrive, wearing that daring fashion combination of evening wear and sunglasses.)The police car chase, broadcast live from helicopters, has become a television staple. This may not say much for us as a culture, but it certainly feeds the need of some Americans to hold their breath and wait to see if a real-live human being is going to be caught, shot or blown up or meet some other terrible fate. Once you've seen O. J. Simpson in the vehicle being pursued, reportedly holding a gun to his head at one point, the tension about whether Noah Wyle will forget his lines just isn't that high.NBC's late-night comedy sketch show ''Saturday Night Live'' has, for 25 years, lived up to its name. In fact, it may be the one true success story among the industry's efforts to capitalize on the novelty of the live broadcast. The show has had its ups and downs, but it has never lost its slightly desperate edge. As its producer, Lorne Michaels, told Bill Carter of The New York Times last year, describing the process of writing, rewriting and rehearsing each sketch: ''It doesn't go on because it's ready. It goes on because it's 11:30.''FOX tried a live series nine years ago with ''Roc,'' a half-hour comedy about a garbage collector and his family in Baltimore. The theory was that since the cast included stage-seasoned actors like Charles S. Dutton, Rocky Carroll and Carl Gordon, the show should take advantage of it. But the novelty soon wore off (or never attracted enough regular viewers to begin with) and ''Roc'' went off the air after three seasons.For now, the novelty of live television drama may pay off in high ratings. ''Fail Safe'' did much better than CBS's Sunday night movie usually does, with a 10.3 rating, which means about 10.3 million households viewing. And that was up against both ''The X-Files'' and the season finale of ''The Sopranos.'' But the likelihood that a group of talented, intelligent, hungry young writers will find their way to the medium at the same time as a sympathetic, intelligent producer, creating that second golden age, is extremely slim. And even if it did happen, says Mr. Kisseloff, the new work would never find its way onto the air live.''There is just no chance-taking today,'' says Mr. Kisseloff. ''There's too much money involved.''TELEVISION/RADIO  Correction:  June 4, 2000, Sunday  An article on May 21 about live television dramas misidentified the director of a planned broadcast of ''On Golden Pond.'' He is Ernest Thompson, not Craig Anderson.Correction: June 4, 2000, SundayAn article on May 21 about live television dramas misidentified the director of a planned broadcast of ''On Golden Pond.'' (914) 265-5384.Portraits From SouthburyThe York Square Cinema in New Haven is noted for its art gallery as well as its 55-year-old tradition of showing unusual domestic and foreign films that are not widely distributed. In its gallery through June 6 are a selection of portrait photographs made by Richmond Jones at the Southbury Training School in 1974 and 1975.During his long career as a photographer, Mr. Jones has produced work that appeared in exhibitions in Switzerland and Canada as well as in New York.His Southbury portraits are unusual in their focus on the individual. There are no shots of bleak interiors or institutional life, no polemics, no attempt to record a visual expose. Each portrait is skillfully composed, lighted and revealing of its subject. The theater's lobby gallery, at 61 Broadway, is accessible from 5 to 10 p.m., Monday through Friday, and from 1 to 10 p.m. Saturday and Sunday. The number to call for more information is (203) 776-6630.Old Lyme CentennialOne hundred years ago the boarding house that Florence Griswold ran in Old Lyme became the home of the Lyme Art Colony, populated in summer by American Impressionists, including Childe Hassam, Willard Metcalf, William Chadwick, Walter Griffin and Wilson Henry Irvine.In celebration of the colony's centennial, Patricia Norcia, a New York actress, researched and wrote a one-woman play about six women who lived at the house during the summer of 1910. Ms. Norcia will portray all of them in two performances, at 3 and 8 p.m. on Saturday at the Ivoryton Playhouse on Main Street in Ivoryton. Each performance will be followed by conversation between the actress and her audience.In the course of the production she portrays Whistling Mary, the Irish housemaid; Matilda Browne, the artist; Beatrice Hoffman, an artist's wife; Ellen Wilson, the first wife of President Woodrow Wilson; a farmer's wife, and Florence Griswold herself.Tickets are $15, students and adults over 64 $12. LINDA GRANT, a school board member, calls the dispute over a proposal to put up lights at the high school football field here ''a tinder box that could go up at any time.''On one side are residents offering to donate $125,000 to pay for the lights and also to provide additional funds to cover necessary operating costs. They want the lights so that teams can play at night, and they argue that it will let parents share more after-work time with their children.LINDA GRANT, a school board member, calls the dispute over a proposal to put up lights at the high school football field here ''a tinder box that could go up at any time.''On one side are residents offering to donate $125,000 to pay for the lights and also to provide additional funds to cover necessary operating costs. They want the lights so that teams can play at night, and they argue that it will let parents share more after-work time with their children.''The lights will bring us together,''said Sandra Zwerger, a member of the group that favors the lights.On the other side are members of the Rye Natural Light Association, who don't want lighting poles as tall as 15 feet rearing up from a quaint part of the city, across the street from the church where George and Barbara Bush married. They fear the lights will mar the view and lower property values.The controversy has proved extremely divisive, said Ms. Grant, chairman of a Board of Education advisory committee that was appointed over the winter to study the issue.At meetings, the opposing sides sit on separate sides of the aisle, like feuding factions at a family wedding. ''It's upstaging everything,'' Ms. Grant said, ''even the budget.''The pro-light group argues that the night illumination would not add to the taxpayers' burden.Also, the lights would be turned on only seven times a year and would be lowered on their poles when not in use, said John Eyler, the president of Toys 'R' Us and a member of the pro-lights group. ''After we rented lights for $5,000 for one night game,'' he said, ''we thought about how it would be a great idea to raise money to install permanent lights so we could hold more events.''But the opponents have other concerns.''The proposed industrial-style lights are completely out of character with the high school architecture and historic and pristine nature of this neighborhood,'' the group that is opposing the lights said in a statement.Or as Drew Shea, a banker and the president of the Rye Natural Light Association, said, ''Large lights will attract crowds and create a celebratory atmosphere in people's backyards.''The opponents see the gift as benefiting only the high school's athletes, while the school district has more important issues to consider.''This gift looks a little frivolous to many people,'' Ms. Grant said.  ''What kind of a statement is it making when maybe it would be more important to create another first grade to maintain our pupil-teacher ratios.''Cathleen Morgan, the chairwoman of the Board of Education, called it ''a very very controversial issue and one that people are very passionate about.''The board will vote on May 31  whether to accept the gift.
To the Editor:Abraham Lincoln, Adlai Stevenson, John F. Kennedy, Ronald Reagan, Bob Dole. What did each have that today's presidential candidates lack in such great abundance? A sense of humor, springing from the gut, not a 3-by-5-inch ghost-written card [''Fear and Joking on the Late-Night Campaign Trail'' by Peter Marks, May 7]. Neither Al Gore nor George W. Bush has the instincts it takes to go joke for joke with a killer comic. Indeed, it sometimes seems that both Mr. Gore and Mr. Bush have decided that maybe Calvin Coolidge had the right idea: ''I think the American public wants a solemn ass as a President. And I think I'll go along with them.'' Each would profit from the advice of Richard M. Nixon, who, of all people, said, ''The worst sin in politics is being boring.'' And, when elected, the winner should keep in mind this warning from Mr. Dole: ''What people often forget is that the last laugh doesn't belong to the victorious candidate -- it belongs to the late-night comics.''WES PEDERSEN  Chevy Chase, Md.To the Editor:Abraham Lincoln, Adlai Stevenson, John F. WHEN brownstones were constructed on block after block of Brooklyn in the late 19th century, they provided housing for well-to-do people whose live-in servants, usually immigrants from Italy, Ireland or Germany, would dust the intricately carved moldings and cook in the ground-floor kitchens, sending food upstairs to the dining room by dumbwaiter.Eventually though, brownstones  in much of Brooklyn became associated with the working class, and then the poor, who moved in when the buildings were divided into rooming houses. People with money, by and large, didn't want brownstones in Brooklyn; they wanted to live in apartment buildings in Manhattan or houses in the suburbs.WHEN brownstones were constructed on block after block of Brooklyn in the late 19th century, they provided housing for well-to-do people whose live-in servants, usually immigrants from Italy, Ireland or Germany, would dust the intricately carved moldings and cook in the ground-floor kitchens, sending food upstairs to the dining room by dumbwaiter.Eventually though, brownstones  in much of Brooklyn became associated with the working class, and then the poor, who moved in when the buildings were divided into rooming houses. People with money, by and large, didn't want brownstones in Brooklyn; they wanted to live in apartment buildings in Manhattan or houses in the suburbs.All that of course has changed. Brownstones are chic. They're appreciated. And of course they're appreciating. Houses that were affordable to the middle class not long ago are now homes for the rich, some selling for $1.1 million and more in well-established brownstone neighborhoods like Park Slope, and  $750,000 in Fort Greene and Clinton Hill.There is however, a section of Brooklyn that is close to Manhattan and still has hundreds of town houses and brownstones occupied by regular working and professional people: Bedford-Stuyvesant. To the people who live there, mostly African-Americans or those with Caribbean roots, it is a tight-knit, family-oriented community that has been saddled with a negative image that does not reflect the reality there.To real estate brokers it is a gold mine, just waiting to be discovered by newcomers who have no idea of its charms, of its thousands of historic homes just 15 minutes on the A train from downtown Manhattan.Everett H. Ortner, chairman of the citywide Brownstone Revival Coalition, says Bed-Stuy may have as many as 6,000 brownstones, perhaps more than any other neighborhood. ''The quality is superb,'' he said. When houses go on the market,  brokers say they are often priced at less than $300,000.Walking the streets of Bed-Stuy, it feels like many other brownstone neighborhoods did 10 or 15 years ago, before they became home to chic little shops and restaurants. Lovely homes fill block after block, but the commercial activity consists mainly of beauty parlors, nail salons and other prosaic services and products.Some of the main commercial streets are dotted with vacant storefronts. On a hot day, it is hard to find a shop selling sandwiches or ice cream cones. ''You can go block after block and not see a grocery store,'' said Kenneth Adams, president of the Brooklyn Chamber of Commerce. ''There's a lag on the commercial side.''That disparity between the quality of the housing and the variety of stores is something that is starting to change, and if it does in any significant way, the neighborhood will become more appealing to people who  associate city life with a convenient cup of coffee.Recently, local people have started the kinds of enterprises they want to patronize. Jean Williams-Cutler, a native of Jamaica, and her husband, Timothy Cutler, an Englishman, opened a small, casual restaurant  at the corner of Marcy and Putnam Avenues last fall called Doctor's Cave Cafe, after the beach in Jamaica where they met 11 years ago. Ms. Williams-Cutler said they decided to open a cafe in the building they have owned and lived in for 10 years because the space had been occupied by a ''greasy spoon'' and they believed the neighborhood needed better restaurants. Ms. Williams-Cutler, a nurse, and her husband, a lawyer, serve things like homemade pizza, quiche, roasted oxtail, pastas and curry.Not far away, on Lewis Avenue, Monique Greenwood and her husband, Glenn Pogue,  have bought a building with five commercial spaces, all to be rented by local entrepreneurs, and six apartments above. A  bookstore called Brownstone Books is scheduled to open, as is an antiques store called the Parlor Floor. And in July, when the new stores open, Ms. Greenwood and Mr. Pogue will start a cafe, named Mirrors by their 8-year-old daughter, Glynn, ''so people can come in and see their beauty,'' Ms. Greenwood said.They already own a restaurant on the same block, Akwaaba, opened two years ago, and a few blocks away on McDonough Street, the Akwaaba Mansion, where they cater to a bed-and-breakfast clientele in four elegantly furnished rooms in their 18-room house. ''Akwaaba'' means ''welcome'' in Ghana.MS. GREENWOOD, who is also the editor in chief of Essence magazine, said she and her husband became entranced with the neighborhood when they went on a tour of historic homes 11 years ago that was sponsored by the local Brownstoners. ''First we fell in love with the houses,'' Ms. Greenwood said, ''and then with the people who lived in the houses.'' The community, she said, ''has everything I would ever want, except some amenities.''Her passion for the neighborhood is typical among many of those who own the brownstones, many of them with their original details intact and some of them part of the official Stuyvesant Heights Historic District. It is not unusual to meet people in Bed-Stuy with extended family in their homes or on the same block. Houses tend to stay in the same family for decades.It is that stability that seems threatened by the sudden interest by brokers in selling the homes to people who are not from the neighborhood. Residents complain of aggressive door-to-door solicitations by brokers seeking listings, and offering to pay cash. Brokers who have for years done business in Bed-Stuy say they have to find more listings in the neighborhood to satisfy potential buyers who can't find anything they can afford in neighboring Clinton Hill or Fort Greene.Eva M. Daniels, who has her own real estate company in Fort Greene, says escalating prices have put houses in Clinton Hill and Fort Greene beyond the reach of many aspiring buyers. ''Bed-Stuy,'' she said, ''is a very hot community right now. I cannot tell you how many calls I get every day asking for Bed-Stuy.''But prices are rising quickly. She said she received a call from a mortgage broker recently looking for comparables for a house that was selling for $365,000. Last year, Ms. Daniels said, she sold eight houses in Bed-Stuy, and the one that went for $265,000 was considered high at the time.  Now, the same house might be $310,000.Right now, she said, ''I have three listings in Bed-Stuy, and it's not enough. I'm setting out to increase my listings. You write letters. You make calls. I know a lot of people. I get a lot of referrals.'' Her two grown sons live in the neighborhood, and she said it's a place that has ''only gotten better, and it was never as bad as people thought it was.''A few years ago, she said, people from outside the neighborhood were typically uninterested in renting there. Now, she said, she is renting floor-through apartments for $900 a month or so, and duplexes for as much as $1,800.Brokers say that people interested in Bed-Stuy rarely ask about schools, but that if clients do ask, the brokers refer them to books that evaluate local public schools.The area is also receiving a new focus from the Corcoran Group, a large and aggressive Manhattan-based broker that has been expanding its Brooklyn operations and  expects to open a new office in Fort Greene in late September. Jerry Minsky, who will be the managing director of downtown sales for that office, said Bed-Stuy has as many as 20 blocks in its historic district alone of ''fabulously intact town houses.''For the entire neighborhood, he estimates that the average selling price of a town house last year was $180,963, up from $156,006 the year before. He believes he has customers who can pay between $350,000 and $399,000 who would buy in Bed-Stuy because they can't afford Clinton Hill or Fort Greene, and they want ''museum condition'' brownstones.That is exactly the kind of price hike that will make it difficult for young people who have grown up in Bed-Stuy to remain. ''Bed-Stuy is a community of extended family,'' said Tohma Faulkner, a member of the Brownstoners of Bedford-Stuyvesant, the local group dedicated to preserving the old housing. She owns a house with her sister, which they share with their mother. ''Young people are having problems coming back,'' she said. ''My goddaughter is going to law school. When she comes back in three or four years to buy a house, she's priced out.''Bed-Stuy may not be known to outsiders for its tight community of brownstone owners, but that community has existed for years. ''There have always been middle-income and upper-income African-Americans there -- sophisticated, well-educated people,'' said Jerome Krase, chairman of the sociology department at Brooklyn College and the Murray Koppelman professor. But, he said, because of racism, and because Bed-Stuy was populated by blacks, ''people figured it was a slum.''The area has had a high percentage of poor people for decades, as well as problems with abandoned housing. But the city, as well as nonprofit groups like the Bedford-Stuyvesant Restoration Corporation and the Bridge Street Development Corporation,  have made progress toward solving some of those problems.The New York City Department of Housing Preservation and Development has, in partnership with nonprofit groups and developers, had 700 two-  and three-family houses built in Bed-Stuy in the last decade, and 2,800 housing units rehabilitated. The commissioner, Richard T. Roberts, said that the city had also encouraged retail development, particularly on Fulton Street, that has led to some services people in the neighborhood said they needed, like a sit-down restaurant, Choices by Oasis.The city has contracted with developers that have successfully renovated and resold most of the 79 brownstones that the city owned in the neighborhood.Charles Brass, president of the New York City Housing Partnership, said the buyers of the 900 new homes his group has completed are stable, employed people earning incomes up to $70,000. ''There haven't been any defaults to speak of,'' he said. ''In all of our projects, there's still strong demand.''THOSE houses let people know that the neighborhood is not being ignored. ''The infrastructure has gotten much better,'' said Bryant Johnson McInnis, who has published a book with photos and text about Bed-Stuy, called ''Glory in a Snapshot.''The rehab of vacant buildings has made a major change,'' said Mr. McInnis, a homeowner in the neighborhood who is the assistant director of Neighborhood Housing Services' Bed-Stuy office.The biggest change now needs to come in the commercial area, according to Charles Atwell, a longtime broker and property manager who owns Stuyvesant Heights Realty. Mr. Atwell is disappointed that more local people are not starting businesses. A space that's 900 square feet, he said, rents for only $1,200 a month. With the influx of brokers from elsewhere and the rising residential prices, he fears that when businesses do arrive to cater to the newcomers, they will be run by outsiders, or national chains.It is difficult to generalize about crime in Bedford-Stuyvesant, because the area is covered by several police precincts. But  crime figures for the first four and a half months of this year, a police spokesman said, show that incidences in all the major categories, like murder, robbery and burglary, are down from last year at the same time, for the area bounded by Fulton Street on the south, Halsey Street on the north, Tompkins Avenue on the west and Stuyvesant Avenue on the east, which includes the historic district. Only the incidence of rape has increased.The changes in Bed-Stuy are taking place in an area with strong block associations and so many churches that some blocks have more than one. In fact, it was the presence of the churches that led Laurie Cumbo to open Bed-Stuy's first museum this year.Ms. Cumbo, a graduate of Spelman College in Atlanta with a master's in arts administration from New York University, did her thesis on Bed-Stuy's ability to support a museum. Studies showed, she said, that people of African-American descent who attended museums regularly were also dedicated churchgoers. That was one thing that led her to believe that the community -- with by her count 82 churches -- was ripe for a museum.Ms. Cumbo, 25, circulated her thesis to local politicians and church groups and found interest from Bridge Street Church, a black congregation now located on Stuyvesant Avenue that was formed in 1766. This year, in 1,000 square feet of the church's newly renovated space, she opened Mocada, an acronym for Museum of Contemporary  African Diasporian Arts. Her current show, of work by Melvin Clark, attracted 300 people to its opening reception.The museum is just one outlet for artists. Some Bed-Stuy artists are showing their work through a relatively new group called  Sonya, which stands for South of the Navy Yard Artists. Gigi Stankiewicz, an artist who creates works based on the human genome project, lives on Classon Avenue in Bed-Stuy. Although people associate lofts with artists, she says brownstones provide good working space because of the high ceilings on the parlor floors.Ms. Stankiewicz moved to New York after receiving her master's degree from the Rhode Island School of Design, and says she is particularly charmed by Bed-Stuy because she lived in Newport for six years and  likes the historic houses and quiet streets in both places. ''There is a renaissance going on here,'' she said. ''Homes are getting fixed up. We're at the beginning.''Some of the significant art activity in Bed-Stuy isn't immediately obvious, but it is there, and growing. Benjamin and Elaine Antonetty recently opened an art gallery on the parlor floor of their Jefferson Avenue brownstone, which they bought two years ago. It had been a rooming house occupied by 13 tenants, many of them not even paying  rent, said Mr. Antonetty. Over a year, first by persuasion and then by legal action, he removed the tenants, and when they were gone began restoring the house.Now, their new home is a showplace. Mr. Antonetty worked as the general contractor, having all of the wainscoting stripped and the carved wooden moldings returned to their original state. ''Everything was painted,'' he said, even the subtly colored tiles in front of the fireplaces.Everything is returned to its original glory, with mahogany on the parlor floor, cherry on the second, and beech on the top. Mr. Antonetty has a passion, he says, for wood, which may be the source of his strong feeling for these 19th-century houses. ''To me, wood is strength,'' he said.Mrs. Antonetty, who grew up in Fort Greene, and Mr. Antonetty, who grew up in a public housing project in Bushwick, moved to Bed-Stuy 15 years ago, and before buying their new house lived in one next door that they still own. ''We fell in love with brownstones,'' she said. Their new house reflects the melding of Victorian and African influences, with a new stained-glass image in their front door that is an African symbol for belief in god.They run their art business, which includes a framing shop, the gallery -- Aviva Arts, which is open by appointment only -- and a mobile gallery, where companies allow them to sell directly to the employees. They sell mostly lithographs, serigraphs and original paintings by people of African descent.NEARBY, Doreen de Leon, a native of Grenada, lives in a brownstone on Jefferson Avenue that she bought in 1984 for $60,000. She also has her own real estate company in Brooklyn, which she started shortly after retiring from her job as a bacteriologist. She also has occasional art shows on the parlor floor of her home.Ms. de Leon said she does a lot of sales and rentals in the area. Apartments that rent for about $1,000 a month, she said, would be $1,500 in Fort Greene, and they are drawing people with their fireplaces and parquet floors. ''The majority of calls are people coming from Manhattan,'' she said.For longtime homeowners, the new attractiveness of their neighborhood is both annoying and gratifying. Demetrice Mills,  who works in computer systems on Wall Street, lives with his wife and three children on Classon Avenue. He came to New York 27 years ago as a teenager on his own from North Carolina and moved into a rooming house. He fell in love with the owner's daughter; they married, and eventually bought the house from her parents. They still own that house, as well as another on Classon that they now occupy.The influx of real estate people looking for listings, he said, is grating on longtime residents. ''There's a door-to-door campaign by realtors,'' he said, started in the last year. People have even posted notices saying they will pay cash for houses.''A lot of the neighbors are quite upset with that,'' he said. ''It's like an invasion. There's the sense that white people are coming to buy our houses, that we are being pushed out of our neighborhood.''It's disturbing, he said, that family members who might want to keep a house won't be able to afford to buy it from relatives. The neighborhood has a family feeling, he said, that is most evident in barber shops, where young boys and old men and every age in between hang out, talking, even if they're not getting haircuts.He hopes, he said, that newcomers will become part of this open, friendly neighborhood, and that they will send their children to the local schools. He tries, too, to look at the economic benefits of the change that is just beginning.African-American homeowners, he said, will have property that is far more valuable than it has been, property they can leverage, through home equity loans, into cash to improve their lives, to send their children to college. And maybe, to help them buy the more-expensive homes in their old neighborhood.
