Mr. Gorton has long feuded with some tribes over fishing rights and sovereignty issues. The Indian groups said they expected to spend $1 million or more, with some of the money coming from tribes with gambling casinos in other states. Ron Allen, chairman of a tribe on the Olympic Peninsula of Washington, called Mr. Gorton ''the most vociferous opponent of tribal sovereignty that Congress has seen in 40 years.'' Mr. Gorton told The Post-Intelligencer: ''They have a total right to do what they want in the political world. I have a very good record on supporting the appropriate ambitions of Indian peoples, but I will continue to fiercely protect the rights of their non-Indian neighbors. If they don't like that, they have every right to try to beat me. They are not going to succeed.''Sam Howe Verhovek (NYT)ELECTION COMPLAINT IN NEVADA -- The Nevada Republican Party has filed a complaint with the Federal Election Commission over advertisements by a lawyer who is running for the Senate as a Democrat. The television and billboard advertisements do not mention the candidacy of the lawyer, Ed Bernstein, but focus instead on his law practice. But state Republican leaders say Mr. Bernstein's intention is to gain an unfair advantage over his opponent, Representative John Ensign. The Republicans say the promotions amount to illegal campaign contributions from his law firm. ''Bernstein has officially filed with the secretary of state and the F.E.C., however, his face remains on corporate-financed billboards across Nevada and his law firm commercials continue to air touting him as a caring person,'' said Ryan Erwin, executive director of Nevada's Republican Party. Mr. Bernstein said the advertisements have no connection to the campaign. The latest billboard, with a legal assistant saying ''Ed Bernstein cares,'' went up this week.(AP)
THOMAS KUHNA Philosophical History for Our Times.By Steve Fuller.472 pp. Chicago:The University of Chicago Press. $35.THOMAS KUHNA Philosophical History for Our Times.By Steve Fuller.472 pp. Chicago:The University of Chicago Press. $35.One of the few books that most college graduates in this anticanonical age are expected to have heard of, if not to have read, is ''The Structure of Scientific Revolutions,'' by Thomas S. Kuhn. First published in 1962, when its author was a 40-year-old professor of history at Berkeley, it has been translated into two dozen languages and is cited in countless articles and books spanning virtually all social scientific and humanistic disciplines. Journalists report that it is Vice President Al Gore's favorite book. Yet ''The Structure of Scientific Revolutions'' was written for philosophers, not the general public. It is relentlessly academic. Dozens of more accessible books about science and its history are forgotten soon after they appear. Why did this treatise on scientific development become one of the most influential academic books of the 20th century? The question is given point by the fact that most defenders of this book, to say nothing of its critics, acknowledge that many of its arguments are flawed.One person who thinks he has the whole Kuhn episode figured out is Steve Fuller, a philosophically trained sociologist at the University of Warwick in England. In ''Thomas Kuhn: A Philosophical History for Our Times,'' Fuller asserts that most people who take Kuhn seriously just aren't very clever: Kuhn's book is so vague as to be an inkblot; people make of it what they will. This has long been one standard answer to the question of Kuhn's popularity. Kuhn was a lightweight, in this telling, and his influence is a sign of our ostensibly dreadful times, when even the learned can't tell a mediocre mind from an intellectual giant. A second answer, also of long standing, is that ''The Structure of Scientific Revolutions'' contained a lot of good ideas about how science works. In this view, Kuhn's ability to speak effectively to certain specific interests compensated for the holes in his analysis, and made it possible for people who were not fools to get a great deal out of the book.Both answers begin with the same basic understanding of how Kuhn challenged inherited views of science. Before Kuhn, most people understood scientific progress in terms of a series of heroic individual discoveries that contributed to an accumulating body of knowledge warranted, ultimately, by nature itself. Kuhn argued that tightly organized communities of specialists, not individual minds, were the central actors in scientific development, and that these communities made progress in two distinctive modes. In ''normal science,'' researchers did narrow, technical work guided by a ''paradigm,'' a view of the field that served as a set of predictions for what investigators would find. When these researchers observed, instead, a lot of things that did not fit, the community entered a period of ''revolutionary science.'' In this mode, the community debated the utility of alternative paradigms and eventually selected one that explained a greater range of relevant phenomena and promised to guide the next phase of normal science.Kuhn went on to suggest that scientific development is best seen not as progress toward a fixed goal set by nature but as progress from existing knowledge toward more fully confirmed answers to questions scientists put to nature. Since the questions themselves sometimes change, the progress of science is discontinuous.But most philosophers and historians soon came to the conclusion that Kuhn's signature concept of the paradigm was frustratingly vague. They generally agreed, too, that his pivotal distinction between revolutionary and normal science was hard to sustain. Even some of the great revolutions in biology and physics, moreover, proved hard to shoehorn into his model. Many thinkers who were convinced by Kuhn's case for the historical contingency of scientific truth conceded that his formulations were too ambiguous to play more than a heuristic role in the conversation about ''relativism'' he had stimulated.Fuller carries the dismissal of Kuhn and his sympathetic readers to a snide extreme. Kuhn himself, who died in 1996 as an emeritus professor at M.I.T., emerges from Fuller's account as a well-meaning simpleton. Fuller explicitly compares him to Chance, the character played by Peter Sellers in the movie ''Being There,'' based on Jerzy Kosinski's novel. Chance finds himself in a conversation he does not quite understand, and says things that other people misinterpret as profound because they believe he is someone else. Kuhn's relation to his audience, Fuller declares, is ''a similar comedy of errors.'' Kuhn was the proverbial dwarf standing on the shoulders of giants. From a distance, ''the dwarf may look like the head of the tallest giant.''Fuller provides glimpses of a potentially provocative analysis of the political matrix of Kuhn's popularity. But he implausibly attributes to personal connections much of Kuhn's rise to prominence, as if readers cared that Kuhn was a protege of James B. Conant, a former president of Harvard University. Fuller's Kuhn is also a political cat's-paw for the more worldly Conant, whom Fuller presents as a defender of Big Science who was happy with an image of science as too specialized and autonomous to be subject to public control. Fuller sees ''The Structure of Scientific Revolutions'' as ''an exemplary document of the cold war era,'' and says its chief impact has been ''to dull the critical sensibility of the academy.''''Thomas Kuhn: A Philosophical History for Our Times'' is nearly unreadable by any but the most devoted maven of the sectarian disputes between specialists in the sociology and philosophy of science. Copious and polemical footnotes exhaust even a professional reader's patience. If a prize were awarded to the academic who persuaded a major publisher to accept the most footnotes citing himself, Fuller would be a strong contender. He makes almost no effort to explore the numerous substantial justifications for the second, more generous explanation for Kuhn's influence. Kuhn spoke directly, if unintentionally, to a widespread honest curiosity about how science related to the psychology and politics of nonscientific experience.Kuhn emphasized the power of pre-conceived ideas to control the observations of scientists, and insisted that without the focusing effect of these ideas investigators would not be able actually to see the phenomena the explanation of which was essential to the creating of new knowledge. A fully ''open'' mind cannot focus on the relevant particulars. What made this contribution so important was the widespread presumption that scientists, rather than being bound by preconceptions, were open-minded in the sense of always questioning inherited ideas. Kuhn's emphasis was not unique among his generation's theorists of science.But Kuhn developed the point compellingly with concrete examples and with a social-psychological language that enabled a range of readers to grasp the function of provisionally unquestioned presuppositions. What was equally important, he assimilated the behavior of scientific communities into popularly understood theories of the dynamics of other human communities while simultaneously offering an account of the distinctiveness of the most technically developed of natural sciences.HE applied to science a vocabulary normally used to describe political actors, especially during revolutions. Communities of scientists, like political communities, were organized by certain traditions that periodically came under strain and were then revised, sometimes sweepingly. The leaders of both kinds of communities were genuine wielders of power, who used their positions to bring their constituencies into line.But, while Kuhn thus opened up the entire domain of science for political analysis, he argued that the behaviorally visible mark of a truly scientific community was its high degree of autonomy, its ability to exercise authority over its own intellectual affairs. He confirmed the instinct that science was ''really different.'' But he also showed that scientists, within their domain, behaved very much like the rest of us.''The Structure of Scientific Revolutions'' presented the strongest case ever made for the dependence of valid science on distinctively constituted, historically particular human communities. Far from dulling the academy's critical capacities, Kuhn directed those capacities at scientific communities that were previously spared the searching scrutiny he inspired. He demystified science without degrading it, and in so doing he saw beyond previous theorists of science without denigrating them.David A. Hollinger teaches history at the University of California, Berkeley. His most recent book is ''Science, Jews, and Secular Culture.''
I STOOD shivering, as quietly as I could, as afternoon shadows stretched across the river around us. The water was above my waist, lapping at the bib of my neoprene coveralls, and there was nothing to insulate me from the conclusion that I was out of my depth. Barely 20 feet away my adversary had begun to taunt me, rising to the surface to slurp down every defenseless bug around -- save the imposter at the end of my line. I cast my rod again, a bit less awkwardly. Again I was ignored.I reminded myself that we had come to this far corner of northern California for more than just the fish. My father and I had both been tempted by friends' stories about the spare beauty of the place, the open spaces and the quiet.I STOOD shivering, as quietly as I could, as afternoon shadows stretched across the river around us. The water was above my waist, lapping at the bib of my neoprene coveralls, and there was nothing to insulate me from the conclusion that I was out of my depth. Barely 20 feet away my adversary had begun to taunt me, rising to the surface to slurp down every defenseless bug around -- save the imposter at the end of my line. I cast my rod again, a bit less awkwardly. Again I was ignored.I reminded myself that we had come to this far corner of northern California for more than just the fish. My father and I had both been tempted by friends' stories about the spare beauty of the place, the open spaces and the quiet.Hours into our first encounter with fly fishing, we seemed already to be sloughing off some outer skin of our city lives. A few days of this, we figured, would be a nice chance to spend some time together without much else going on. We might even learn to handle a fly rod.Not so long before, I had felt proudly immune to the plague of fly-fishing madness that followed Robert Redford's film ''A River Runs Through It.'' Surely, I thought, life was too short to spend whole, tedious hours of it fashioning little ersatz bugs. Not to mention the countless innocent trout that would be quarry for stockbrokers got up like Brad Pitt.Several years passed, though, and the fad faded. I found myself being preached to by a couple of friends whose commitment to the sport apparently involved some secret vow to convert others; my qualms began to erode. But there were still hurdles: the expensive fishing gear, the various complex knots, the abiding mystery of the ersatz bugs.Our solution was a company called Clearwater Trout Tours. Clearwater runs both a guiding service and a fly-fishing school out of a small inn on Hat Creek, an hour's drive east from Redding and at the center of some of the best wild trout waters in the west. Many of its customers are anglers who know what they're doing and can choose where they want to do it.But the company and its proprietor, Dick Galland, have a strong pedagogical bent, and they offer instruction that ranges from basic techniques to a course for experts called The Enlightened Master.The standard beginners' class that we took first, in the fall of 1997, was called Mastering the Art of Fly Fishing. Given that we started after lunch on a Wednesday and finished up at noon the following Sunday, mastery was hardly in the cards. But our instructors balanced their respect for the sport's complexities with an attitude that we ought to learn quickly enough to enjoy the experience, catch some fish and be able to venture out again on our own.After our first few hours, I wondered whether this wasn't like taking a quick Berlitz course in Chinese. Our class of six -- my father and I; a businessman from Los Angeles and his daughter, a radio executive; and a married couple in their late 30's -- had assembled around a big wooden table in the main dining room of the lodge. Our instructors passed out handbooks, and they looked encouragingly thin. But by the sixth page the booklet was already diagramming something called a ''double-surgeon's knot.'' By page 21 it was advising on the proper deployment of a ''slip-bobber and minjig combination.'' Then we started to practice some basic knots, and I was reminded why I'd never made it to Weebelo.Fly fishing is essentially an elaborate fraud. It is perpetrated by choosing a faux bug to match whatever the fish are eating, disguising the bug's provenance with a very thin nylon line, and then serving up line and bug with an elegance that would test the best Parisian waiters. Trout are not as dumb as they look: if the end of one's line is not assembled of the proper monofilament and properly turned knots, it will slop down before a fish with all the subtlety of a burger at Hooters.Surprisingly enough, though, even the double-surgeon's knot turned out to be doable. After a while, the tackle started to seem less complicated. A lesson on different kinds of trout water was altogether understandable, and we began to relax. Then we went outside.From the sleepy two-lane road that runs through the center of Cassel, Calif. (that is, the post office, the fire station and a small general store), we hadn't at first noticed the long, smooth lawn behind Clearwater's hedges. The grass turned out to be very well suited to the practice of fly casting, and we practiced for quite a while, catching many trees. The rule of our group seemed to be that the less strength one had, the more quickly one grasped the rhythm and stroke that would turn the line overhead in a tight, graceful curve and then roll it out so that the fly dropped delicately at its outstretched end.Before the sun had set, we were all tired enough to retire to the lodge for popcorn and beer. Clearwater House is a modest but comfortable place, furnished with arts and crafts pieces and decorated with fishing photographs and river maps. The end tables are stacked with copies of The New Yorker and National Geographic; the book shelves are filled with volumes like ''The Way of a Trout,'' and the encyclopedic ''Caddisflies.'' Old jazz plays on the stereo. The seven guest rooms are fairly small; most have twin beds and all have private baths. Guests can help themselves to homemade cookies and fresh coffee in the dining room or to juice and soft drinks from a refrigerator on the enclosed back porch.Breakfasts and dinners, served around big tables in the front and back of the house, were never elegant but always good. In the evenings we fished along a nearby stretch of Hat Creek, with Mount Lassen rising in the distance, or watched such classics of fish video as ''Anatomy of a Trout Stream'' (in which case about half of us usually fell asleep on the living room couches). A more adventurous night might consist of a trip to the 50's-era bowling lanes in the nearby town of Burney, or a drink at the old hotel in Fall River Mills.For our first long day on the water our two guides and their apprentice chose a stretch of lower Hat Creek that was shady and relatively slow. The trout were rising so infrequently that I couldn't help wondering about our chances. But by scooping a large screen into the water, our guides were able to show us what they might be eating below the surface: the tiny underwater form of aquatic insects, known as nymphs.Duly prepared, we embarked on the practice of ''short-line nymphing.'' This involved casting tiny nymphlike flies upstream and a few feet below the surface with the aid of a tiny lead weight that we attached near the end of the line. We had been instructed to watch our lines closely as the fly drifted with the current, and to set the hook deftly at the slightest sign of line being tugged.It was the deft-setting-of-the-hook part that took some work. Although we fished with small fluorescent indicators stuck on our lines -- the training wheels of short-line nymphing -- the slightest pull from a submerged rock or weed was generally enough to prompt us to rip our rods skyward, as in one of those television fishing shows in which the angler hooks a huge marlin. Unfortunately, the technique turns out to be both ineffective for catching trout and unhelpful in keeping one's balance on the slick rocks of the riverbed.The ethic at Clearwater and at most other fly fishing schools is ''catch and release.'' This means no trout dinners. More important, it means that the tiny hooks on the flies have no barbs, making it imperative that one keep the line taut once a fish finds the end of it.My own experience was that the rare, hooked trout liked to swim frantically in all directions. This generally prompted shouts from the nearest guide about proper positioning, and I usually responded to this instruction by joining my fish in a wild, thrashing dance that must have looked something like Joe Cocker on speed.OUR guides would not have passed central casting. I had expected weathered older men in goofy, fly-blown hats, spooning out fish wisdom like cough syrup. Instead we got Mike Peters, an erstwhile ski-racing coach from Mammoth, Calif., and Scott Saiki, a 27-year-old Hawaiian-born surfer and snowboarder whose command of fly fishing technique was impressive even to his fellow guides. Both were as patient as they were knowledgeable (and our second visit to Clearwater last summer suggested that they were by no means the exception).Clearwater's owner, Dick Galland, was a pioneer in some of the early Outward Bound programs in Colorado and Texas, and one of his earliest ventures in fishing instruction was a course he taught in San Francisco in the late 1970's called Zen and the Art of Fly Fishing. There is nothing too touchy-feely about Clearwater's approach these days, but the emphasis remains clearly on how one learns to fly-fish rather than on how many one might catch.This began to make clearer sense to me on the third day of our ''mastering'' class. We set off for a lower section of the Pit River, a place that our guides referred to portentously as the Pit. The fish beckoned to us from about 300 feet below the road, in water that cut through a canyon spread with brilliant fall colors.Wading slowly through the strong current, fighting to keep our balance, it seemed that fly fishing had become a contact sport. Then, wherever we stopped, it was as though we were meeting the fish all over again, this time with the proper introductions. Our nymphing began to look less awkward, and most of us actually caught a few fish.The next afternoon we found ourselves in an even more spectacular setting, a spot along Hat Creek called Carbon Flats. Iridescent grasses glowed in the clear water, and even from the banks above we could see big silvery shapes working their way lazily upstream. These trout, it turned out, were some of the most famously coy fish in the west. But by then we were all casting well enough to be satisfied just to stand in the slow current, soak in the sun, and practice. When a few fish began to strike, we shared the thrill.Carbon was no less compelling when my father and I returned on our second trip to Clearwater early last summer. This time we took a couple of old friends who had been fly fishing for years, and the four of us shared the wisdom and humor of two of the lodge's most experienced guides, Tom Peppas and Art Teter.As spectacular as it had been to see this swatch of northern California at the peak of its autumn foliage, June was even better. The days were warm and long and we switched from neoprene waders to lighter, more comfortable Gore-Tex versions from the Clearwater rental shop. We returned to the Pit to do some more full-impact nymphing, and then spent a quiet, enjoyable day learning to fish from skiffs on the Fall River.Almost from the start I wished that I had put in a little practice on my casting and knot-tying in the interim. But part of the joy of fishing with guides was that we could brush up as we went. If anything, Tom and Art were too accommodating, helping us out of so many tangles (literal and figurative) that I was afraid we weren't working hard enough.In the end, we felt that our mastering course had given us enough confidence to go on fishing. The knots no longer felt so complex, and we could start thinking about finer points like when to change from one type of fly to another. But none of that seemed to matter much when we went back to Carbon Flats. The setting was again magnificent, and even on a Saturday morning, we had the crystalline river all to ourselves. The trout, however, seemed to see me coming.This time, summoning all the delicacy I could, I cast again and again to what seemed like a perfect spot, just ahead of my fat prize. And the fish rose once again to taunt me, eating every bug in sight save mine.How to be outsmarted by a troutArranging an ExpeditionFor information about Clearwater Trout Tours, contact the company at Clearwater, Box 90, Cassel, Calif. 96016 or call (415) 381-1173 (especially in the winter months) or (530) 335-5500. The lodge is open for guided fishing from the beginning of the trout season in late April until it ends in November. Classes usually run from early May until October.Clearwater can be reached from San Francisco (just under six hours by car), from Sacramento (about five hours) and from Reno (slightly less than three hours).ClassesThe basic ''mastering'' class costs $995 a person for four nights' lodging, all meals, equipment rental and instruction. There are also intermediate and expert-level courses for both men and women, as well as three courses designed for women, including a women-only ''mastering'' course. Students must buy their own flies and some of their own tackle and fishing licenses, at an added cost of about $100 for the course. Tips to the lodge staff (10 percent of meal and accommodation charges per guest) and the guides ($50 to $90 per guest) are customary but optional.Private guiding packages are available throughout the season for $315 a person, including all meals and overnight lodging (double occupancy). Intermediate and expert courses are taught every other month. In winter the company frequently runs fishing tours to such places as New Zealand's South Island, which is famous for its brown trout, and Christmas Island in the south Pacific, a mecca for bonefishing.EquipmentFly fishing is the gift that keeps on costing. Expect to pay in the $500 range for a good rod and about $200 for a good reel. Not to mention the vest, the waders (neoprene or Gore-Tex, depending on the water temperature and the season), the wading boots and the tackle. The lodge sells fine equipment in its store, but neither the guides nor anyone else made any perceptible push to sell it.TIM GOLDENTIM GOLDEN is an investigative reporter for The Times.
BECAUSE it is so contentious, the debate over reforming Social Security draws plenty of attention. So it is easy to overlook that Congress has just reformed Social Security -- enacting a change that should have been contentious but somehow wasn't.For the first time, workers in their late 60's have the choice of collecting a full pension regardless of what they earn. That can backfire. What America's senior citizens decide to do with this choice will affect their level of income -- or poverty -- in deep old age. Because of the way the new law plays to human nature, many might make the wrong choice, taking too much pension now and not enough later. Some already  have.BECAUSE it is so contentious, the debate over reforming Social Security draws plenty of attention. So it is easy to overlook that Congress has just reformed Social Security -- enacting a change that should have been contentious but somehow wasn't.For the first time, workers in their late 60's have the choice of collecting a full pension regardless of what they earn. That can backfire. What America's senior citizens decide to do with this choice will affect their level of income -- or poverty -- in deep old age. Because of the way the new law plays to human nature, many might make the wrong choice, taking too much pension now and not enough later. Some already  have.''Waiting to collect benefits is basically betting that you will live beyond the average life expectancy,'' said Peter Orszag, an economist and Social Security expert at the University of California at Berkeley. That average for people who are already 65 is 81 for men and 84 for women, and rising for both. ''When you give people in their late 60's the choice of collecting their Social Security benefits now, then you raise the odds of their being poor in real old age.''The mechanics are simple enough. Previously, people between 65 and 70 who earned more than $17,000 a year had their Social Security pension benefits reduced, and those who earned $52,000 a year or more had them postponed entirely, until they turned 70. As a quid pro quo, the monthly pension checks they ultimately received were higher.Now people in their late 60's can earn any amount and still draw full pensions. But the old quid pro quo survives: people can still voluntarily wait until 70 to get larger checks thereafter. Those who take their pensions at 65 get a head start in total benefits paid, but those who wait will overtake them in their 80's, and the longer they live, the wider the gap will grow.The monthly payment at 70, for example, would be $1,300 for someone who passed up $1,000 at 65.Congress had been moving gradually in this direction, but the new legislation, signed by President Clinton April 7, completed the process in one leap. As a byproduct in this election year, the Social Security Administration expects to deliver $6 billion in extra pension money.But that is politics. The real issues are work incentives and adequate income in very old age, particularly the latter. It is still possible to postpone collecting pension benefits until age 70, but hardly anyone has chosen to do so. Of 419,000 registered wage earners in their late 60's who were collecting either reduced benefits or none at all when the new law took effect, only 800 are still holding off until age 70.WHAT does not mean the others have all actively chosen not to wait; many were probably swept passively onto the benefit rolls. To minimize its clerical work, the Social Security Administration sent out letters announcing that all 419,000 would receive full benefits automatically, unless they called a toll-free number and specifically opted to wait. Getting through on the often-busy phone line was not easy.People who wanted to wait could also have sent back their first checks. But in defiance of a main tenet of mainstream economics, that people make rational decisions in their best interest, hardly anyone returned the checks. ''People in their 60's in good health whose parents lived long lives should rationally choose to defer,'' said Henry Aaron, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution. ''But there is a tendency to want your money now.'' Particularly when it is in hand and substantial; the first checks averaged $3,500, retroactively covering the first four months of the year.There is a second irrational tendency among people drawing both paychecks and benefit checks: to spend the pension rather than save for future retirement, increasing the odds of poverty later. But Congress gave in to an irrational outcry from working people in their late 60's who complained with growing frequency that withholding benefits was an unjust ''tax'' on work.''There is a real misperception out there that when the money is withheld it is gone; they will never see it again,'' said Kenneth S. Apfel, commissioner of Social Security. ''The number of seniors who perceive this is not insignificant.''So Congress acted. Federal surpluses helped to make the action politically palatable. So did another misperception: that in a robust economy suffering labor shortages, removing the earnings limits would encourage senior citizens to work a lot more. The most optimistic studies fail to support this contention. Hours worked will rise 5 percent at most, or roughly the equivalent of 50,000 full-time workers a year. That is what today's strong economy absorbs in a week.Maybe there is a lesson here for judging the Gore and Bush proposals for Social Security reform: Look for the misperceptions.ECONOMIC VIEW
The good news about education has become obvious: the quality of public schools is now on center stage in national politics. From George Bush and Al Gore down to aspirants for state and local office, all politicians have embraced the cause of high standards and excellence. The bad news is that the remedy everyone but teachers and pupils wants to prescribe is more testing.The mistrust of schools and teachers has become so widespread that the only politically viable solution seems to be to impose more standardized tests. Forty-nine states have now adopted curriculum standards that explicitly require testing in order to measure the performance of pupils, teachers, principals, and superintendents; by 2003, 26 states will have mandatory statewide tests for high school graduation. As a nation, we now administer at least 500,000 different kinds of standardized tests a year.The good news about education has become obvious: the quality of public schools is now on center stage in national politics. From George Bush and Al Gore down to aspirants for state and local office, all politicians have embraced the cause of high standards and excellence. The bad news is that the remedy everyone but teachers and pupils wants to prescribe is more testing.The mistrust of schools and teachers has become so widespread that the only politically viable solution seems to be to impose more standardized tests. Forty-nine states have now adopted curriculum standards that explicitly require testing in order to measure the performance of pupils, teachers, principals, and superintendents; by 2003, 26 states will have mandatory statewide tests for high school graduation. As a nation, we now administer at least 500,000 different kinds of standardized tests a year.Testing has also become big business. We spend more than $200 million a year on it. The market for standardized tests is growing faster than that for textbooks. Unfortunately, the two go together all too neatly; three publishing companies dominate the market for tests and textbooks alike.The tyranny of testing has become so intense that teachers may find themselves spending more than half the year teaching specifically for tests; their jobs and the standing of their schools are on the line. Not surprisingly, some teachers in New York and Maryland have been accused of cheating to improve their pupils' test scores.The problem is that our mode of testing is primitive and out of date. We still adhere to the so-called ''objective,'' machine-readable examinations pioneered in the mid-1950's. In the case of the Regents examination in New York, the questions themselves are often confusing or deliberately obscure and sometimes even embody errors.Who, after all, is writing our English and mathematics tests? Not our leading writers, scholars and mathematicians. Furthermore, we still confuse speed with competence. Knowledge and understanding are not about rapid reflexes; learning is not a sport. Quickness of recall does not indicate depth of understanding.Nor do all pupils know the right answer in the same manner or get the wrong answer or fail to grasp something the same way. Knowledge and skills are always approximations. A pupil who confuses World War I with World War II knows something more than one who mistakes World War I for the American Revolution. Today's testing instruments do not effectively account for how and what pupils know.Even worse, they are not designed  to measure the rate of change in each test taker. When we go for a medical checkup, we are evaluated not only in terms of an objective standard of health but on the progress or deterioration in our own particular bodies since the last examination.The most egregious aspect of our mania for testing is that pupils never find out what they got wrong and why they got it wrong. High school students taking the Regents exams in New York do not get their tests back; neither do the vast majority of millions of children taking Iowa and Stanford tests or statewide reading exams. Most often, even the teachers don't get the results back in time to help them in their teaching.What is the use of test results that are released months later, measuring a classroom, a school, a district or a state in terms of aggregate test scores? Would we tolerate a system in sports where the calls of umpires and linesmen remained a secret until the next season and the hits and errors of particular players were never revealed or justified?In Texas, studies have shown that weeks after taking the Texas Assessment of Academic skills test created in the 1990's, pupils fail to show the apparent mastery of knowledge registered when they first took the tests.Testing can and must be linked to learning. A mistake (and right answers) must be analyzed and corrected immediately for each pupil individually, just the way we respond when we teach sports and music. As it stands today, testing is little more than an adult political obsession that just results in more tests and profits for test makers.Yet we now possess the means to change testing fundamentally. Rapid advances in computers and declining costs make powerful new technologies, once reserved for government and industry, accessible: technology involving complex computer simulation, as in pilot training, and manipulation of data. We can design tests that are interactive in a way that both helps learning and raises the standards of education. Even for young children, it would be possible to throw away the No. 2 pencils and machine-scanned answer sheets, and have the student tested at the computer itself.There needs to be an initiative between government and the software industry to develop a new generation of tests. Programs can be written that inform the test taker immediately why the answer was right or wrong and that lead the pupil through the logic of the question to confirm understanding or correct ignorance. Politicians and school boards can still get their treasured measurements of timed test scores; as players are timed in  a chess game, the clock for each test taker can stop and start as the individual goes through every question, discovering how and why he or she arrived at answers.Computers also make it possible to measure the rate of change for each pupil -- indicating not only the student's progress but the teacher's effectiveness. Diagnostic tests at the beginning of each year can be designed that reveal what a pupil can and cannot do or does and does not know, establishing a baseline. If in the same classroom one fifth grader reads only at a second-grade level and another on an eighth-grade level, a teacher should be evaluated by what is learned by each of them over the course of a year.Connecting testing to learning could also free teachers from forced adherence to bland state-approved textbooks. They would be given the opportunity to select and choose materials that meet the needs of each pupil. They would be able to justify the sort of differentiated, case-by-case decisions for which true professionals should be trained.Reforming testing practices to make all this happen, however, will not be easy. Because software companies and the entrenched testing and textbook industry respond to short-term profit motives, public investment will be required for the longer-term work of adapting computer technologies to a new kind of testing.Without a radical reform in the way we test, there will be no improvement in learning and educational standards. We can bridge the gap between those who are passionate about measuring standards and those who are ideologically opposed to testing as discriminatory and unfair.What our politicians are offering us now is more of the same: a misguided reliance on a monopoly in a pseudoscience of testing that defines teaching and depresses learning.Leon Botstein, the president of Bard College, is the author of ''Jefferson's Children: Education and the Promise of American Culture.''
